Excellent stay whilst in Tokyo. Great service, staffs are very friendly and courteous. Location is very close to the tokyo station, which offers huge array of shopping and dining options. The area can be pretty quiet on the weekend though.

I was unable to get a reservation at our previous favorite (the Mandarin Oriental) so I took a chance on this one. We certainly didn't have to settle for less--though the price was better. Expansive, comfortable rooms, excellent staff, great location (Tokyo Station is a 2 minute walk). Views from the room extended all the way to Mt Fuji. The morning breakfast service was the best we had in Japan.

We stayed three nights at the end of our trip to Japan. We wanted to finish in style and we certainly did. This is a beautifully luxurious hotel right beside Tokyo station, with great service and a fabulous pool that I used every night. We had a palace view room on the 35th floor, great view and an absolutely beautiful room.This level of experience in a hotel doesn't come cheap but if/when we're back in Tokyo, it will be hard not to stay here again.

Of course nothing good in central Tokyo comes cheap, so you'll be expecting to pay up for a five star room. Shangri-La is very good, although in my experience second to the nearby mandarin oriental. That said, shangri la has a great location literally on top of Tokyo station making it easy for airport transfers via the Narits express trains. We enjoyed a few days here with phenomenal views from our 33rd floor room. Rooms have a massive bed. Possibly the biggest bed I've ever slept in, which was excellent. The shower room is a full wet room with a bath. Robes, slippers, big towels etc. All very good. Excellent and helpful staff provided everything we needed, including an iPhone charger. Price of breakfast at 5,500 yen was a bit of a joke though (Usd55), but that's just life in high end Tokyo.

I am fortunate enough to travel to Tokyo quite frequently, and this is mr preferred hotel to stay in. The location is very good with good access to the Ginza shopping area, and some excellent restaurants; not forgetting the location to the train station makes it ideal for getting to other parts of both Tokyo and Japan. The restaurants are pricey but good quality, but the guest rooms are large and well appointed.

I was initially hesitant to stay at the Shangri La Tokyo. Although I am a member of the Golden Circle which is a loyalty club reserved for previous Shangri La occupants. I have all my life stayed at the Imperial Club for my previous business trips. However my trip this time is purely leisure to have time off with my wife and kids. It may be a bit pricey as it is a five star hotel. All the restaurant outlets are excellent from La Placere the hotel coffee shop to the Nadaman the japanese restaurant also offers excellent steak and shabu shabu. And of course with their requiistie tempura. The lobby bar also offers excellent nightlights of Tokyo. But the location is very strategic located right next to the Tokyo Station which is perhaps the main hub of Tokyo city. The hotel itself starts on the 28th floor as it is located in a Marunochi Trust Building. And the hotel goes from the 28th to the 38th floor. I have not expected my stay at the Shang to be a disappointment as I have stayed with them at their hotels in Cebu, Makati and Kuala Lumpur plus viewing their sprawling maginificent resort at Shangri La Boracay which is truly world class if not one of the finest resort hotels here in Asia. However the service and staff here is impeccable. I could not ask for more. They do get out of their way to assist you in whatever needs you may have. Service at the lobby bar and their Japanese restaurant Nadaman is tres excellent. Even their coffee shop Le Placere offers excellent service, this is where we have our breakfast. Although the buffet seems minimal and mundane, you do get an extra choice a la carte from the menu and which i normally order their eggs benedict as they do have several variations of this egg classic. The rooms are most modern with all the push button amenities and one could be initimidated at first like with the toilet bowl with the push button bidets but as one gets used to the buttons, one would find how forward thinking the japanese are. As these toilets are normally available only in Japan. Even the showers and tub have the most aesthetic designs, one would be given a sense of freedom as one indulges in the shower. I have not seen as big a shower head as i have seen in this hotel. I have only stayed at a standard de luxe room. Yes the rooms are roomy and not your standard tokyo size hotel. The beds are long and you do get enough head space in the rooms. Never do you feel claustrophic at any point in the hotel. The staff here is very friendly sincere and of course very japanese in their demure. I did check their health club and their swimming pool which is located i think on the 29th floor. It does have a spectacular view of the city especially by the pool. My 5 night stay here is most wonderful and memorable. It is centrally located where the airport limousine bus final stop is here at the hotel, All subway stations are linked at the Tokyo station which is adjacent to this hotel and takes around 5-10 minute walk from the hotel. And as a runner a most wonderful venue for a morning jog is the Imperial Palace making ones stay in Tokyo most treasurable as the palace is a runners' paradise. The shopping around Tokyo is also most accesible, as taxis abound and most shopping is around 5-10 minutes by cab from the hotel like Takashimaya or Mitsukoshi department stores. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone considering a most pleasant stay in Tokyo.

Our room at the ShangriLa Tokyo hotel is excellent as expected. What made this trip special is how the staff handled a crisis that we had. My wife's passport slipped out of her pocket in the car that took us from the airport. Because it was a private car we had no way to trace it. The staff at the ShangriLa, especially Mr. Mochizuki the Reception Supervisor and Ms. Ogiyama, on the hotel guest relations staff really went out of their way. Not only did they arrange to review the video of our arrival to get the details on the car, but Ms. Ogiyama accompanied us 20 minutes away to the police station to explain the situation. Outstanding service and attittude. Ultimately the driver actually drove over an hour out of his way to return the passport, but the ShangriLa staff went way out of their way as well. Will be hard to stay anywhere else in Tokyo in the future!

Shangri-La Tokyo is an excellent hotel and would have received five stars if it were not for certain service issues (but more on that below).To start off, as many reviewers pointed out, you cannot really beat the location of the hotel, a few hundred yards away from the Tokyo Station and within easy walking distance to both the Imperial Palace and Ginza shopping areas. The room (we stayed in the Deluxe King one) are spacious with a very nice apportioned bathroom and a big sitting area. The hotel's wi-fi connection is free, fast and reliable. The views from the windows are excellent throughout the hotel. The personnel (with a few notable exceptions at the reception) would go out of their way to assist.In terms of the negatives, we were a tad disappointment with the room service being 20 minutes late with our dinner order and the next morning, our room was not serviced until 2pm and even then, a maid only came after our call to the service centre. One should really not have to do this at a 5-star hotel. The other thing is that I was slightly underwhelmed with the breakfast spread. For the price of a breakfast, I would really expect there to be a greater choice. The inability of the kitchen to cook a very basic order of fried eggs sunny side up on two different occasions (the eggs came out overeasy) was also somewhat surprising.

Shangri-La Tokyo is becoming our favorite hotel. We have stayed at a number of other Tokyo hotels, Peninsula, Four Seasons, Mandarin Oriental, Grand Hyatt, Ritz Carlton to name a few. First off, you cannot beat this location. It is literally next door to Tokyo Station and it is still very quiet. The service and the food improved over our last stay last year. This stay they upgraded our suite to the Shangri-La suite which was absolutely fabulous! The suite was huge with its own kitchenette. Unheard of for prime Tokyo space. The rates are a real value here for what you get here. The executive level suites allow you to have a quick and free meal on that executive floor. The wifi is really great here- a big problem at most other hotels in Tokyo. It's the best by far.The room service was also really great this time, much better than last year.The staff are really nice and competent. My only downside would be the Shangri-La standard for lighting seems to be a dimmer is better mandate.

We came on a Friday evening to visit the bar at the Shangri-La in the 27th floor , which offers a fantastic view not only over Tokyo station but also over the entire skyline ! Absolutely worth the view and the drink menu is fresh and inspiring with great signature cocktails and food. A great way to spend the evening in a stylish yet very sophisticated environment.

This was the fourth time I/we have stayed at the hotel. Every single time the service levels are exceptional, the rooms immaculate and large and the cleanliness fabulous.The in house restaurants are first class..it's convenient to the train and Ginza shopping.I will be back every time I am in Tokyo.

Absolutely luxurious hotel, the bedroom was simply awesome, the rain shower in the wet room was incredible and also a great bath where you could luxuriate and either watch the television through the glass window in the bedroom or gaze at the night lights of Tokyo, also a magnificent curved sofa by the window. The maids do an incredible job of cleaning, you could eat off the floor if you so desired. The service in this hotel made you feel very special, have never had better. The location is second to none, everything on your doorstep. However two negatives, I did not care for breakfast buffet, do not like ordering cooked eggs, bacon etc., off menu, have had far superior buffets. Other negative was that a friend tried to order a "lemon, lime and bitters" drink in the bar opposite reception and they didn't know what it was so then tried a "Pimms" again no knowledge.

Reception staff (Momo) was extremely helpful with check-in, providing directions, and purchasing train tickets. I am pleased with the service of the staff (meet and greet service was great - they helped us navigate Tokyo Station during rush hours). Location of the hotel is excellent - close proximity to Yaesu north exit and Daimaru department store

This was my second visit to the Tokyo Shangri-la -- having a bit more free time this trip, i was able to enjoy a few of the hotel amenities, and wanted to update my review accordingly.The hotel and room itself were just as lovely as last time; clean, spacious rooms with tasteful, elegant decor.I wanted to add how impeccable the customer service is; always helpful and willing to accommodate, etc. As i was checking out, they were assisting another customer with airport transportation advice; the thoroughness and patience with which they handled the situation was really amazing -- it was clear they wanted to ensure the customer was 100% happy and no detail was missed.This time, I had the chance to enjoy both the lobby bar, as well as room service dining. The lobby bar is well appointed and was rather busy when i went (around 10pm), mostly full of business travelers such as myself. Having said that, the barkeep was more than attentive and there was no shortage of selection. (yes, he speaks fluent English)Room service was actually quite good -- I chose to order cooked Japanese food and each component of the meal was delicious and delicately prepared. I was a bit worried about regretting eating in (since there's so much good food in tokyo!), but the quality of the food more than answered that question.Similarly, the minibar was well stocked (see my FS @ Canary Wharf review for what NOT to do at a minibar in a 5-star hotel!) -- given the recent increased popularity of Japanese whiskies, i was delighted to see the hotel had ample selection.Overall, every aspect of the Shangri-la was enjoyable; i did try a different but comparable hotel on my previous stay, but needless to say, that was a mistake -- the Shangri-la is still the best place to stay in Tokyo's city center.
user_name:
jpg28242
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at shangri-la hotel in Tokyo for 12 nights with my 6 yr old, and the hotel is stunning, and the staff are so friendly and helpful. We arrived Monday 7th March about 12:30 pm and once we got there they took our luggage and took us up the lift, they then took us straight to our room and I got to check in inside the room which was really nice and got to have a shower before going back out as sitting on plane all those hours so it was nice to be able to freshen up. Also booked birthday cake for my daughter as it would be her birthday following week whilst we were there, they also gave her teddy which is cute. The room is lovely size and view was great, my girl loved watching the trains. Bath and shower I loved. And free WiFi in the room is really helpful and didn't need Internet during the day. The checking out was just as easy and a member of staff escorted and took our luggage to the platform for train to airport which is good as It would off taken me lot longer to find it, I did forget my prescription glasses at hotel and didn't realise until I was on the train, did get up at 5 in the morning so was half sleep lol and sent email and the reply I got was brilliant and that they are sending me my glasses back which is good as it would cost me quite bit to get another pair. I can only praise the hotel and the staff and hope we get to come back one day as it made our holiday even more amazing especially being right next to tokyo station exit which is so convenient. And hotel is so child friendly, they even had kids size slippers for her and kids toothbrushes very thoughtful.

We stayed in Tokyo for spring break. Weather went from 60 deg to 37 deg during our stay but we had a wonderful time nevertheless. Not yet as crowded and some cherry blossoms already on display.I went back and forth booking our hotel - looking at several hotels, particularly the Peninsula. I was very glad that we finally decided on the Shangrila. We did check out the Pen lobby and although both locations have their pros and cons, I think that the Shangrila location is better all in all. I liked the Shangrila lobby better as well. Even before we arrived, the concierge was very helpful re: booking our dinner reservations and tours. The Meet and Greet option was brilliant. After a long flight from the US, being met by someone at the Tokyo train station was very helpful. Tokyo station is gigantic and it would have been difficult to navigate it that first night.We booked a Club Horizon room and was given a room in the 37th floor with views of the Imperial Garden. As mentioned by others, the Club room option is really worth the money. We opted to eat breakfast at the restaurant downstairs (Piacere) - more variety. You can choose one hot item off the menu and then avail of the breakfast buffet. I chose the Japanese meal every day and it was delicious. But you can eat breakfast at the Club as well. They provided drinks and light snacks throughout the day which was really worth the money. Then they provided cocktails at night. For the first two nights, my daughter fell asleep in the early evening so we had to cancel our dinner reservations. The food at the Club was sufficient that my husband and I did not really feel the need to order room service.There is a large department store next door (Daimaru) with food stalls and is connected to the Tokyo terminal. Would be easy to buy food and eat at your hotel - cheaper option. We did try the lobby lounge at the hotel for lunch once and the food was very good.The room is excellent - spacious with a very big bathroom. As mentioned by others, the thing that sets Shangrila apart is the service. Their staff are so well trained and engaging that you really feel taken care of. They will really try and do anything for you. All in all, this is an excellent hotel, wonderful service and perfect location. We will plan to stay here again when we return to Tokyo.

One of the finest places I've ever stayed. Positives:Great location next to Tokyo Station and Daimaru Department Store. TONS of restaurants and shopping nearbyBeautiful, modern, comfortable roomsFabulous bathrooms with tub and rain showersAbsolutely SUPERB housekeeping staff. SUPERB!Great food and room serviceWonderful and helpful staff at every turnNegatives:Well, it's fairly expensive. It's worth it though.Really, you would be hard pressed to ever do better, anywhere.

Staff were exceptional, we required assistance booking trips from Tokyo to Kyoto and on to Naoshima.The concierge assisted us with making the proper selection and also booked our train tickets in advance of our stay. We were escorted to the platform by lovely staff member who waited for us to board the train to ensure we were safely on our way to Kyoto. The gym and pool are beautiful and all amenities well maintained. Breakfast each morning was outstanding, our bedroom was beautiful and immaculately turned over each morning and evening. We enjoyed our stay at the Shangri La Tokyo

Incredible service. Beautiful rooms. Quick internet. Concierge floor was a great choice (horizon floor). It was our first time in Tokyo and the staff made everything so easy and wonderful, during our 3 night stay. We decided to take a bullet train to Kyoto. The hotel sent a staff member (for free) with us to the train station (less than 5 minute walk) & the staff member led us to the ticket booth, translated for us so we were sure to get the correct train tickets & finally walked us to the train platform. I've been fortunate to travel to many beautiful places & stay at many luxury hotels, but the Tokyo Shangri La Hotel is now my new favorite.

This brand squarely knows its clientele's expectation, luxury and elegance! The Shangri-la Tokyo didn't disappoint, from 1st class service at the Front desk (thank you Mayumi Sakaki) to dining confirmations/recommendations from the Concierge (thank you to Takayuki Yoshioka and Miki Saito), every detail of our stay was carried out with extreme politeness and genuine friendliness. The experience at the Shangri-la will spoil you with luxury amenities, a beautiful Spa and a hotel room suited for royalty.The lasting impression of this hotel is how the culture of Japanese hospitality has far exceeded the US by bringing a balance of warmth and professionalism with richly, designed accommodations and aesthetics. Congratulations Shangri-La Hotel, Tokyo! We hope to visit you again in the future.

The hotel is very well located, close to Tokyo station and a 10 minutes walk from the imperial palace. The rooms are large, well equipped and very pleasant (but do not expect any original design). The beds are very comfortable. The rooms have a very beautiful view over the city. There is a free wifi. The breakfast is very good (but a bit pricy). The restaurant is also good, but very overpriced (with menus at 18000 yens). The staff is extremely professional: from the doorman to the maid, everyone offers a top class service. All in all, an excellent address for a business trip in Tokyo.

Gorgeous hotel in a great part of town ( near the main train station ) the rooms are very spacious with a sexy see through shower. The paintings in the hotel are beautiful and the smell - it's their signature scent smells so good. The breakfast buffet has great American food and traditional Japanese. Had the freshest sushi at Nadaman. Impeccable service. Highly recommend.

Stayed 7 nights in a deluxe king bed room. I have stayed at the Palace and Conrad. This hotel exceeds both of them, but of course you are paying a bit more for the experience. The location is perfect, next to Tokyo station. The Palace is also very close, but I find the underground walkway a little confusing. The staff is extremely polite and friendly. As you go up the elevator, the ground floor staff bow to you. The combination ala carte/buffet breakfast is extremely high quality. I ordered the eggs benedict royale, it was topped with caviar, a first for me. The buffet is rather small if you compare it to the Shangrila in other Asian countries ,like Bangkok. The only thing I found rather odd was the morning newspaper, left by the elevator. Most hotels I stayed at would leave a newspaper hanging on your doorknob.I would love to return here. The price is certainly a big factor.

Stayed for 4 nights, 2 of us plus our 11 year old. The room was very nice with a huge bathroom and like everywhere else we visited in Japan, very clean.The breakfast was fantastic, the waiting staff was professional and friendly and the breakfast room itself was lovely. The pool itself was good but these experiences are always affected by how discourteous your fellow guests are at the pool, no reflection on the hotel which couldn't really do much about badly behaved teenagers. We used the Concierge service often to book a personal tour, Shinkansen tickets and transfer luggage, and they were very good. We ate at the restaurant which was nice but overpriced - you can get excellent quality food in Japan pretty much anywhere (even at railway stations!) for much less but we were tired after our flight and wanted to stay in. We also stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo (which has a better location and street presence) but the breakfast and staff here were better.I would stay again.

Outstanding! Wonderful! Fabulous! Great location and amazing staff. Rooms with views and service that exceeds. Easy access to Tokyo and conveniently located. Staff were friendly and catered to questions and need for help.

Convenient location right next to Tokyo station. If you like to run, the loop around the palace and Budokan are nearby, have great views and few stops/starts. The service is great Japanese service at Shangrila standards. The restaurant is amazing--best breakfast buffet I can remember-everything is well chosen and well prepared. My husband is a pastry connoisseur and ranks Shangrila Tokyo #1. The flowers throughout are beautiful, and I always walk around the public spaces to see all of the arrangements and am delighted to see something new or creative but always beautiful. And then the room is unique. When we stayed at the Oberois in India, after the first one that we loved, the others were all pretty similar, regardless of where we were. This Shangrila is unlike the others we have stayed in and has its own unique and beautiful design.

We stayed recently on a quick trip before catching the train to Nagano. We arrived early and as our room was not available, we were offered an upgraded corner room that was available, for a little more. It was a reasonable price increase so we took it and checked it at 6 in the morning after an overnight flight.The room was superb, with views in both directions. Massive bathroom, separate sinks and a shower wet room. Awesome shower power and plenty of luxurious marble.Pleasant restaurant, small but quality gym and an indoor pool. Both were pretty empty during our visits. Excellent service overall. Location good at Tokyo central station, plus easy access to restaurants and the Ginza. Would stay here again definitely.

We were very excited to stay in this hotel because it was our wedding anniversary and it was our first time to experience Shangri-la Hotel Tokyo. We went there around 11am to check-in but the guy(forgot to get his name) front desk officer told us that check-in time is 3pm and there is no available room yet. So we told him that if we would to store our luggage and we will just come back after having our lunch. Then Mr. Front desk told us that there's ONE ROOM AVAILABLE 10sq.m. bigger than what we booked but there's an additional fee of ¥10,000. We told him thank you but ¥10,000 is to much we will be back at 3pm. And again Mr.Front desk officer told us that there's ONE ROOM AVAILABLE same of the room we booked but its a corner room so the view is much more nice but we have to add ¥5,000. We told him that no thank you, we are not planning to upgrade our room . And the next thing is Mr.Front desk told us that "Oh! your room is just now available" will a little acting. He told us that we can now check-in in our room.Very disappointing, we spend around 20-30 min to Mr.Front desk's offer to upgrade the room. And when he noticed we have no plan of upgrading, that's the time he gave the room to us. This is the what we encounter from Shangri-la Hotel makati, shangri-la edsa and shangri-la mactan, They want you to upgrade your room to get the additional fee, same tactics with Sofitel hotel. This is no 5 star hotel, what a poor service. My wife got emotional and upset her tears kept falling, this like an fraud "詐欺".Mr.Front desk was trying to fool us to upgrade our room because there's a no room available but there is a lot available. Mr. Front desk noticed my wife was in tears and told him what we felt about checking-in and specially it was our anniversary. He immediately apologize and sent 2pcs bananas and 3 oranges for the incident and for our anniversary.Well, what I can say is:1. a platter of fruits is complementary in a 5 star hotel not for a special occasion or for apologizing.2. Most 5 star hotel offers a free upgrade not. And if there's fee a 5 star hotel will not pestering you to upgrade.3. If you need/want a newspaper you have to get it with yourself here in the elevator. It's a D.I.Y. Do It Yourself 4.The big difference between a 3,4 and 5 star Hotel is SERVICE. But people still try to stay in a 5 star hotel even its expensive just to experience the best service.5. I didn't expect this will happen in Tokyo Shangri-la specially that Japanese service is the best....................what a shame 6. Overall, nothing special in this Hotel.

I have been coming to Tokyo for years and know the Japanese options as well as the Western ones like the very: Four Seasons, Park Hyatt, Conrad, etc. First, this place is ideally located as it is close to the palace and closer still to Tokyo station. If you land at Narita (and God help you), the hotel is right next to the station. It is also about 30mins from Haneda airport which is far better. Second, it is one of the newer comers to town and it shows in every positive way. Amazing rooms and great views. Local friends cautioned that the high floors will experience more volatility in a tremor than other hotels but I am not sure any one building is better than another in that regard. Finally the service goes beyond the already high local standards. Example: my Rimowa suitcase was damaged as I arrived. Ms Shiori Kubota, General Manager, personally saw to it that a new suitcase was purchased and all my affairs repackaged by the time I returned to collect my bags in the afternoon before departing. I shall forever remember and appreciate her exceptional service. And I shall forever make a point of returning to this hotel each time I visit Tokyo!

This will be My first choice in Tokyo! What do I love about this hotel? Let me see ... Everything works! And the hotel spells luxury.The room is large and luxurious! The bathroom is huge with separate WC, vanity area and bath area - the tub and shower areas are separate, imagine the space! Lovely lovely lovely! In addition, Shangri-la provides l'occitane bath products which I love!We had 2 double beds in the room which were extremely comfortable. Turn-down service was much appreciated. There was a Nespresso machine in the room; perfect! With a good selection of teas as well.Room service was prompt and efficient. Check in and check out was a breeze! The reception staff were helpful and very polite. I must commend Yumi Tsujimura-san for her flexibility and helpfulness during my stay.Shangri-la starts from the 28th floor of the Marunouchi Trust Tower so we get great views from the rooms. The hotel is next to Tokyo Station so it's really central and very convenient. There are lots of food, supermarkets n eateries nearby.I will definitely return to Shangri-la the next time I visit Tokyo.

I stayed two nights here during my most recent business trip to Tokyo. First of all, its proximity to Tokyo station makes it so accessible for business travelers. Few things that really make this hotel stand out :impeccable Japanese service ,luxurious and spacious room, easy access , great food , the list just goes on..I will definitely come back again for both business and leisure!

I chose the Shangri-La Tokyo for our family visit due to its proximity to the Tokyo station and the fact that the rooms were bigger than the Four Seasons. On the website, the hotel stated that they could accommodate two children in the room by stating this request on the booking form. Shortly after I received an email stating that their policy on this had changed but that they would accommodate me on this occassion. A subsequent email requested an extra charge for my 12 year old son. I was very surprised on arrival to be told that I could have the two boys in the room but there could only be one extra bed. I requested an upgrade to a larger room to have two beds, or failing that I requested our booking be changed to adjoining rooms (for which I was willing to pay extra) but was told briefly that this wasn't possible. Basically, it all seemed to be my problem.Fortunately the room was rather large and had an extra couch, so my son slept there which was satisfactory but disappointing.Apart from this, I would recommend this hotel for its location, amenities and services (apart from the reservation misunderstanding). The position next to Tokyo station was brilliant, partly for access to sights by tokyo rail but also because everything was available at Tokyo station from specialist ramen to toys to starbucks. The 'meet and greet' service was a boon, as it would have been a bewildering trip through the station from the Narita Express when we first arrived.I can't comment on the restaurants as they have a children over 6 only policy so we couldn't go. The breakfast was a bit over the top even for a buffet but just next door at the Tekko building there was an excellent newly opened Sarabeth's.The room was lovely, with nice views over Tokyo. The bathroom was large, with a stand alone bath and an open shower which actually worked quite well. My husband loved the toilet which was a luxury model with all the bidet functions including something called a "power deodoriser" which I didn't try.

There is no other way to describe our stay than magnificent! The hotel is centrally located at Tokyo station. It is in the upper levels of the tower and so on arrival you are greeted by the concierge at either the basement (where there is the most spectacular entrance for a basement) or ground level. We arrived in by train so our bags were immediately taken by the concierge. As soon as she noted we were in a Horizon Club room we were immediately guided to the separate check-in up stairs. It was late when we got in and we were immediately seated in the lounge where we could enjoy the canapés and cocktails while they checked us in. The staff were simply outstanding at all times and there was a bottle of champagne waiting for us in our room. On check out, my wife had fallen in love with the Shangri-La bear and when we went to purchase one, it was gifted to us. Such a nice touch.The food was outstanding, the Egg Royale was out of this world as were the pancakes. The room was spectacular, the view over the city at night and during the day is mesmerising. The pool area is lovely and has some great views of the royal Palace grounds. The rain head shower in the bathroom was something you longed for after a day of city exploring and with its location at central station, it is an ideal base to explore this amazing city. The palace is also within walking distance and the fish market is a short taxi ride away (make sure and leave the hotel by 4:30am for this). Prior to arriving, the hotel's assistance in making restaurant reservations during the busy golden week was a pleasure.Simply put, one of, if not the best hotel experiences I've ever had.

Hotel - The hotel ticks many important boxes. It feels good to be there. The design is modern and clean lines. It is good for holiday, family, couples and business. The rooms are comfortable and specious. All works all good. The breakfast is very good. The bar is great try one of the 3 signature cocktails. Great view from the bar window. Location is excellent. Central plus next door to tokyo station. This is really helpful and of course saves time in a busy trip. Above all, the service is exceptionally top notch - even for 5 star hotels in Japan and elsewhere. There was a common strong quality in the service which is hard to put the finger on. Everyone was consistently excellent, friendly (but not over the top), and efficient, and somehow projecting a genuine desire to be helpful. This makes a difference in terms of practical tips, advice and arrangements, and in terms of feeling good being there, and this also crystallises a decision to come back.

Impeccable shangrilla service, very nice and helpfull staff. Flawless as always.A great size room for tokyo standard.Next to tokyo station, alot of good food and easy access to trains. A few department store around the area, daimaru next door, takashimaya and mitsukoshi about 5 mins walk. 10 mins walk to ginza, a quietter area away from the buzz of ginza.Definitely one of the choice in tokyo.

The Shangri-La is located in Marunouchi, rather near the train station. However, the station area in Tokyo e is far from what can be found in Europe. It is safe, full of great restaurants, located near the famous Ginza district and all parts of the city are easily accessible since you can take a bunch of lines from the Tokyo Eki. The hotel is situated in a tower nearby, on the 28th floor (and on). The hotel is missing the standard grand entrance you would expect from such a hotel, the driveway, the huge doors, spacious lobby etc but again it is just Tokyo style as others luxury properties have it this way, too. Its style is classic and formal.The rooms have great views, especially the ones with the Tokyo Skytree view. They are spacious, refined and really really clean. The best part is the huge comfy bed, the tub with the room view and the amenities. Also, the housekeeping staff is very polite and the service center staff + waiters are very helpful and eager to provide a great service.I stayed there two times now and the thing I liked most every time was the breakfast from the Italian restaurant located near the lobby. I tried a lot of things like ricotta pancakes, the french toast, the eggs Benedict (classic ones), fruit, danish pastry .... and I cannot say what I liked more. If I had to choose I would definitely recommend going for the different variations of the poached eggs and the Chef's signature pancakes and trench toast.

From the greet and meet at the Narita Express on the platform when we arrived to taking us right to the door of the Shinkansen as we left, we could not of asked more of the Shangri-La Tokyo staff and experience. The room was perfect and the Teppanyaki was awesome. The hotel is so good we are going back in two weeks time.

This is my second time to stay in Shangri-la Hotel Tokyo and this time with the kids. Upon doing my reservation, I have requested for a complimentary bed for my child which was graciously given to me. Upon check in, i felt very welcome as they greeted me with a "welcome back" and all went in very smoothly, they even mentioned that I have a package that was delivered to them already inside the room.Upon entering the room, the bed was all set up and turned down since we arrived late in the evening, they even provided a teddy bear android size slippers for my children. A welcome treat is also there, a train bread with jelly beans and candies for the kids. The room as always is very spacious and clean, it was like back when i came in last March and it is how I remembered it but this time with the view of the Tokyo Sky Tree. All toiletries are available with a special kit for the kids as well. Breakfast was served at Piacere, it is a part sit down/part buffet type of breakfast. Order whatever in the menu as you like and get some cold cuts, fresh fruits and salad as well as freshly squeeze juices in the buffet table. I love the french toast as well as the eggs benedict. I love the location of Shangri-la as it is just adjacent the Tokyo Station, with loads of restaurants to choose from and a Daimaru Department store inside it. It is also centrally located with multiple train and subway lines which makes it easy to go around Tokyo but it take time to get use the directions since the station is huge.I love this hotel because it takes good care of you during your stay, and even had some surprises for my kids during our arrival. Checking out was no problem as well and we will surely look forward to come back here again in the future.

Our first trip to Tokyo and could not fault the Shangri-La hotel. Location in Tokyo is really important as it is so large and so many different things to see and with the hotel being located next to Tokyo train Station, this made it extremely central, a massive plus. The hotel itself is on top of an office building so starts at the 28th floor so there was not a bad view. The service was totally beyond anything we have ever experienced. Small example, we wanted to catch a train on our first day and a staff member escorted us to the station, helped us buy a ticket and took us to the actual platform - all with a smile! Exceptional. Also definitely recommend upgrading to the Horizon Club. Top floor of the hotel and great place for breakfast and a cocktail before dinner. Thank you so much Shangri-la Tokyo. We have stayed at many hotels around the world and this was one of the best. Made our trip first class. Cannot recommend this hotel highly enough. Just brilliant.

The hotel location is excellent in the center of Downtown Tokyo next to the Tokyo train station,offering fantastic travel options for getting around Tokyo. I arrived at Haneda Station which was a pleasant 30 minute taxi ride to the hotel. A phone book of restaurant options are located within walking distance to the hotel, the Daimaru Department store is located next to the hotel. Attractions like the Imperial Palace, Ginza shopping centre are within a 15min walk from the hotel.The hotel sits on the upper floors of a multi story office building offering fantastic views of downtown Tokyo. The rooms are large and extremely comfortable, large TV, nespresso machine, to die for king bed, large bathroom with rain head shower, L'Occitane toiletries are a nice bonus.The staff,and in particular the concierge offered excellent service and advice.Not a cheap hotel, but you know this when you book.For Tokyo and what the hotel offered I thought it was good value. I enjoyed my stay in Tokyo and loved this hotel. When I return I will certainly be staying the the Shangri-La Tokyo.

I had an amazing three days in this beautiful hotel. I highly recommend it. The staff are well spoken, well mannered, and extremely helpful. I'll be definitely coming back in the near future. Make sure to upgrade to a suite. The views of the city are just magnificent.

Service at the hotel is top notch. Reservation staff and concierge were extremely responsive. Special mention to the concierge, Hiroko, for the quick responses and helping me with reservations even at the last minute. The room was big with extremely good views. I was only able to confirm my train ticket an hour before arrival into Tokyo and the meet and greet team was on hand to meet us. The only minor point is that the room description stated that the room had a standalone forest rain shower which was not available in the room I had. Not a big deal if one doesn't mind standing in the tub to shower. The hotel is in an excellent location and easily walkable to Marunouchi and Ginza. Overall an excellent stay.

I have been on the road for a week in Japan. I deliberately chose to stay in Shangri-La Tokyo for 4 days to rest and recover as I have been amazed by the Shangri-La experience in Asia. When I arrived by my own car, the bell boy at basement 1 was very helpful in helping with our luggage and directing me to the carpark. In fact the bell boy went out of the arrival lobby to the carpark entrance directing to B2, just to make sure I do not missed it. Well done! The concierge on level 1 and basement 1 were always very warm, very Shangri-La. My check-in at the front desk was received warmly. Beyond that, the front desk appeared busy, indifferent, staff looking at their computer screens (even when there's no one checking in). Perhaps I am not in my suit, but again why should I? I was on vacation. And I was dressed in lesser quality in another Shangri-La hotels such as Philippines and Singapore. But I never felt anything like this before. Bigotry because I am of a particular race? I travelled extensively in Japan for the past 10 years. The only time I had such experience was with a Swiss competitor hotel in Osaka. I never use that chain since. Since all guests will bypass the front desk when the they leave or enter the hotel, this must be rectified. This is not the typical Shangri-La experience.Had 3 rooms on the 34th floor facing the Imperial palace which offered you glimpses of the castles. You do have unrestricted space of about 1 km before you hit the neighbouring office towers. You will have a good view of the JR station if you love trains.My room was perfect. Tip top conditions, luxurious feel, nicely placed sofa for you to enjoy the view. Absolutely clean. Wow. You will have enough amenities to overwhelm you. You have a box of electronic cables in a box to match any gadgets you have. And stable wifi. I could not find a fault with the room. The only one AFTER looking around for 4 days - my downlight at the basin lacked a lens cover. Can you imagine that?I travelled with 2 boys. They are a mess. The housekeeping ensured that they are not a problem. Always neat and tidy everyday. You do have the convenience of living beside a JR, ie the trains, shopping and restaurants. My wife made an interesting remark - it is all very upmarket. If you want a more down to earth feel, you may have to travel out perhaps. I would love to give this hotel a 5 star rating, for its excellent room and almost perfect Shangri-La experience. But the front desk needs work.

Located on the top floors of this 40 storey building the hotel holds it's secrets until you emerge from the silent and disarmingly fast lift service.From this vantage point, the city of Tokyo stretches out to distant horizons. At night, it is truly spectacular reminiscent of the futuristic city portrayed in Ridley Scotts iconic film 'Blade Runner'. I stayed in the deluxe imperial garden room suite. Luxuriously presented throughout, this spacious room is well equipped and furnished for all your needs. I had a comfortable and solid nights sleep in a superb extra large king size bed. Automated blinds isolate the glazed walk in shower and bathroom area whilst a fully automated toilet finishes off a quintessentially Japanese experience.Service and cleanliness were beyond reproach. The dining experience was excellent. Breakfast was comprehensive. Everything was beautifully presented including my laundry. Simply outstanding.I will stay again.

Wow, what can i say about the Shangri-La Tokyo, other than we had a fantastic 5 nights stay. On arravil by train from Narita airport, we where met at the train platform(after a phonecall from the aiport with our arrival time and our carriage number) by a lovely lady whom guided us through the cazy/mad looking, first impression of Tokyo Station. At the arrival of the hotel, we where guided to our room for checkin, what was great after a 18 our flight! The room was spacious and had a great view on the railway tracks of Tokyo Station, which we liked. The staff of the hotel is great, and they recognize you when you return back after sightseeing Tokyo, they are all very helpfull! So thank you for feeling welcome!! There where two small problems we had during our stay, wich one was handled well, and one was disappointing. One day after a long day sightseeing we went for the pool, before you enter the pool you have to wear bathing hats( not sure if there another word for it) what is fine if that's the rule. After entering the pool there was one Asian man swimming who i think he thought it was his private pool, he made the most disgusting noises, and spit it out at the end of every swimming lane. We didn't wanted to be in that pool for any moment longer, and talked to the staff, they where on "our" side with on this matter, but that was it. It totaly ruined our day, and had hoped for some kind of response, but am sorry to say, there wasn't anything, not even on the next day we got to the pool. One day we have a private guided who showed us her side of Tokyo, and we invited her back to our hotel for a coffee in the lounge, the lounge was fully booked with guests outside the hotel for afternoon tea, so no room in house residents. They told us go to the restaurant( great place where we had great breakfasts each morning) when we got there, they told us also no, can't have any coffee here. That's when i got mad, it's strange that when you big money to stay here, you even can't have a drink with a guest. That' s when the manager came in, and told us that we could have a drink or two. He was very friendly and understanding, and at the end we didn't paid for the drinks, but that's wasn't what we wanted, just want to have a drink without the hassle. Next time we come to Tokyo/Japan, im a sure we will stay here again. The Shangri-La is located almost above the Tokyo Station, which is a city on its own. With a large department store called Daimaru, if you like food like us, you have to visit this store. You can also find great cheap restaurants withnin Tokyo station, and you won't a lot of western tourists, and ordering is sometimes a challenge, but that is one thing we like about exploring the world. Thank you Shangri-La Tokyo for making our first visit to Japan a memorable stay.

I chose Shangri-La because of its proximity to the Tokyo Station. It is very close. Tokyo Station is a maze so it was difficult to find the hotel at first. Look for the North Yaesu Exit. Shang is very near amenities. The Imperial East Garden is just a 15 min walk away and from Tokyo station all other places are within reach. The room was spacious and luxurious. The staff is courteous and helpful. We enjoyed our stay.

We have stayed at most of the 5 diamond properties in Tokyo. Including the Ritz Carlton in Roppongi, the grand Hyatt in Roppongi, the Four Seasons Chiyoda, the Mandarin Oriental Marunouchi and our favorite the Pennisula Hotel in Ginza.The location of the Shangri La is the best hands down for us. Most of our business is in this area but it is super convenient because it is literally in a building next door to Tokyo Station. So you have incredibly easy access to transport as well a large shopping mall underground and lots of great and cheap places to eat. You can also walk conveniently to Nihimbashi. Added plus, for some reason there wasn't any noise factor here like you have at four seasons and mandarin oriental being so close to the train station.They also have their executive lounge here which is beautifully appointed and offers really nice high quality food. The staff throughout are very gracious and helpful. We stayed in a suite which was large for Tokyo and most cities. Really nice amenities throughout. Only downside, decor is a bit over the top for some and lots of dark wood and mustard colors. Also, they allow smoking in the suites which is going to bother you if you are sensitive.Room service was passable. Wifi super easy and good.Large workout room and spa.

I recently spent a week at this hotel and was once again very impressed by the quality of the experience. The staff is terrific. The rooms are clean, very comfortable and my only complaint about the bed is that it is so comfortable it's hard to get up on time. Alvin in the Piacere restaurant was consistently helpful and made great suggestions on wine and food. The lobby bar has a great selection of wine and spirits and is a very nice place to unwind at the end of the day. I was also able to visit the spa and gym and the service was terrific. The location is convenient, with easy walking distance to Ginza and next door access to subway and rail. Once again thank you Shangri-La for giving a little safe harbor during a long busy trip.

When traveling, I expect issues to occur, nothing is perfect, but it's the staff which makes the difference on how that issue is perceived. The family had a 1 day layover in Tokyo during our travels so spent 2 nights here in 2 adjoining rooms. I don't think we found issue with 1 thing. Everything was as good as it could have been.Setting up transportation to/from the hotel via the concierge was seamless, our arrival was swift. The lobby is small, so if crowded I can see this being a concern, but it was not an issue for us. We enjoyed our short stay there and plan to return.We took advantage of room service quite a bit for the late night arrive and jet lag hungers. The food was as good as room service can be and the service delivery it was excellent. The hotel staff was attentive, but sometimes we had some trouble with language, but any miscommunications was quickly resolve so I give the highest marks there. Everyone was extremely helpful. There was no issues which weren't resolved on the spot (not there were many). If you are in the area and looking for a 5 star hotel, the Shangri-la Tokyo should be on th short list.

They have invented a new level of service without being excessive or tacky. The rooms are large with a perfect layout. Lovely beds, discrete service and the location is perfect. Sure, it is expensive! Coffee is 15 USD and you can spend a fortune on a lot of things. But for a short stay in Tokyo I would without a doubt return! Already missing my complimentary pj's and Kimono

The Shangri-La Tokyo is adjacent to, but not connected to, Tokyo Station, which is at the financial/business center of Tokyo and adjacent to the Imperial Palace - and, of course, a hub for various train lines to all points across Tokyo and Japan. It is a simple trip via NEX train from Narita - apparently the hotel will send staff to meet you trackside if you request it in advance. The hotel is located at the top of an office building, but has a ground floor entrance staffed by a concierge who will show you up the elevator to the lobby. The views are beautiful but, depending on the room, landmarks such as Mt. Fuji might be obscured by other skyscrapers.The property is opulent, befitting a Shangri-La. Nespresso machine, Japanese teas, and bottled water were complimentary. The mini-bar was stocked with Hibiki 17-year and Yamazaki 12-year whiskeys for under Y1,500 ($15), which was a nice treat and cheaper than at a bar in the US. I dined in the Piacere restaurant, in the bar/tapas area, and had excellent ham and salami sliced from the leg jamon-style. I also tried the room service - BBQ ribs from the Western menu - but they were not memorable.The good-sized room had a soft bed as well as two each of hard/thin and thick/soft down pillows to mix and match as desired. There was a banquette-type couch by the window perfect for relaxing and taking in the view after a long day. The desk has an abundance of power outlets (including powered USB) and wifi is free throughout the property. Also provided is a very Japanese stationery kit which included not only paper and pencil, but three colors of highlighter, a metal pencil sharpener, and a rubber eraser. The closet space was more than adequate for my trip but less than other high-end hotels.The bathroom was appointed with L'Occitane bath products and a Toto Washlet toilet with numerous adjustable settings if you're in to being perfectly clean. My room had only a tub and not a separate shower, but it was fully handicapped-accessible. The fitness center had free weights (in kg not lbs, so use Google on your smartphone to convert), strength machines, treadmills, and an exercise bicycle, as well as a three-lane lap pool. Chilled bottled water, headphones, towels, and apples and bananas are provided. I was jet-lagged so was in the gym at about 5am each day, and the soundtrack of early-2000s hip-hop (e.g. DMX) really got me going and provoked an unexpected sense of nostalgia, haha. The locker room area is one of the best I've seen in a hotel - including not only a sauna and hot tub, but also a rainfall/steam shower that sends water cascading down from a shower head about 10 feet in the air - it felt like a luxurious, warm torrential downpour. The shower also had large pump-action bottles of body wash, shampoo, and conditioner, which is way better than tiny bottles with screw caps. Pros: location, amenities, fitness center, general opulenceNot-pros (not bad but not the best): room service, access to station and street (you'll get the hang of it after a couple of days but it can be confusing at first)

From the moment I arrived I felt very welcome and taken good care of.The view from my corner room left me speachless several times.Service and about everything else was perfect as well.The only flaw was that I wanted afternoon tea. Unfortunately I been told that there where no seats available. I asked for room service and again I heared the word 'No'.Shangri-la London in the shard was very happy to provide afternoon tea in the room.Why is this here not possible?

This hotel is absolutely gorgeous. There are beautiful chandeliers everywhere, and fabrics and colors which make the place luxurious. The rooms a little more muted but still very lush. The delicious breakfast buffet meticulously cut fruits, fresh vegetables, cooked to perfection omelette- so heavenly and perfect way to begin your day while gazing over Tokyo.If you have a chance to try to the spa services- don't miss out!
user_name:
JetChic11
New York City, New York

review_body: I recently visited the Shangri-La in Tokyo for business, and all I can say is WOW! Beautifully appointed modern property with a staff that is out of this world. Guest rooms are large, spotless and well equipted. Room service and housekeeping is quick and very efficient. My favorite was the Wonton soup, simply delicious!I highly recommend a visit to "Chi", the spa at the hotel. One of the best spa experiences I've ever had. The treatments rooms are incredible with a gracious staff to match. A special thank you to Ms. Yamaguchi (reception), and Ms. Kakuta (my awesome therapist).I would also like to commend these members of the staff for their professionalism, attention to detail and gracious hospitality: Atsushi Shibata, Tomoko Mizukoshi, Kyoko Takano, & Yasushi Nagano. These staff members exemplify the BEST of the BEST, Arigato!I look forward to seeing everyone again on my next visit.
user_name:
Vinceonthemove
New York City, New York

review_body: It is our 10th stay and the hotel staff have made it a double perfect 10.The location right next to the Tokyo Station is a huge advantage to go around town. The Maurunochi area is an interesting area for art museum goers since the Mitsubishi Ichigokan Museum and several others are within walking distance from the hotel. Maruzen, a bookshop carrying the largest collection of English books is also nearby.Dining options in the neighbourhood are like sands on a beach. No one will fail to find a restaurant which suits their palate. Shangri-La's Nadaman is the best one of the chain I have gone to in Tokyo. The exquisitely prepared dishes make eating a pure blissful experience.

I have stayed here many times and it is a great hotel. Great restaurants, wonderful breakfast buffet, super staff, and superb rooms. The level of service and attention is very high. Everyone is special. The ice bucket is always full, there is always a chocolate by the bed, and everything else is exactly how it should be.

Corner room on 36th floor was one of the finest rooms we have ever enjoyed in a city hotel. The room and hotel are elegantly appointed with luxurious fittings, furniture and accessories. As others state, stunning views, fantastic location and elegant luxury all under one roof. It is the extras that are worth noting: hosiery provided along with Bulgari bathroom supplies, pajamas, slippers, yukata and robes provided, crystal glasses accompanied the champagne, cross-cut wood coffee table, amazing art in all public areas, personal escort to the train, Swarovski crystal handle bars in elevator and a standard of service above others. Our recent stay in the Shangri-La Shard wasn't in the same league. Sorry Shard Management.

The Shangri-La in Tokyo is simply in a league of its own. In a fantastic location near Tokyo Station, the hotel oozes elegant luxury. Staff are top notch - professional and courteous. The rooms are very big, comfortable and full of luxury. The breakfast is small but the food selection is superior to any other hotel i've been to (the granola + chia seeds + goji berries + dried banana = amazing combo!). The gym is also very nice.The only strange thing was that I didn't receive the traditional Shangri-La welcome tea when i arrived in my room. I asked about this at reception when checking out and staff seemed to suggest that this was not offered at the Shangri-La in Tokyo?Highly recommend this hotel.

I loved the convenient location; just a quick elevator ride to the Tokyo train station.The staff is amazingly friendly, efficient, respectful, polite, helpful... there are not enough superlatives. We were treated like royalty at every moment.The room was lovely - comfortable and efficient -- every think you could possibly think of was provided. The views were incredible; even from the wet room -- where you can open the shade and see the views while being deluged with water... great water pressure, by the way. And, the toilet is even welcoming.We ate dinner in the room one night and breakfast in the restaurant which provided a whole other view. The food was lovely, not "American" size portions, but breakfast is also a buffet -- so there is a lot to choose from. This is not a budget travel option - but when you need a luxurious space to relax and rest your head, you can not go wrong. Chandeliers are everywhere; the hotel sparkles!

Stayed 5 nights at this hotel. I chose this hotel because it is located next to my office. It is also conveniently located at Tokyo Station. So it is extremely convenient if you need to travel out of Tokyo on the Shinkansen. Lots of eating places and shopping located at Tokyo Station.The service here is excellent. Always treated with a smile whenever I encounter a service staff. And most importantly, they all speak good English which makes communication a breeze. This is so rare in Japan.My room was a corner room on level 33. It is beautiful and has a large window facing opp the bed and gives a few as far as Tokyo Sky Tree. There is also a large window next to the bath tub which allows one to soak in the tub and admire the city view at the same time. The bathroom is huge, especially the shower area. The room is equipped with a nespresso machine too. My king size bed was especially comfortable. I slept well from the first night.Breakfast is at the Italian restaurant. You choose a main from the menu and the rest is buffet. Selection is not large, but I like the idea of a make yo order breakfast. They have a good selection of poach eggs made different style and pancakes to choose from the menu.We had a dinner at their Japanese restaurant, Nadaman which was excellent too. I will write a separat review for that.If I have a chance, I'll definitely stay here again.

I stayed for three nights in November. First of all, every staff member whom I encountered (and there were many) were unfailingly pleasant and polite.The room was massive with every amenity you would want and the view was extraordinary - no need to fork out for the Tokyo Sky Tree if you are staying here!The service in the bar was efficient and unobtrusive.The first problem I encountered was at check-in where I was told that there were no rooms available matching the type that I requested when I booked online many months ago. This is not satisfactory, for when you pay an awful lot of (your own) money for a room you expect to get that type of room - or at least be informed when you book online that there are none.The second annoyance was with breakfast. The charging is poorly explained, for the breakfast menu in the restaurant differs from the in-room dining one. A continental breakfast in your room costs 2,600 yen, but the same breakfast in the restaurant with the addition of an egg dish, costs 4,400 yen. I got the shock of my life when I got the bill. This situation needs to be better laid-out, both in the room directory and outside the restaurant.The location of the hotel is exceptionally convenient right on top of Tokyo Station. If you plan on doing a lot of walking, bring extra thick socks and well-worn-in shoes.I would stay here again, but only after I phoned the hotel beforehand to make sure that the room I booked and paid for was the one I will actually get.

The lighting was a nightmare, they also have those really dated systems where you have to put your room card in for electricity.I'd paid for a suite, which wasn't the best layout.The TV system in the bedroom was terrible, in the living room reasonable.The toiletries provided were excellent, possibly the best of hotels I've ever used.The in house Japanese restaurant is excellent as is the bar in the lobby.We used the hotel car multiple times and the driver was again, one of the best I've ever had.Checking out was a nightmare. More paper and refunds then additional charges on my card instead of just one charge.... I'm lucky my bank didn't block it thinking it was fraud!Furniture was dated and the air con poor. But the wifi was free and a reasonable speed (enough to stream video without buffering)Would stay here again if in Tokyo.

This hotel was fantastic from the moment we arrived. Check in was efficient and we were shown to our room quickly. We had our luggage sent on from Kyoto (look into this while in Japan this service is pretty standard) and it was waiting for us in our room. Our room was fantastic and large, bed comfortable with wonderful bedding and beautiful bathroom. The amenities were perfect we wanted for nothing. Nespresso machine, hairdryer but not powerful enough (are they ever), water pressure fantastic and a lovely deep bath.Breakfast was a treat - best I have had in a hotel perhaps ever. Also was available till 11:00 every day. Don't look further.

Very Nice Hotel & Located next door to Tokyo Station. A cut above the rest. Truly first class and I recommend everyone to stay here when visiting Tokyo Lobby bar is a great place to socialize and meet new friends and the hotel restaurants are fabulous.

Excellent hotel located close to Tokyo station. Very helpful and extremely polite staff. The restaurants were a little pricey but the overall experience was first class. The location meant that it was easy to take the bullet train to Kyoto.

This is one of my favorite and plush hotels, when i can afford it, which is rarely. Everything is immaculate with large rooms, a massive bed, all mod cons and appointments and super service. Its tough to fault it, though it rates a 4.5/5 on the fluffy towel index - they could be a bit bigger, but then again I am not a small man. The location, whilst a pain to find, is super, with walking access to 100s of restaurants, bars and the Imperial Palace. I will be back - when my CC can cope.In this case - you get what you pay for - excellence.

Truly a five star plus experience..in this case the cost of a five star is worth it. The hotel does all of the little things right..I have been to hotels all over the world ...and this ranks as one of the best experiences.. They do all of the little things right.. Highly recommended if you want a high end hotel experience..from the airport pickup to the drop at the bullet train platform.. They exceeded expectations..the food was top notch , concierge was knowledgeable, and staff friendly

I stayed at the Shangri-La for three nights during my recent trip to Japan. The service was excellent and the staff extremely well-trained and helpful. The concierge stayed an hour extra after his night shift was over just to help me plan my last day in Tokyo. The morning concierge also spent almost an hour helping me plan my day sightseeing in Tokyo and walked me to the train in Tokyo station so I could catch my train to Kyoto on time. On my last day in Tokyo, A staff member helped me with my luggage and walked me directly to the train through the very confusing Tokyo station. I would have definitely missed my train if not for her assistance. The dining experience was exceptional with the staff making special accommodations for my dietary restrictions. I highly recommend this hotel for anyone who wants to be treated well and experience exceptional Japanese hospitality in a luxury setting.

Extraordinarily convenient location, very central and just next to the train station, with typical to Shangri-La perfect service and very well designed, spacious rooms with large walk-in showers and very big bathtub. Fitness center is rather small but well equipped and the swimming pool long enough to be able to enjoy few laps. All in, excellent hotel, whatever for business or touristic stay.

Top notch hotel down town Tokyo next to Tokyo station. Fantastically well trained and friendly staff (I love this "welcome back" stuff that the hotel staff in Japan say to everyone). Very large room with a fantastic shower room. And what we love: 4 towels. Good view and very comfortable bed.The best executive floor level lounge I have ever been to. Serving champagne at sunset and very cosy. Great job guys!

I had a lovely stay at this hotel and enjoyed it very much. Excellent staff and I enjoyed returning back to the hotel after very busy days.The room was incredibly comfortable. Very nice bed and spacious. The Spa was amazing! Great massage and experience, there. Nice indoor pool, as well. Very nice staff at the Fitness Center.The disappointments were with the dining. I ordered a Continental Breakfast and lets just say it was not worthy of a 5 star hotel. We also had a client dinner at Piacere. Beautiful Restaurant. The quality of the food was very good but the portions were incredibly small. While I didnt go, the Sky Bar was very pretty.I would stay here again but would likely dine elsewhere.

Conveniently located at Tokyo Station with Daimaru Department Store and Tokyu Hands as next door neighbour, staying in Tokyo has never been better.We took the N'EX from Narita International Airport and was greeted by the hotel staff right on the arrival platform. He helped us with the luggages and guided us through the labyrinth of Tokyo Station to the hotel. And also assisted us back, upon request, on our departure date.We were impressed by all the dedicated hotel staffs and the Horizon Club cocktails and almost-fine-dining-canapes which make our stay at Shangri-La a Shangri-La one!

Having traveled fairly extensively, the Shangri-La is at the top of our list of wonderful hotels. The staff is amazing - seeing to your every need, the location is perfect - Tokyo Station is literally next door, the rooms incredibly well-appointed and ultra-modern. I found I had to cancel a night's stay the day before we arrived, and it was done without question or any sort of penalty (even though I had booked through a 3rd party service - by mistake). My only recommendation would be to have the bar/lounge area be non-smoking, like the rest of the hotel. Otherwise, there will be no other hotel for us the next time we find ourselves in Tokyo. Superb.

I've stayed in this hotel 4 times and each times and each time I stay here, I'm as impressed as the last time.The hotel is in a fantastic location, offers great views and has spacious and comfortable rooms.The service is impeccable. Staff can't do enough to help you and the house-keeping standards are phenomenally high.I've already gone into the details in another review.If you can afford to stay here, then I would recommend it highly. I would give it 6 stars if I could.

For us, the Shrangri-La is a huge part of why we love visiting Tokyo! From the beautilul spacious view rooms, to the great pool, to the all too patient and knowledgeable concierge Yoshi - this hotel is 5star perfection. We are tough critics and are always thoroughly pleased with our stay. The staff is helpful and friendly taking Japanese hospitality seriously.

This thank you note was long overdue since we were there in May-June 2015 for a 2 weeks stayed for holiday. Everyone was helpful from the bell boys to the receptionist and also folks from the club floor. The concierge was excellent in finding the best foods in town fit within your budget. For restaurants that required reservation way in advance - the concierge will book for us prior 1-2 months before we arrive into Tokyo. The Tokyo Train station beside the Hotel have a lot of nice restaurants and surprisingly good Ramee stalls at the basement and shops. Overall great location and we look forward to come back again.

We stayed here our first days of our trip and the last night before we headed home. A wonderful hotel in a great location with great and attentive service. You can walk most everywhere, but the best part of the location was the proximity to the central train station. The hotel has over the top comfort with its large room and bathroom. And hip bar for an evening drink. A delicious continental or Japanese breakfast served with a great view of the city. Be prepared to feel like royalty.

We stayed for 8 nights in a Deluxe King room with a rollaway bed for our 5 year-old son. We found the best rate was through booking directly with the hotel. The king size bed was huge and comfortable. The room was spacious even with the rollaway bed. Great bathroom. Good lighting. Spectacular views. Free wifi. Useful items that I’ve never seen in a hotel room before including a torch, and bathroom scales (which we used to weigh our luggage after shopping). Beautiful L’Occitane bath products.Excellent location right above Tokyo Station. If you are arriving by train, definitely pre-book the complementary meet and greet and then email the Shangri La from the train with details of your car number. Tokyo Station is huge and easy to get lost for the first time. The Shangri La is closest to the Yaesu North exit - walk past Starbucks, then out of the building and turn right at the Bellmart (convenience store) and you should be able to see it just opposite the Beer CaféAsk for a non-smoking room if that is important to you. Our room had no smoke smell.While we were right above Tokyo Station, we mostly used the Nihombashi Metro station for getting between the hotel and most places in Tokyo. Nihombashi Exit A3 is closest to the Shangri La (about 1 block away). Otemachi metro station is also very close.This is one of the few hotels in Tokyo that doesn’t have restrictions on when children can use the swimming pool or a minimum age. You must wear a swimming cap. The pool is open from 6:30am-10pm. Towels, water, fruit, and slippers are available – as well as a beautiful warm shower. The staff were excellent with our son. The adjacent gym is open 24 hours.Complimentary bottles of water are provided in your room on arrival, each day, and each night at turn down. If you need more water, you can ask at the pool or at the bell desk near the exit. They often offer a bottle of cold or room temperature water as you leave for the day.Room Service and food at the Lobby Lounge is exceptional and the prices of room service were not as expensive as I was expecting. The Chinese Fried Rice is delicious and the Ceasar Salad was also fantastic. There is a good children’s menu including vegies sticks, mini burgers, fries, fried rice with chicken skewers. All is tasty, arrives hot due to the clever under-table heated compartment, takes around 30 minutes from the time you order, and is beautifully presented.There are heaps of dining options close by. The 12th floor of Daimaru has several restaurants with English menus. There are also many restaurants in “Kitchen Street” within Tokyo Station but few had English menus. We enjoyed our meal at the Master’s Dream just near the Shangri La. Diamaru has a grocery store in the basement. There is Bellmart at the entrance to Tokyo Station, and a Seven Eleven on Yaesu Street. We asked to have the mini-bar removed from our fridge so that we could keep a few things such as yoghurt and fruit.We were on the 35th floor and had a view out to Disneyland and could watch the Disney fireworks at 8:30pm each night. A great way to end the day, even though the fireworks are a long way off. We also had an excellent view of SkyTree.Daimaru is a huge department store next door to the Shangri La. It also has Tokyu Hands. I had more fun shopping for souvenirs and children’s gifts in the lower floor of Tokyo Station. Look for ‘First Avenue’ signs, or go down the stairs next to Starbucks. You’ll find stores for Lego, Hello Kitty, Pokemon, Tomica Toy Cars, Tamagotchi and much more.The staff at the Shangri La are all friendly and happy to help guests in any way they can. It’s a beautiful place to stay.

From the moment we arrived the entire staff made us feel completely welcome. The club lounge was excellent and the club concierge truly made us feel at home. We are looking forward to returning in a few days.
user_name:
Johnny R
Richmond, British Columbia, Canada

review_body: When I arrived at the Shangri La I was unwell and needed a room ASAP. the lady that served us was brilliant, we had to upgrade our room so that I could rest, but that was fine with us and well worth the money. the staff were kind and attentive and can speak great english. I made myself better by sitting in the deep bath taking in the tokyo skyline in the corner suite! We dined at the Italian restaurant that night and the food was amazing. this was the perfect end to our Tokyo anniversary trip! thank you to all the staff that made our last night in Tokyo amazing, even if i was sick and a bit cranky!! Highly recommended!

This hotel is fabulous. Very quiet and luxurious. If you are looking for a respite from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, this hotel hits the spot. Not a place for action or exciting restaurants. You can find those all over the city.
user_name:
JimmyB726
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here only a single night but that was long enough to realize that this is a wonderful property, well-managed with a great staff. It is easy to speak English and get along here. They could not have been nicer to us. The Park Hyatt is perhaps the gold standard in Tokyo for Americans, but I think you can't go wrong staying here.

Japanese trains are undeniably efficient; however, arriving in Tokyo Station (and not speaking Japanese) can be a terribly confusing navigation of, what is, a rabbit-warren. It is during this moment you appreciate choosing to stay with Shangri La in Tokyo. We were greeted by the very charming Arissa at our carriage door after using the Narita Express following our flight from Hong Kong. She helped us escape the station, and her colleagues waited for us at the lobby to take us up for an 'in-room' check in. This meet-and-greet service is complimentary, and superb. Our room was great; with some great surprise additions. Just in case you travel without your trusty Kimono, Shangri La have some in the room waiting for you. This is in addition to the pyjamas and great L'Occitane toiletries. As a Jade Golden Circle member, we received cookies and chocolate milk, and a late check out. The lady who checked us in even provided us with some tourist information (as it is in my Golden Circle setting that I travel for leisure). The experience was personal and the staff obliging. We dined at various restaurants during our stay. Piacere, for breakfast, was outstanding. They serve breakfast in a great combination style between a buffet and an a la carte menu. The food was fresh, and the views over Tokyo are picturesque from the 28th floor. It is furnished to a very high standard and is a very enjoyable place to visit. I also ordered room service and visited the Lobby Lounge, both of which were just as excellent. Shangri La Tokyo is worth a visit if you happen to be in the Japanese capital.

This was our tokyo base at the beginning and at the end of our japan trip and it worked so well. We had looked extensively before choosing shangri la which turned out to be the least expensive of the luxury hotel in town. But there was no spared luxury inthe service and the location proved to be perfect right next to the Tokyo (train) station and next to Ginza. As many hotels in the city it occupies the last few floors of a skyscraper. The decor is minimal but warm and tasteful. Rooms are very large with wonderful views. Bathroom huge and full of amenities. The concierge service was spot on and ready to be in touch via email during our excursions. On our second stay at the end of the trip we were greeted by a tiny kimono clad bear with a sign "welcome back". We will definitely be back. Tip: they offer a complimentary track pick up/drop off service in connection with the arrival/departure of your train.

The staff and service here were outstanding.After the first night in the Horizon Lounge we never had to give our room number to gain access for Breakfast or complimentary evening drinks.We were always are\\dressed as Mr and Mrs Garnett.Whilst not cheap it is nice to receive such service.I will say the bed didn't agree with my back, but that just be me and my bask:-)

First class all around.Everything one would expect from an Asian 5 star hotel. Located very conveniently next to the Tokyo central train station the hotel is on the higher floors of a high rise office building.Featuring separate entrances it is an oasis in a fast moving city. The first thing that hits you in the pedestrian entrance is the distinctive fragarance of the Shangri-la. Very refreshing on a hot summer day. Whisked up to the 23rd floor lobby we proceeded to our room without delay with check in details handled there.We had a three day stay and the concierge was very helpful in arranging tours and dining spots. Another very attractive feature is the "meet and greet" service in the train station. There was a hotel representative waiting when we got off the Narita Express from the airport. This service was very appreciated as a first time visitor to the central station would be easily confused by the many levels and passageways in that structure.Food and beverage services were excellent especially the breakfast and cocktail lounge which features a spectacular view of the city.A very well organized house with unfailingly polite staff.
