The Tokyo Central train station is home to several luxury hotels. You really can't go wrong with any of them but Shangri-La was very memorable. The hotel is literally next door to the train station making it easy to walk there without the need for a taxi. The hotel is very clean and smells great. The staff were all very friendly and helpful during our entire stay. The room was comfortable and a good size. The bath products are luxury products. Overall one of my favorite hotels in Asia. The breakfast buffet was also fantastic. Highly recommended.

First, the staff were very helpful and friendly. I honestly believe they made our stay in Tokyo wonderful. Second, our room on the 31st floor was luxurious and had a stunning view over the city. Third, the restaurants provided great food and (again) great service.

I liked everything that the hotel offered. It is a quiet and classy hotel. The smell is so clean the moment you step in the hotel. The staff were all so helpful. A staff even accompanied us to show us the way to the train station. It is not easily accessible to non hotel guests which makes you feel safer.

No matter whether you are travelling for business or for leisure, the location of this hotel is perfect. Literally next to one of the busiest stations in Japan - Tokyo stn. The city view is beautiful.The staff are simply top notch from front to back (those in the breakfast lounge, in the lobby, at the front desk, in the restaurant... You name it.)The breakfast is a semi-buffet style one, where you can order the main one from the menu and the rest from the buffet. I stayed for 4 nights, and I had the same Japanese set for breakfast everyday! The room is spacious... Which is not always possible in central Tokyo. It's also well maintained. When I'm next back, I will happily give up trying any other hotels in the region for this one.

Thoroughly enjoyed our stay in the Shang in Tokyo. Luxurious. Centrally located right next to the Tokyo station where you would go to take the Shinkansen out of Tokyo. Highly recommended. The rooms are large with great views of the city. The technology in a Japanese bathroom is mind boggling!

Shangri-La Tokyo has been our favorite place to stay in Tokyo for a while now. It is convenience located right by Tokyo Station. If you come in through Narita Express or another train, you can notify the hotel with your itinerary in advance or en route and a hotel staff in red uniform will wait for you on the platform, assist you with luggages and escort you to the hotel.The minute you walk into the hotel, you will be greeted with the Shangri-La signature scent. The room is spacious and nicely apportioned with L'Occitane or BVLGARI toiletries, depending on room type but both are great. There is a nice indoor heated pool next to the spa and the gym. When traveling with our son, he gets special treats and an adorable teddy bear wearing the hotel bath robe. (We have a few of these cute little guys now but always a nice surprise to see one and I wonder at what age they will cut him off.)They serve delicious food in the restaurants and for room service. Nadaman serves great traditional Japanese food and in addition to the regulation seating, it has a teppanyaki room that can seat 6-8 people and sushi bar. Piacere serves great a breakfast buffet, afternoon tea, and Italian fare. We love the little origami crane accompanying the room service. Great attention to detail on everything. I love the hotel's proximity to Tokyo Station, which offers abundance of restaurants and shopping in itself. The hub of the great transportation system takes you to the whole city and the entire country. Did I mention whenever I stayed in the hotel on my birthday, I got complimentary yummy chocolate treats!?Tipping is not customary in Tokyo; in fact it can be down right embarrassing trying to tip someone, who would profusely bow and refuse the gratuity. But the attentiveness and the attention to details are most impressive.

Something incredible about Japan is the quality of food and service in the country, every where you go you will eat well and the service will be cordial.I like several things about this hotel:-It is across the street from Tokyo so it is very convenient.-The service in general is excellent.-Internet is the best I tried so far, it is easy to connect and extremely fast.-The gym is not so big but it doesn't get crowded.-They have a very nice pool also.

This was my first time staying at a Shangri-La property and it was nothing short of fabulous! We had two rooms, both facing the Palace and Tokyo Station. The King sized bed was possibly the biggest bed I've ever seen! Even the rollaway was super comfortable. The decor was very luxurious, from the silky sheets to the L'Occitane toiletries and rainfall shower head. The room was totally automated by remote which was a little confusing, but interesting nonetheless. Service was great, and we were especially impressed by the very deep bow given by hotel staff each time you get into the elevator in the lobby. Location is also perfect, 10 minute walk to Tokyo Station and right in the middle of Nihonbashi, with proximity to the Imperial Palace and Ginza.Despite everything, I had to deduct one star for food. We ordered room service the first night and it was very disappointing- tiny portions and very expensive. Breakfast the next morning was an improvement, but nothing special. I'd recommend walking to nearby Eggs and Things in Ginza.All in all, a stay I'd repeat!

Stayed here two years ago and loved it. The attention to service and details is impeccable! I think they even put us in the same room this time as we had two years ago. Great experience, comfortable rooms, great restaurant, and the perfect location to start or end a Japanese experience.

Deserving of the five stars. First class service from the moment you pull up. No worries if you do not speak Japanese. The full staff is fluent in English. Great fitness center and pool for quick workout if on business travel. 3 very good restaurant choices right in hotel. Highly recommend.

We have stayed at the Shangri la Sydney but it just doesn't compare to Tokyo. I cannot fault this hotel or its staff. Complete excellence from comfort of beds and rooms to the wonderful club lounge with stunning views and food to match. After a long day sightseeing there is nothing nicer than to arrive at the club lounge and be served some wonderful wines overlooking the wonderful city of Tokyo. If we are in Tokyo again we will be staying here. Arigato to all staff.

I've stayed at this hotel countless times and enjoyed every single one of them. The number of missteps can be counted on one hand and this from 7+ stays.I love that Shangri-la Tokyo is a full service hotel with a proper entrance, even though it shared office space and the lobby isn't on the ground floor. The kind door people welcome you and bow 90 degrees as your elevator closes. That is rare in the world (even in Japan and North Asia) and the first sign that Shangri-la puts you on a pedestal as a guest. They do this for everyone, not just the suited men or Birkin carrying women too.Staff take off their shoes when entering your room and stoop down when speaking to you. They're really the best when it comes to service. A special shoutout goes to the Horizon Club staff and the indefatigable, tireless Ms. Mizukoshi. She's a miracle worker.Plush. Everything there is so plush from Shang the mascot bear to the carpets and the bedding. It's a sign of true luxury and no expenses spared for one of their flagship properties. Breakfast at Piacere is consistently good. You have a choice between their Western short menu and the buffet spread, Japanese or Chinese set and the fresh spread. The Chinese dim sum set is probably one of the worst. Nutritionally devoid and not really tasty. This might come from the fact that they have no Chinese restaurant in-house unlike Mandarin Oriental across the freeway.Spa: One of the best in the city. No city outer views but a calming oasis in a city of bustle. I don't miss seeing the urban jungle when I spa at the CHI spa.This is always one of my Tokyo homes away from homes. I just need to find the time to get back there!

We stayed here twice, before and after a cruise. The service was always attentive and the hotel was beautiful. There was a small mix-up when we checked in and our room was changed. The staff were extremely apologetic and compensated us for the delay.

Stayed at this hotel twice, excellent location, friendly staff, clean luxury roomsEntrance is a bit hard to locateWhat mostly brought me back is their Halal menus for in-room dining, a rare thing to find in JapanGet the club lounge access, amazing views and outstanding service

Stayed here for a week with family in August everything here is perfect the rooms are great the food is great,ambience and decor are superb,you can't fault the superb esp the ones who serve breakfast this is a true five star property it's a shame there is not an outdoor pool but the indoor one is fine probably one of the best Shangri la s that I have been to!!

I recently arrive back from Tokyo and I have to say that the Shangri La is a superb hotel and the service is excellent. I began my stay in Tokyo at the Peninsula, but checked out as the service was below average and all the staff looked miserable. At the Shangri La, all the staff were welcoming and the concierge desk in particular were brilliant. They cannot do enough for you and always with a smile. My daughter has food allergies and they did their utmost to ensure that they catered for her. If you are looking for a top class hotel in Tokyo, look no further than the Shangri La. The rooms are wonderful and the location excellent. I thoroughly enjoyed my stay here. Thank you all at the Shangri La Tokyo!!!

My recent stay at the Shangri-la hotel in Tokyo was, by far, the most impressive and memorable hotel experience EVER. (And I've stayed in a lot of first class hotels around the world over the past few years). The service of the entire hotel staff, from the moment we arrived to our departure, was nothing short of exceptional and could have not been any better. The food and beverage director, Hanno Barkhoff, went far beyond the call of duty to ensure that we felt welcome and that all of our needs were taken care of. A big thanks also to Jens Moesker, GM of the Shangri-la Tokyo, for the hand written welcome card. In my opinion, this hotel demonstrates customer service excellence at the highest level and sets the benchmark for all other first class hotels around the world.

Notwithstanding its location right next door to the busy Tokyo Station, once you step into the Shangri-La, you enter a world of sophisticated luxury and exceptional, attentive service where every detail is taken care of. Located in floors 28 through 37 of a high rise building, the rooms provide an awesome view of the Tokyo skyline, and if you love watching trains you can enjoy the movement in and out of Tokyo station in the comfort of your luxury room. Everything about the Shangri-La Tokyo is exceptional. The executive suite provides a beautiful and large space, with great bathroom facilities, and work space where everything works perfectly, and every possible wire or plug is made available to connect. Every staff interaction, bar none, is handled in the most professional and friendly manner—from the restaurants to the meet and greet escort at the train station. Incidentally, the latter is a terrific amenity, especially if you are not too familiar with the station or city. A friendly face greets you at the train platform and escorts you through the maze of corridors and gates to the hotel lobby (and same on the way out). The Horizon Club (executive lounge) staff is also great—booking tickets, arranging reservations—all handled efficiently and professionally. I am generally partial to the Shangri-La hotels—when I find them in a given city, they deliver a consistent level of excellence. This particular location probably outdoes all of them. The traditional Japanese restaurant features the highest quality sushi and sashimi. Breakfast is served at the Italian restaurants, and features excellent variety for breakfast (the lobster eggs benedict is outstanding). The only disappointment was that this Shangri-La did not include a Cheng Palace Chinese restaurant (like the ones in Kowloon and Paris). Hopefully management will see the value in providing this treat to their guests craving top quality Chinese culinary preparations.

Located right next to the Tokyo Railway Station and the heart of its commercial centre, the hotel is as all other Shangri-la in the world, simply amazing. Rooms are spacious, staff are warm and professional, food is great. I am very happy with my 4-day stay there with one problem, the layout of the gym. The gym is small but has all the state of art equipment. Gym itself is not a problem, issue is with its layout. The reception for the swimming pool and the gym is within the gym. People pass the gym to get to the pool. Imagine half way in your workout, there are people wearing slippers and bathrobes passing by. It feels weird. Shangri-la will still be my first choice when I visit Tokyo. But seriously, if you have the budget, please do something with your gym/pool access point layout.

Stayed during June 4-6 on a business trip where my company is located nearby, so very convenient also a step away to Tokyo JR which can bring you everywhere in Tokyo. Room is quite spacious, front staff is helpful and warm, in room breakfast was good and served on time. I had a very enjoyable two nights stay here

There are many hotels to choose from in Tokyo, but you certainly can't go wrong with the Shangri-la Hotel Tokyo. It's centrally located at the Marunouchi Trust Tower in Chiyoda, which makes it easy to go anywhere within Tokyo. We've stayed there several times. The service is superb, by both Japanese and Shangri-la standards. Communicating in English is not an issue as it can be with some hotels in Tokyo, even American chains. We were traveling as a party of three (one teenage boy), and we reserved a suite, with a trundle bed set up in the living room. That arrangement worked very well. (For a family of four, you can get two connecting rooms or a suite with a connecting room.)Room service has both Asian and Western dishes and is promptly delivered. The breakfast buffet also contains both Western and Asian dishes and works well for people of varying preferences.The concierge is extremely helpful, both for making dinner reservations and for printing out directions in Japanese for the taxi drivers.The only caveat is that the entry to the hotel can be a little confusing to find, and some taxi drivers have difficulty finding it.All in all, we love staying at this hotel and highly recommend it for Tokyo visitors!
user_name:
mayliang
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Friendly Staffs, good service, clean room, good location. I hope in the future more better food and beverage quality than during our staying, especially the breakfast should be neutral , so every guest can eat the food alias HALAL.

Hotel location was grea,within walking distance(15-20 min ) to ginza,or have a very convenient underground connection.Very close tp garden of Palace. Staff were really excellent,has a good command of English.Last day we have to go another town by fast train,a staff from hotel escorted us till to our seats on the train.Breakfasts were so nice as well the Japanese restaurant

I stayed in the Shangri-La Hotel Tokyo for six nights, and having stayed at some of the best hotels in the world, felt that it was one of the best I have ever stayed in.I loved this hotel because: (1) Their location in Tokyo Station was very convenient for catching trains to other parts of this city, as well as this country. Also, the astounding number of shops and eateries within walking distance gave me so many shopping and dining options. Last but not least, the train from the airport runs right into this station; (2) Their complimentary "Meet and Greet" service, which greeted me when I got off the trains from the airport and another city, as well as escorted me to the trains to the airport and another city, eliminated the complication of navigating the maze-like Tokyo Station; (3) Their complimentary wifi service was really fast for a hotel, and I achieved download speeds of around 12Mbps; (5) Their concierge was very good at assisting me in organizing various aspects of my trip, especially reservations at hard-to-book Michelin-starred restaurants; (4) Their room was spacious and comfortable, with superb amenities all around; and (5) Their service all around was truly excellent.The only glitch I experienced was the HDMI port connecting the desk to the TV malfunctioned. And yes, the desk in the room had all sorts of TV and telecommunication ports.By the way, unless you enjoy the bird's eye view of the train station, which I did, I would advise against paying up for the view of the Imperial Palace, as the line of sight to this attraction is heavily obstructed by buildings in between. Note that this hotel is located from the 28th floor and upwards.

This is THE hotel to stay at in Tokyo. I've stayed at several different hotels in Tokyo (some 5-star) and this hotel is by far the best. It is exceptional in every area. Let me start with the hotel staff. They are welcoming, hard-working, knowledgeable, and helpful. They also go above and beyond to make sure your stay is perfect.The rooms are incredible and the baths are the best ever! I love the lemongrass bath salts and don't ever miss taking a bath when staying at the Shangri-la. The rooms are not just clean, they are beautifully decorated and have all of the amenities you could want. And, did I mention, the beds are super comfortable?Lastly, the hotel restaurant is very good - especially for breakfast.I refuse to stay anywhere else in Tokyo ever again. It's the Shangri-la or nothing!

Beautiful hotel and everything you would expect from the Shangri La groupImpeccable service and spacious luxurious roomsThe best views of Tokyo city, best seen at night with the bright lights shining into your room - making it quite a romantic setting for a city hotel!We had a club room so breakfast was served in the club lounge but we loved the atmosphere, ambiance and decor of the main dining room, which still situated on a high floor had brilliant views of the city.The concierge team were particularly helpful in helping to organise our travel plans for the rest of our time in Tokyo and our trip to Kyoto and even helping to book hotels for our trips in other cities to make sure we got good rates.Japanese are the greatest hosts and very elegant and welcoming in every aspect which is mirrored by the staff at the Shangri La TokyoShop are very close by too as is Tokyo station so its the perfect tourist location!

Stayed here for five nights, occupying an Executive Suite. Suite was spacious and very comfy. Nice king size bed, wonderful bathroom with a marvelous walk-in shower and a separate electric toilet.Hotel itself is beautiful, situated in an office building, from floor 27 to floor 37.Good breakfast at the Piacere restaurant, plenty of choices and wonderful, quick service. We actually had breakfast here only once, we afterwards had breakfast at the Horizon Lounge (as we are Golden Circle members ). Here the options for breakfast were plenty as well, buffet and a la carte. Mentioning the Horizon Lounge I need to say that for the Happy Hour (between 5.30 pm and 8.00 pm every day) the appetizers & amuse bouche choices were rather limited, compared to other Shangri-la Horizon Clubs. Also, sorry to say but the staff at the Horizon Lounge Tokyo, although extremely polite, lacked friendliness and warmth.Very prompt housekeeping and turndown service, all maids spoke English.Nice gym (although a bit small and got cramped in the morning hours). Nice swimming pool.I was extremely impressed with the spa, the therapist was extremely skilled, extremely polite, the spa atmosphere very nice, probably among the best spas I have ever been to.Fast and free wi-fi.The view from our room was a nice one, over the Tokyo skyline. Hotel is extremely well soundproofed and everything is of the best quality and finished to a very high standard and with an eye for details that is truly impressive.The hotel is situated in the heart of the business district, not far from some good shopping areas and less than 5 minutes walk from the Tokyo Train Station, where you can take the Narita Express Train or a Shinkansen line.On our departure the hotel gave us an escort to the train station, to show us the exact way to the Nozomi Line, as the Tokyo station is quite big and you could easily get lost.

They provided fresh fruits and desserts in the room upon arrival, which was really sweet. Also the location is excellent, being close to Tokyo Station therefore Shinkansen. Had a great time here! The internet was also pretty impressive!

The room was very good, comfortable and spacious with a wet room shower/bathroom. Staff were courteous and helpful. A slightly awry breakfast service was quickly rectified.This was one of the best hotels my wife and I have stayed in.

First impressions - plush and opulent. Probably typical of the Shangri-la design. Blink was everywhere - from the crystal chandeliers and crystal filled hand rails in the lift, to more chandeliers and gold in the lobby, it was everywhere! Love the rooms - they were not as big as Park Hyatt, but somehow more comfortable. Had the best sleep here. Love the location - it's walking distance to almost everything - the commercial district of Otemachi, the shopping district of Ginza, and the F&B options around the Yurakucho area, the highly accessible train network of Tokyo Station.Don't like the tiny gym/swimming pool. Otherwise this hotel is great on the whole!

The Hotel is conveniently located near Tokyo rail way station.The rooms are excellently appointed with all amenities needed for a pleasant stay.The staff are friendly respectful and efficient especially in Piacere restaurant

You can't really go wrong with Japan. Anywhere you stay will have a standard of comfort, class and quality that will run across all levels. From the capsule hotels to the extremely luxurious, you are more than guaranteed that your service and the quality of stay will be next to perfect.The Tokyo Shangri-La is no exception. After the 46 minute ride from Narita to Tokyo station, a mere 5 minute walk will bring you to your hotel. Now I don't normally take the luxury route in Tokyo, however this time, travelling with 6 other people, a modicum of comfort and space was required. With, plush beds, a large bathrooms with rain shower and bath, wide sweeping widows and all the amenities that you can think of, the Shangri-La has it all. Now, true to the nature of Japan, the rooms aren't huge, but they do make excellent use of the space, but that is a small sacrifice for what you get. With the great location and the excellent service. There is a small pool and even smaller Gym, but there is enough to kinda get your heart rate pumping but I am sure walking around the city will give you just as much exercise. But if you're in Japan, you're not there to sleep, you're there to go about the city and with Tokyo station being a hub for a number of Metro and Railway lines, you can get to anywhere in the City, plus the rest of Japan is within grasp as the Shinkansen (Bullet Train) stations are housed below you also.Shangri-La hotels are always known for their attention to detail and when you throw in Japanese hospitality into the mix, you are guaranteed you're in for a treat. The Shangri-La is on the high side in the pricing scale however, it's worth it. If you though are looking for something on the more reasonable side, The Yaesu Terminal Hotel is across the street. And it's excellent. (see below)http://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g1066444-d619181-Reviews-Yaesu_Terminal-Chuo_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.html

Great modern rooms, excellent views from rooms, location is perfect for getting around. Though could do something different with the restaurants as they did not entice me to dine there. Very friendly will go back if get the chance.

Just had 4 great nights with our baby, it couldn't have been better, for those travelling with babies/small children, this hotel goes above and beyond. We requested a baby bed when booking and then got a lot more; kids slippers, kids toothbrush, baby soap and lotion and diaper pail (emptied by housekeeping twice a day). Nothing was too much trouble.The hotel is in a great location, you can explore Tokyo station with the various shops and it's very easy to get up and down to the trains with a stroller. Breakfast is a classy buffet (not a massive overdone deep fried mess)with a choice of main dish which keeps you fill till mid afternoon. Staff are hugely accommodating and there are plenty around.We even had a fantastic dinner at Nadaman, their signature Japanese restaurant with baby in tow and by the time we arrived with the stroller, the ramp was in place so no awkward carrying down steps required.Would stay here again in a heartbeat.

we visited Tokyo a few month ago . the hotel located near Tokyo station and very convenient for travelling. the staff in the hotel are very friendly . great restaurants and breakfast . our room have a good view of the imperial palace garden.

Great hotel to be staying in the heart of the city as its very convenient to get around from since its by Tokyo Station which is superb. Staff are super helpful and the food is great too.I used the spa and have to say it was amazing. Managed to fall asleep while having a deep tissue so that's saying something!!

Just Wow! My husband and I went to Japan a few weeks ago, and despite only one place (Takayama - what a 'dead' loss place that was - we took a bullet train for 4 hours to get there - forget it, it's a dump - so nobody bother!). Thankfully, we changed our travel arrangements to stay at the Shangri-La in Tokyo for longer - what a good move that was!Two Bell Boys (actually one of them was a girl!) met us at the train platform when we alighted, and escorted us, whilst wheeling our suitcases, to the hotel. Before they took their leave, they introduced us to a 'very nice Concierge lady', who then escorted us to our room. Upon our arrival, the 'very nice Concierge lady' checked us in - in our room!!! - Most impressive!!! (Food for thought... why can't every 5 star hotel do this?)Ok, so once ensconced in our 'more than adequate' abode, one checks out the amenities/nice touches - of which they were an abundance! From the beautifully stocked mini bar and it's suade-ette lined drawers, housing each wine glass/highball glass/short glass etc. to the exceptionally well designed bathroom drawers - with every necessity one could ever need - Needless to say, they were both replenished twice a day - not the mention the clean bathrobes and kimonos, also twice a day. Amazing!Suffice to say, Shangri-La hotels, certainly know how to impress (Btw, the first one we stayed at was on our Honeymoon 24 years ago in Hong Kong and then Bangkok - and they knew what they were doing then!)Excellence

We visited Tokyo and other parts of Japan but this was our base. What a wonderful hotel and amazing staff! Rooms are excellent! We had a city view and it was all that we thought it would be. We could see straight to the coast. The staff was so wonderful, restaurants offered an array of dishes and the lounge was a great place to unwind after a long day. The hotel is located within walking distance to shopping and some great local restaurants. We like to experience places that the locals visit and the concierge recommend places that he would go to. Promise you won't be disappointed in choosing this hotel!

Great experience at this hotel. Staff were very attentive and welcoming, interacted well with my daughter and genuinely keen to help in anyway possible.The room had a good view of the Imperial Palace gardens - although slightly blocked by other buildings - and also of the Tokyo skyline.The hotel is very conveniently located at Tokyo Station but you have to pay close attention to the signage to find the right way out of the station to the hotel.

Overall an excellent property as demonstrated by the many reviews before this one. However, I'd argue that the hotel's location can be good or bad, depending on what you do and I'm writing from a tourist perspective. Shangri-La Tokyo's location is great if the train plays an essential part of your itinerary, (e.g. side trip to Kanazawa) as it's right next to the JR Tokyo Station. Yet, the location is definitely not as good as Peninsula's (quite bad if you ask me) if shopping and fine dining is on top of your as Shangri-La is at least a 20 minute walk from the Ginza Mitsukoshi/Wako intersection. Service overall is excellent and I can't find anything wrong with it. Yet, when compared to The Peninsula which I've stayed a number of times in previous trips, the service at Shangri-La feels a bit mechanical and cold. Concierge is pretty good, but I dare to suggest that The Peninsula's is better by being more human, more patient and more passionate towards figuring the guest's needs. Stayed for 5 nights in Horizon Club Deluxe Room during Mid-April 2015.

Best hotel to stay at. Great location. Great breakfast. Very friendly staff. Rooms are great and so are views. Early check in without problem. Paid for an upgrade, totally worth it. Wouldn't hesitate to stay again.

My husband and I stayed 1 week at Shangri La TokyoWe hesitated between Peninsula and Mandarin and I am glad we went to Shangri laAmazing support from the concierge Great restaurants & breakfastThe only thing that would have made me give a 4 1/2 if possible was that my non smoking room was smelling cold tobacco ... A wide spread problem in smoking japan

This is a review for a Horizon Club room/stay. We arrived in Tokyo early afternoon. After a 13 hour flight, and this being our first time in Tokyo, we had booked a hotel car to pick us up. I am so glad we did, it was the perfect start to our amazing trip.We arrived at hotel, was immediately checked into our room by a very friendly Horizon Club host - I am sorry, I would have loved to mention her name here, but I am afraid that I have forgot. During our 3 night stay, all staff at Horizon Club were nothing short of excellent - they did everything to ensure that we had a wonderful stay. Maps, train schedules, even a guide to the Shinkansen train station who walked us to the train when it was time for us to continue our Japan trip. The room was very, very nice - we had a corner room with plenty of space for us - two adults, one teen daughter. Big windows with great views to Sky Tree (and some construction, but that did not bother us). Lovely decor and bathroom with big shower/tub with equally great views. Lovely bath amenities from L'Occitaine and almost everything else you need - toothbrush, combs, razors - and we also loved that every night, hotel pyjamas was laid out on our beds. The room amenities were great, too - ironing board, tea/coffee, robes and slippers. We loved the pool area - especially candlelit at night with all the city lights. As mentioned we had access to the Horizon Club, which was wonderful. Delicious breakfast, afternoon tea, drinks and canapes. We were told that the breakfast selection was a bit larger at one of the restaurants, but we felt that we had plenty of choice at the Club and just went there every morning. It was a great place to go for a drink before heading out for dinner. And some nights, we even returned for a nightcab before going to bed. Comfy furniture and great views of Tokyo. And, as said, helpful staff.We were truly impressed with the Shangri-La and the level of service provided here and will not hesitate to come back. On our last leg of our Japan trip, we stayed at Peninsula (find my review in my profile), but Shangri-La is many levels above Peninsula in terms of rooms, pool area, dining options and staff. We actually tried to check out of Peninsula and book another stay at Shangri-La again for the last couple of days of our trip as it is so much better, but unfortunately they were sold out… no doubt that on future trips to Tokyo (of which we hope there will be many, as we have fallen in love with this wonderful city) we will book Shangri-La again.

Excellent over all experience- Great location- Outstanding facility- Great service- A bit pricy I was traveling for business, and that was my first time at the Shangri-La. My room was ready upon arrival and I had a great stay. You need to try the pool, great for laps, and awesome view.

I've stayed at several of the other 5 stars - Mandarin, Peninsula, Four Seasons - and find this one to be the best priced and most conveniently located of the group. The scale is more intimate than the others, and that's fine with me. I found the service to meet or exceed the levels, and the rooms are large, well-appointed and very quiet. At the Shangri-La you have complete control over the room's cooling system. Food and drinks in the hotel's restaurants and bar are quite good, and you can eat well prepared Japanese food (along with other cuisines) which is something that isn't really available at the other locations.This has become my go-to location for Tokyo.

After being met at the airport by easily recognized Shangri-La staff and whisked by driver in their luxury Audi to our below-ground private hotel entryway, where 3 staff members welcomed and took us directly to our 28th floor corner room where we were checked-in while being served tea.... Do you get the idea???The service at this hotel is magnificent. Our Horizon Club corner room was an incredible gift to two weary travelers after a long non-stop from Chicago. From the Bvlgari amenities to the incredible laundry service, their focus is on the indulgence of each quest. Our shower (which included a separate tub) was huge and besides the Bvlgari, had a rainfall-type option. It was wonderful. Then, there was the bed... It was the finest bed in which we have ever slept, anywhere, anytime. Period. It was an joy to stay there and we look forward to staying there again.

Excellent hotel and staff located conveneiently next to Tokyo station. Jason Yap the assistant housekeeping manager has kindly promised to mail to me some items I shopped for at Takashimaya (which is a 5 min walk away).....all free of charge. Impressed by their service!

This is really the place to stay if you intend to move around as we did using this place as our hub. The main train station is connected directly to. i suggest that you apply for a golden circle account so you can have added features like room upgrades. I got the new executive suite and it was really amazing and i think it will be my next choice when i visit Tokyo again.

The service is always excellent. The location is very convenient. The staff is very well trained and the experience is always consistent. On this visit there was a fairly large earthquake with the epicenter about 700 miles away. This was a first time to experience anything like this. The hotel team was calm and reassuring during and after.
user_name:
Global-EXEC-Travel
New York City, New York

review_body: The Shangri-La is located right on Tokyo station so, although in the business district very convenient to travel from. The rooms are large and very well appointed. This is a true 5 star+ hotel. It is great for business travel as well as tourism.  The restaurants in the hotel are world class, but also world class in terms of price. Both food and drink prices are very high. So plan to eat out if you dont have a large wallet. The only downside is it is a bit of a walk to restaurants and other shops - excluding Tokyo station which is huge.

Stayed here for a week in May of 2015. One of the best travel experiences I've ever had. The rooms are clean, immaculate in design with modern amenities, free fast wifi and terrific use of space, light and materials. Beds are very comfortable. Bathrooms are terrific. The staff is incredibly helpful without being overbearing. Laundry service, maid service, waitstaff all top notch. The lounge and restaurants are first rate with stunning views of the city. And finally, the location of the hotel is convenient for getting around metro Tokyo and Japan as it's half a block from the Tokyo Station rail station. All in all a terrific experience. Thank you Shangri-La Tokyo!!

As Shangri-La members, we choose to stay with the luxury hotel chain whenever possible. Our three day stay in Tokyo was a luxurious start to our Japanese travels.We were met at the bustling Tokyo Station by hotel porters who escorted us to the hotel... This is a must if you are arriving by train.Check in was efficient, yet cold. Seated in the Horizon Club, there was none of the usually "welcome back" chitchat we have come to love at Shangri-La Hong Kong and Singapore... We were simply handed our keys and shown to our room. A nice welcome touch was the birthday cake they bought to our room for my husband.The room itself was lovely... A plush corner suite with sweeping views over the train station and city. The bathroom is always a highlight at the Shangri-La.Sadly, we found the Horizon Club to be small and inadequate for such a large hotel. The drinks selection was very poor... Not even sake on offer. This is almost unheard of in Japan!But the biggest let down for us was the staff... No warmth shown whatsoever. Checkout was another cold transaction. Sadly, we won't be staying at our much loved Shangri-La next time we visit Tokyo.

Stayed here with the entire family for our summer vacation in Tokyo. Rooms were very spacious and amenities are complete. Location is perfect as well. Just across is the Tokyo Station. Will stay here again if in Tokyo.

The location near Tokyo Station was convenient though the entrance to the hotel is a little tricky. The service was exquisite and the room had every amenity with a superb view toward the Imperial Palace. Close to restaurants, shopping and an excellent art museum.

I flew Garuda GA-874 from Jakarta to Tokyo on Sunday May 17th. A great 6.5 hours midnight flight. Arrived in Haneda Airport in the morning. After imigration and luggage pick up. We took a taxi from the airport to Shangri La Hotel. It took just over half an hour though it was on Monday rush morning hour. The check in process was very efficient. I just mentioned and spell my surname in the reception located at 28th floor. The reception swiped my credit card and immediately after it I received my room key card. The room is situated almost at the side of the famous Tokyo railway central station. A great view to the station and City Central. The noise from the station is hardly heard from the room on 32rd floor. In Shangri La there are a number of top notch restaurants: western style, Japanese and oriental. For the breakfast, a variety of menu are available. Nadaman Japanese restaurant is a great choice for lunch or dinner.For a shopping, it is just in the next block. A big shopping mall called Daimaru Tokyo.Distances to The Imperial Palace or Shinjuku business district are reachable by private taxi, buses or by train.The location of Shangri La Hotel is so strategic. You can reach it from Haneda Airport and Narita Airport by using several modes of transportation: private taxi, limousine bus or express rail.

Hotel staff/Concierge: in preparation for our trip, we reached out to the concierge for a restaurant reservation. Service was very responsive and attentive, and they secured one of the toughest reservations in town! We also mentioned that we were celebrating an event during our visit; upon arrival, a chilled bottle of bubbly was waiting for us as part of the welcome amenities. Special touches and excellent service like this does wonders for brand loyalty!WiFi: free. easily accessed in the lobby and room, no password required The room: CLEAN, comfortable, plenty of mirrors. Very spacious - even with a desk and a wrap-around sofa, the king room still has plenty of space (could definitely fit a rollaway if needed). Slippers, yukatas and pjs provided. Also available in-room are an iron and ironing board. The lighting system was a bit complicated and took a few minutes to figure out, as some of the controls are near the desk.The bathroom: CLEAN! The rain forest shower was heavenly. Bath amenities are l'Occitane Jasmin & Bergamote - which happens to be my favorite l'Occitane scent, so I was very happy. After check-in, we showered, then made a quick stop to the shops in Tokyo station. We were out for maybe 1.5hrs and returned to the room to change for dinner. When we returned, we were pleasantly surprised to find that the bathroom had been cleaned and bath amenities/towels replenished! Highly recommend!!

Not having been to Tokyo for over 10 years, I just picked the hotel by its brand and location right at Tokyo Station. I was flying into Narita and then catching a Shinkansen to Osaka a few days later. A free Meet and Greet service was excellent. All we had to do was to send an e mail to the Hotel before the flight departure and a phone call from Narita advising them of my car number on Narita Express. We were met right at door of the train by a Bell staff. She helped with the luggage and guided us through a maze that is Tokyo Station. She was very polite and helpful but not over-the-top Japanese politeness which can be very annoying.Generously proportioned room was sumptuous and restful with glimpses of the Imperial Palace. It contained every conceivable amenities and conveniencese - I didn't have to ask for power adapters, for example, they were right there in the room, in case someone like me had forgotten to pack one. Breakfast, included in our room charge, was beautifully prepared and presented. It is a buffet style, but in addition, you can order specific dishes. Go for the Japanese option!I will certainly go back - but this time for holiday travel so that I can enjoy every bit of convenience, luxury and style the Hotel has to offer.

It was the Shangri-la instead of the Mandarin this time to try out my Diamond Status. The hotel has a great location for moving around Tokyo due to its proximity to the station. The rooms are large and well appointed as they are at Shangri-la properties. The public areas are a little tight. Staff is attentive and efficient. The Horizon club a great asset Overall an acceptable experience

The Shangri-La Tokyo is conveniently located next to Tokyo station, a great hub from which to travel to other tourist attractions around the city. The bad: it was like a maze getting from the N'EX platform up to the ground level and to the hotel. An escort service is available and I would definitely recommend it for first-timers. The good: their service is impeccable, absolutely first-class! It made a lasting impression on my whole family. If money were no object, I would strongly recommend this hotel to all would-be visitors.

Very nice Hotel, great service in an excellent location.Staff are very helpful and friendly..30 mins by monorail + JR train.Check in done in RoomPick up available if you come by trainLounge is a bit small but have a nice view of the Tokyo and selection of food is nicely done and many choice of drinks...Breakfast choice is great with a good selection....Tons of places to Shop and Eat in the surrounding.The imperial palace is nearby...Ginza is nearby...Great!

My stay at the Shangri La Tokyo was without complaint! The location right near Tokyo Station was extremely convenient. The service was strong. And the rooms were nice enough for vacation but serviceable enough for business (without being corporate). I spent another few nights at the Grand Hyatt and found it definitely overly corporate and lacking in character by comparison. Definitely recommend the Shangri La over the Grand Hyatt. I also considered staying at The Palace. Turns out that while I'm sure it's gorgeous inside, it isn't located in an area that's nearly as walkable as the Shangri La. I'm a city dweller and really value a pedestrian experience when I visit cities. So as nice as I'm sure The Palace is, I was glad I chose the Shangri La for its much more walkable location.Ginza is a few minutes away from the hotel as is Tokyo Station. The Muji flagshi, the major department stores, Sukiyabashi Jiro, and many other notable places are within a mile or so walking distance. You can also hop a train to Kyoto or nearly anywhere from Tokyo Station a few steps away. And of course there are smaller izakaya and 7/11s nearby for whatever you may need.The Shangri La rooms are plush and Japanese in decoration. Room color and linens are sumptuous and very inviting. There's a control panel near the bed for various lighting vignettes and for bringing the window shades up and down. Room service includes turndown service. Because the rooms are located in a tall office tower, all of the views are stunning.The wifi didn't work in our room, but the front desk quickly delivered a portable hot spot. We ended up charging it every day and toting it around Tokyo with us in addition to using it in the room. Free wifi while we walked the city? Sure, why not.I forget which room we booked, but the bathroom was beautiful. There was a large vanity and washroom in one area and then an attached standing shower and bathtub in the next. The bathtub was next to a floor to ceiling window which meant you could soak and daydream at the same time. I also noticed that the floor was heated in the standing shower. Nice touch.The fitness area is small but the attached pool is quite sizeable. It's mildly heated and equipped with kickboards, floaties, and refreshing glasses of lemon water. Swim caps are required but provided. You can also borrow goggles for swimming laps. There is enough room for a few people to swim laps and others to bob around happily.The hotel is set back from the road and a bit hard to find, but this means you feel more like you're staying in a nice condo versus a commercial establishment.The only other thing I would say is that the photos of the hotel's common spaces tend to exaggerate its size. The common spaces (primarily the lobby, hotel bar, restaurant) aren't as enormous as the photos seem. This is actually a good thing in that the place doesn't have the usual oversized lobby feel that major hotels have. (I remember staying at the Shangri La in Bangkok and feeling like it was a bit of a guest factory due to the size.) So the Shangri La Tokyo feels more intimate. You can get from the street to your room without going through any towering atriums or endless carpeted lobbies, just a few small elevator banks and nicely appointed seating areas (though it is still a walk!).I highly recommend staying a few days here if you're in need of convenience and respite in Tokyo. The Shangri La made our stay really enjoyable.
user_name:
erinpettigrew
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel, adjacent to the Tokyo central train station, starts on the 28th floor of a modern office building and goes up to the top, the 35th floor. The rooms are clean, confortable, and elegant, with excellent amenities, a big shower room with a bathtub included and a large window (with a lowerable blind) into the main room, a many-function Toto Washlet (you have to see and experience to believe!) in a separate room, and all kinds of automatic controls of the lights and the shades. Staying here is an experience in itself. The location is close to many restaurants, both in the train station basement and on the top floors of the department store over the train station, and in the buildings opposite the train station. The Imperial Palace grounds are close by, and the Ginza area is close enough to walk to. The service personnel can't do enough for you, and the concierge even walked us into the train station to show us where the ATM was.

Shangri-La TokyoGeneral Overview (I’ll go into detail in the following pages)…..Shangri-La is a perfectly serviceable luxury 5 star nicely located right next to the Tokyo Train Station. We took a corner room on a high club floor (36th story) which offered plenty of space for a family of 4 and had decent views. The room was well appointed and laid out nicely. I found the “club Lounge” (located one floor above us on the 37th story) as a nice plus for extra attention and a place to enjoy snacks/meals in relative peace. Breakfast is fresh and nicely presented. The club level staff (the only ones I ever really dealt with other than bell staff) were always courteous, helpful and went out of their way. The common areas are nice enough but I found they lacked any type of grandeur and opulence over being classic functional. I did find that in-room greeting amenities weren’t overly personalized. While they had stuffed animals and a cake train for the kids (a very nice touch), and a couple cookies with chocolate batons for the adults, there was no card recognizing that this was an anniversary trip versus a “standard” card for “golden Circle” members stating “Welcome Back” (never mind that this was my first stay in a Shangri-La and I had only joined the “Golden Circle” club when booking this reservation. Lol).  Overall….. I wouldn’t have a problem staying at Shangri-La again nor would I have a problem suggesting it to others. The personalized service is (for the most part) there. The rooms are spacious and well done. Breakfast was about the best out of the 3 properties we stayed at while visiting Tokyo. While I think Shangri-la is a bit over 4 circles, the previously mentioned lack of grandeur and a few niggles keeps me from giving it a straight 5. In-Depth Review…2 Adults (40’s), 2 Children (girls ages 3 & 7). Travelling for leisure as a wedding anniversary trip.Check in…. I emailed ahead of our departure from the hotel we were currently staying in and we arrived by Taxi. Our luggage was taken/tagged and we were escorted by the bellman up to the Club Lounge for Check-in. After being seated in the lounge, drink orders were taken and a member of the lounge staff came over for a personalized check-in. As we had taken the pre-paid rate, a receipt was given for such. Our passports were checked and the credit card was taken for any “incidentals” (mini-bar, restaurants, spa, etc.). We were then shown down to our room by the same staff member. Painless, easy, personalized, ProfessionalBed Room/Living Room… Luggage was in our room upon arrival. We had a corner room. While the smallest room of the hotels we stayed in while visiting Tokyo, it was still a decent enough size (about 63m2) to accommodate our party of 4. This was the only property out of 3 to have the living room and bedroom areas together versus in separated areas (aka jr. suite style) which helped the room appear larger, spacious, and open. 1 King size bed, 2 nightstands, an L shaped couch next to the window, and a desk/table. Large flat screen TV on wall. We had an extra bed installed for the children which fit nicely below the tv/entertainment area and didn’t interfere with the flow of the room (i.e. we never felt that the room was crowded due to having the extra bed). Amenities were in the room upon arrival. These included a cake train for the kids and cookies for the adults. There was also a small platter of 3 fruits alongside the previously mentioned “welcome back” card. 2 stuffed bears were on the bed for the 2 kids. Overall a pretty professional 1st impression that seemed to give consideration to all guests in the room (the children are often forgotten).Nespresso machine is provided along with a few capsules (although no explanation was provided as to what the different capsules were). Mini bar seemed to have a good selection of drinks. One night they even laid out the ingredients and provided us with an “in-room drink recipe pamphlet”. We don’t drink but I still found it a neat touch and a bit original compared to what I’ve seen at other properties. Not sure as to the food selection to be honest. Bathroom…. Nice large tub next to the window. Separate Rain shower. Usual Japanese “automatic” toilet. Large Single sink. . Nicely decorated and spaciousBulgari soaps, shower gels, etc. All the amenities you would probably expect and perhaps need (razors, toothbrushes, cotton swabs, sewing kit, etc.). They even provided a little kit in a nice bag as a gift for my wife (something to do with makeup removal). While my skin isn’t usually sensitive, the shave cream burned my face for about 20 minutes after I applied it. Adult robes and slippers were in place, but I needed to call for the kids. Although this was easily fixed with a phone call… it was still a slight miss. Plenty of towels were provided and refreshed as needed. I don’t remember ever running out.One issue is that the shower has see-through glass doors… so… anytime someone else needs to use the toilet, sink, mirror, or bath, there is no privacy. I’m not overly squeamish as to nudity… but it’s almost like being in a zoo exhibit. Of course there are no doors on the bath either so perhaps I’m just being overly pickyClub Lounge….I myself found club level to be worth the extra cost and would opt for it again in the future. I enjoy Club Level service & lounges and Shangri-La was no different. While I thought the lounge was a bit on the smaller side and dark (use of dark wood in tighter quarters and lack of sunlight), it was still nicely done overall. I’m a bit up in the air as to their use of couches in the lounge. They take up a lot of space and while they are nice for a drink, they aren’t overly ideal for eating.The lounge staff were all polite and professional with a friendly greeting and quick service. Very attentive. My 3 year old was quite playful and the staff took their time to play with her and were patient with her following them around the place. On our arrival, they had run out of watermelon on the buffet. While I’m sure they were going to refill it anyways, one of the staff (the manager I believe) went in back and made the 3yo a personal plate full of watermelon. One night the 3 year old fell asleep early and upon request the staff made her a small plate of food and delivered it to the room for her to eat later.My 7 year old wanted a massage and the lounge manager went out of her way to coordinate with the spa manager in order to allow her to do so. My 7 year old was so impressed overall with the lounge manager that she insisted on buying her a box of chocolates (first time that’s ever happened).Train tickets to Narita were arranged by Club Lounge staff,Breakfast is nice. Eggs, waffles, pancakes and the Japanese breakfast are ordered off the menu (try the eggs Benedict royale with lobster & caviar. So good that my wife and I greedily ordered 2 each morning). Meanwhile… the buffet contains the usual variety of pastries, fresh fruits, cold cuts, local cheeses, salad, etc. They also do a nice job of throwing in a few extra little specialty dishes (i.e. verines, etc.).  Although a bit limited at certain times, there was usually a selection of food throughout the day. We had “dinner” there once when the main dishes were shrimp and duck. Also nice for a quick coke, juice, or coffee (take away coffee is available). No pineapple juice for the kids but I’m sure the fresh squeezed orange juice was an acceptable substitute.There was a slight mistake as to credits for the spa but as it actually ended up in my favour I can’t really complain. I had originally booked $300 in advanced credit for the spa. They mentioned it would be canceled when I changed to the pre-booked rate. When checking in, they gave me my receipt with a hand written note saying that I had the spa credits. I asked them to verify this as I had been told otherwise… They checked, and while we were out, they left me a note in my room stating that I indeed had spa credit and here’s a spa menu…so…of course we went ahead and used it. When I went to check out, I noticed that they had billed me for the whole thing. Of course I mentioned that I had credit… They then told me that “No, I actually didn’t because of the rate change”. I mentioned that they had said I did & that I even had a note saying so. Either way… They took it off my bill… Although the situation was a bit embarrassing, I would guess that someone on staff made an honest mistake which was corrected in favour of the client (which in my opinion is the way it should be). So again…No real complaints.Spa… We had planned Disney for our last day but ended up too exhausted to really want to do it. I gave my daughter all the information as to crowds and waiting times at Disney and then gave her a choice…Busy day at Disney or a relaxing Spa day (which we had credit for anyways). I’m a bit proud to say that she understood and chose the spa… While we wanted 3 massages of 90 minutes, they only had 1 room available for 60 minutes. I of course bowed out and let my wife and daughter take the slot together. But….. The spa has a policy of 16-17 years old. As I had the lounge manager arrange things, I do hope it wasn’t too big of an issue. A massage is in a private room so it’s not like my daughter would have been running around bothering other clients anyways…….Many properties actually have children’s massages in their Spa Menu. …Happily they were willing to be flexible and allow her in.Either way…They both seemed to enjoy their massages. My daughter was quite happy. My wife usually prefers masseurs over masseuses and wasn’t given a choice but I suppose one takes what is available (or perhaps socially acceptable?). A workout room is available in the spa/pool area. As a tourist I spend enough time walking and carrying my 3 year old to care too much about workout rooms. Pool… The pool accepts children at certain hours (I believe it to be 0900-1800). While allowing my children to swim is a mandatory requirement for me in a hotel (it was actually the reason I cancelled my reservation with Mandarin Oriental), I understand others may want some peace and don’t mind limited hours (too much). Nice enough pool. Medium sized. More practical/utilitarian versus having much ambience. They did have candles set-up in the window but I never saw them lit. View from the pool area was nice enough (but it’s not as if I spend much time looking out the window when I’m playing in the pool with the girlies). The pool was never busy and once we had the whole thing to ourselves.This was the only property we stayed at in Tokyo that had the Jacuzzi and pool in separate areas. Not a huge deal but still inconvenient when you need to keep an eye on kids Kickboards, water peanuts, and kiddie water wings (arm floats) are available poolside. If I remember correctly they offered goggles at the desk. Swim caps were required and provided at the desk (standard in all the other properties I stayed at in Japan as well). Bottled water was set up in the pool area and the spa attendant brought in a pitcher of lemon ice water when we arrived (the pool had been empty upon arrival both times). The normal standard in luxury properties is to lay towels over the poolside lounge chairs (either in advance or when the client arrives on location). This doesn’t seem to be policy at Shangri-La. We don’t do much sitting over swimming so this wasn’t really an issue but it does sort of miss on service/luxury. Housekeeping… For the most part they did a good job of always refreshing the towels, soaps and amenities but we did somehow end up short a roll of toilet paper and a couple soaps on our last day. I just called for the items and they brought them straight up.While water and glasses were provided and refreshed for the adults, they never left any for the kids. I didn’t mention anything, but it would have been a nice touch.Ice is provided at evening turn down.  The beds were done nicely. The kids’ nightclothes were folded and their stuffed animals arranged nicely on the bed. They provided a secondary smaller stuffed bear keychain for the children during our stay. Although they originally provided only 1 for the 2 children, they gave me another one after I left a polite note explaining the situation.Shoe Shine Service... I used this once. I gave them a pair with special leather and special instructions. The shoes came back an hour later nearly perfect. I was impressed with the speed and the quality of the work. They brought the shoes back nicely presented (wrapped in paper and placed in a weaved wooden box). One note… Nobody seems to ever apply edge dressing to the soles (which suffer more than the leather uppers) so I usually carry my own and do it myself.Laundry service….. As a club level guest we had credit for laundry so I had them do a few items for our trip back home. Items were returned nicely presented (wrapped in paper with a scent packet and placed in a weaved wooden box). Slight Service Miss….They wanted full adult price for my daughters’ basic cotton dresses (which are smaller than my cotton dress shirts). When I requested the same thing at the Tokyo Peninsula they actually sent a guy up from the laundry to check things out and quote me a price (which was 1/3 of their listed “dress price….and then they even charged me less than they quoted). Smoking Lounge… This is the only property we stayed at that had a dedicated smoking lounge (there is no smoking allowed on Japanese streets so all hotels have a smoking area). I didn’t use it often but it seemed as if they could pay a bit more attention to clearing/cleaning the ashtrays (especially overnight/early morning). Either way, a dedicated smoking lounge is a plus when compared to having to go to the bar and feeling that you need to order a $20 coffee just for a quick smoke.Location/neighborhood...Right next to the Tokyo train station. This is nice not only for transport but for the variety of restaurants and shops located in the train station (drug store, convenience store, grocery store, starbucks).Also right next door is the high end 10 story Daimaru department store which was nice for a few hours of relaxed shopping on our last day. The restaurants on the 11th and 12th floors are open a bit later (2300) and we ended up having dinner there one night, and dessert another.Other than that, the surrounding neighborhood didn’t really seem to have much to offer other than a few restaurants, a few bars, a few gaming rooms, a few massage parlors. Nothing that really impressed us as something to visit for more than a couple hour stroll. Misc…Banqueting services are available (not used). Room service is available (not used)They have a Japanese restaurant (not used). There’s a bar/lower level lounge on the 27th floor across from reception (not used).Check-Out…. Check-out was handled with the club lounge staff the night before our departure and was simple enough. I had prepaid my room so all I needed was to pay off a bit of a spa tab and the train tickets to the airport that they had arranged for me. As mentioned earlier, there was a bit of a problem with spa credits but they quickly took it off the bill.Departure… We had an early breakfast at 0630. I called to have the luggage brought down at 0715. At 0730 we met staff on the first floor and were walked to our train platform (she even handled our 2 biggest bags). This is certainly a neat feature of the Shangri-La and it certainly helped eliminate the stress of navigating Tokyo station with 5 bags and 2 kids. From my understanding they’ll also meet you at the platform for arrivals.Conclusion… I enjoyed this property as a club level guest. All the bells and whistles are there and not much fine tuning is needed. My big issue is that it lacks the splendor of the other hotels. There is no 2 story entrance hall/lobby with art work, waterfalls, large crystal chandeliers, floral decorations, etc. While everything works quite nicely, aesthetically the public areas of this hotel didn’t wow me and take my breath away. This is of course a personal opinion and others may prefer the more subdued atmosphere offered here. While I might prefer the Ritz Tokyo, I would be more than happy to stay at the Shangri-La again and I would certainly recommend it to others

I stayed at the Shangri-La for business. The room was very large, very clean and nicely decorated. The service was also excellent. The dvd player in the room wasn't working so they imediately brought and set up another dvd player for me to use on my stay.Tip - the building to the "city-view" side of the hotel is being constructed, so I would guess it would be noisy during the day and when finished there will no longer be city-views. The "imperial-palace" view side is better and has a nice view of the train station. The station is far below so no noise issues. A word of caution. The hotel entrance is a little hard to find. The rates were also a little expensive. I stayed there because the Imperial Hotel and Palace Hotel had no availability (both just as nice and better value).

I loved the hotel when I first stayed, 2 years ago, but it was even better this time. Not sure how the rest of the hotel is, but I was fortunate enough to stay in one of the ‘Horizon Club’ rooms, and I can’t speak highly enough of the staff there, who treated me like a favorite visiting relative. I think over the course of the week I must have talked to at least 20 staff members, as well as the hotel manager and the ‘guest relations manager’, all going out of their way to make me feel welcome. which, of course, is exactly what a hotel should be/do;-)

I stayed at the Shangri-la Tokyo in early April and I must say that the hotel deserves much of the good reviews it receives. Throughout the 1 week I stayed there, I found the location extremely convenient, service unobtrusive but caring and efficient.Having arrived in Tokyo right in the middle of Sakura season, it was no surprise to me that the hotel looked very busy. Located right next to Tokyo Station (Yaesu North side), it was rather easy to locate the hotel. Having previously stayed at The Tokyo Station Hotel, I knew my way around Tokyo Station and was able to make my way to Shangri-la very easily. One criticism of the location though, is that there is no fully sheltered access to Tokyo Station, the end of the pathway leaves you exposed to the elements, albeit for only 25 metres or so, assuming you know which short cut to take, otherwise it's a longer distance being in the open. Unfortunately it took me 3 days before I learnt of that short cut. Like many other hotels in Tokyo, Shangri-la is located inside of an office tower, meaning that while the entrance is on the ground floor/basement (if arriving by car/taxi), the hotel lobby itself is on the 26th floor. To get to the rooms, one has to go up to the 26th floor and switch to another set of elevators. Not particularly inconvenient but a tad irksome if you're coming back from a long and tiring day. The property is tastefully decorated, featuring a very nice mix of oriental ornaments and art work. The grand staircase lends a very grand feeling to the hotel. I particularly liked that the elevator doors were made to resemble traditional wooden doors. The lounge across the Front Desk has a great view of the city. Then again, most rooms have a good view as well. The rooms are well decorated with all the modern conveniences one would expect in a luxury hotel. Electronic control panels for the entire room located right next to the bed and a full range of amenities. The long sofa in the room was particularly useful for me, as it allowed me to drop off my daily purchases and sort them without having to sit on the floor or the bed. Wifi speed was excellent and the study table had all the necessary outlets, as well as in international adapter. I had my own adapter but appreciated that Shangri-la thought to include one in the room anyway. I did wish the television had more international channels but that wasn't a big deal. The closet is huge and was perfect for my week long stay, allowing me to hang up all my clothes nicely. Like some of the other luxury hotels in Tokyo, that I've had the good fortune to stay in, Shangri-la provided umbrellas in their rooms. Considering that I was visiting during the wet season, I was most grateful. The bathroom is huge, especially the shower area. Like many other hotels, the shower area is located next to the bathtub. I found the rain shower to be a bit lacking in water pressure, maybe due to the fact that each room has rather high ceilings (more of a pro than a con in my books, made the room feel even more spacious than it already is). The regular shower head though was great, water was consistently warm/hot and water pressure strong. The bed itself was comfortable but not as good as some other hotels I've stayed in. Not a major complaint as it is still very good although I did find the sheets to be a bit stiff. Regardless, I was still able to get a decent night's rest. The fitness facilities are decent, although the gym isn't very big and could use a better range of equipment. The pool wasn't bad, although I was surprised at how crowded it was. Other business/luxury hotels I visited rarely had people using the pool, Shangri-la's was the opposite, even at 7am in the morning. As I preferred less people around, I only used the pool once. Service, as it is with almost all of Japan, was excellent. Every inquiry was met with knowledgeable responses. Even if the staff was unfamiliar with the topic in question, he/she would do a quick search online and come back with all the necessary information. The ground floor staff would greet every returning guest and would ask of their day and if there was anything they could assist with. Certainly made me feel very welcomed. On the whole, I would very much recommend Shangri-la Tokyo to anyone who might be keen to stay there. Personally, I find the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo to be a tad better in terms of service but that is probably more of a personal preference. The soft product is very much subjective but hard product is equally good. Without a doubt, I'd be happy to stay at Shangri-la Tokyo again if the opportunity ever arose.

I come to this hotel frequently, and am likely to stay here several times a year. I like this hotel. However, the last few trips have fallen a bit short. I have a few things I like to make sure I get. One is a non-smoking room. I hate smoke and I have asthma so it is pretty high priority. When I visited a month or so ago I ended up in a room that was suppose to be non smoking but could smell someone had smoked in. The hotel I guess was booked and they couldn't move me.My recent trip, my second request is a king bed. I just like big beds --- no health reason for this request. They gave me a room with 2 twins. I was there for several days and I asked if they had a different room. They said they did but it would be an upgrade so I would need to spend more. I was surprised with this response.... Is this the Japan I know and love?Being that I ALWAYS pay extra to use the horizon club and have been a very loyal customer, I mistakenly thought that would count. Will I stay again? Yes, I likely will, it is a good location, clean and comfortable. Does it feel like a luxury stay or special ... Not at all. Depending on why you are in Tokyo you would have to factor that in. Enjoy this amazing city!!!

Simply breath-taking in every aspect. Service was excellent, décor impeccable, Large full length window in room on 32nd floor overlooking Tokyo skyline was incomparable to anywhere else.One point however is that the buffet breakfast in my opinion was overpriced for what you got. Selection and presentation was good as was the experience and service, however the price was relatively very high to other hotels in Tokyo.

This is a great hotel with incredible facilities and rooms. We stayed twice during a recent trip to Japan - at the start and end of our trip. The thing that really stood out for us was the excellent level of service we received at all stages.Before we even arrived, we requested that the hotel make us restaurant reservations to overcome the language barrier. The team were happy to book everything from Michelin starred extravaganzas to small rough and ready joints ensuring we were able to experience the full range of what was on offer. The hotel even secured us reservations in restaurants outside Tokyo when we weren't staying with them. On arrival we were presented with comprehensive notes on each place including directions, distance from hotel, suggested cost/head and which forms of payment were accepted.We had a few issues whilst in Japan, including a mess up with our Japan rail pass. The staff of the Shangri-la insisted on sorting everything out for us, despite the error not being their making. Similarly one night, revelers in the next room were keeping us up (the rooms are well sound-proofed, but these particular guests would have tested the limits of a nuclear bunker). We called the management, who came and sorted things out. The next day, however, we had a hand-written apology from the duty manager, with his personal contact details should we face further issues. We stayed in the Horizon Club rooms and enjoyed access to the lounge that it gave us, and would seriously recommend the investment for anyone who will use the hotel for any time.Overall, as someone who rarely writes reviews, I would thoroughly recommend this hotel to anyone!Thanks again to all the staff who made our stay so memorable.Tom

From the moment you pass through the ground floor doors and you're met by the Bellboy, through to the reception experience, through to the very personalised check-in service in-room, this hotel delights at every turn. Stayed here last year and the exacting standards continue through 15 months later. The Japanese and Italian restaurants are top quality too, great range of foods and drink.Try the spa, book early to avoid disappointment.One down side for me - smoking is allowed in the lobby bar area and its not kept to a particular area of the bar which is quite disconcerting if you are a non-smoker and looking to eat too.

Grand hotel right in the heart of Tokyo with the convenience of transport network, shopping, visiting business partners in town, etc.Great breakfast spread with ala carte buffet style. Quality and fresh produce used.Nadaman Japanese restaurant serves creative, authentic and great tasting food.Undisruptive highspeed internet great for catching up work in room.Wide selection on intensity of room lighting - great for work and sleep.Will certainly return to stay whenever I am in Tokyo for business.

Stayed in Shangri La Tokyo for business trip 21 - 28 Mar 2015, I missed the tie in the hotel after the flight. Called the hotel from my home country and room services managed to find it and courier back.Appreciate the excellent quality of services and find staff are always smiling and helpful. I enjoyed the stay in the hotel.

I stayed in Shangrila Tokyo during Cherry blossoms in April 2015 with my wife and our 4 years old son. From the check in until departure, the staff provide excellent service, calling us by our names. We left our son's bolster in our room and the staff managed to have it ship for next day delivery. I think Shangrila has proved that they are worthy to be in the same league with Ritz Carlton, Four Seasons and other 5 stars hotel or even better. Bravo!!!!!

We stayed here for about 5 nights in one of the Horizon rooms. The stay was fabulous from start to finish. A very friendly conceirge from Shangri-La met us on the Shinkansen platform (we were on our way back from Hiroshima) and carried our bags from the platform at Tokyo Station to the hotel...it's about a 5-7 min walk. We had a lovely private check in. The only snag was that they initially put us in a smoking room, but this was quickly rectifed.The staff is friendly and professional. The service is excellent but not over the top. Everything is top notch and in a more understated Japanese way. They were very helpful when we need any reservations or advice. The spa is also amazing and I highly recommend you give it a go if spa days are your thing.We opted for the Horizon club because at the time, this hotel was the only one in Tokyo that had a club lounge and we always like some complimentary food and drinks ;) the food was delicious and drink selection was great. Although don't expect any amazing wines, which shouldn't come as a shock as the wine selection in Japan is not abundant anyway.All in all i would definitely recommend if you're looking for a lovely high end hotel in an amazing location.

The hotel is centrally located to everything........local restaurants 2 blocks away (under the train tracks) and about 7 blocks from the Imperial Palace.The room has everything you need........the bathroom is fully stocked and if you forgot anything.......it's probably already in the room.The room is a good size with modern furnishingsThe gym is a little small, but it has everything you need for a good workout.Room Service was good and quickOver all the service was good, i would stay here again!

This luxury property is within the upper floors of a new skyscraper, close to the station and within easy walking distance of the Imperial Palace Gardens. Rooms are spacious and well appointed with magnificent city views through floor to ceiling windows and the staff exude courtesy at every turn. Bathrooms have a glass wall on the the bedroom to enable couples to watch one another in the bath. There is, however, a privacy screen available for those of a shy disposition. Check-in lobby is quite cramped but there is an excellent bar adjoining it. The fine dining Placere restaurant has great city views but we found the food rather pretentious, over-salted and eye-wateringly expensive. Service is friendly but very slow. At breakfast the chef has not yet mastered the art of cooking fried eggs!

We stayed here for 3 nights for the first part of our Japan tour. The staff of this hotel is super, as we arrived from the airport we took the Narita Express to Tokyo Station where Shagri-pa staff is already waiting for us in the platform. It's a good thing we arrange for this free service or we could have gotten lost in this huge train station. Once we arrived at the hotel we were endorsed to Ms Claudia who took us directly to our room and had our check in there. The room is located at the 35thfloor with the view of the Marunouchi district, it was magnificent, huge for Japan. I love the toilet, it's so high tech that it automatically lifts the toilet seat every time you're going to use it, the toilet seat is even heated and comes with a washer to wash your behind after making a dump. What's coll is the it flushes itself after you use it. The room also has a Nespresso coffee making machine and during turn down service they provide you pajamas. Th location is centrally located with JR, Shinkansen and subway lines all inside the huge Tokyo station. There are a lot of nearby restaurants inside the station and a Daimaru department store beside the hotel. Bellmart convenient stores are also available and there are 2 Starbucks coffee if you need a caffeine fix.Check out was also a breeze and again they send us off to the train platform so that we don't get lost and miss our train back.Overall, this was an excellent start off point of our Japan trip.

Needed a hotel near Tokyo Station at late notice and decided to stay at the Shangri-La for the first time.
