Price for the room was horrifying, but it seems it was a very busy Friday night and many hotels were completely full or extravagantly priced, so I just hoped it was going to be worth it.It turned out to be a great stay. I ended up with unnecessary twin beds due to no availability of a single bed, but other than that the room was perfect: immaculately clean, spacious (especially by Tokyo standards) with everything I could possibly need and a pleasant, open view looking out high above Tokyo Station and across to the Marunouchi business district.Staff I encountered everywhere in the hotel were excellent (checkin, checkout, gym and poolside, Italian and Japanese restaurants). Polite, professional, helpful and many also with genuine warmth and not pure rehearsed professionalism.Although I pass through Tokyo Station often, I never realised just how close Shangri-La is, and it was an excellent choice for me as I arrived and departed by Shinkansen and the trains are only a short walk away, mostly under cover.I'm still in some shock from the price of the final bill, but this was mostly a consequence of a last minute booking in a peak time. Even so, I will have good memories of this brief stay for a long time and look forward to returning to Shangri-La Tokyo.

All Shangri-La hotels have superior service and upscale decor, but Tokyo's Shang has a world class ITALIAN restaurant, the best afternoon tea service, gorgeous marble bathrooms, fine art, oodles of brilliant Swarovsky crystal chandeliers and drapes embellishing the public areas- and the deepest lovely bathtubs and abundant fluffy toweling. Beautiful city views and it's proximity to Tokyo Statuon make this hotel a perfect find for any well-heled business traveler or tourist. ENJOY!
user_name:
bloggy99
New York City, New York

review_body: Very comfortable rooms. Perfect service. Our room had a great view, massive bathroom and a nespresso coffee machine. It also had comfy pyjamas, kimono style robes as well as regilar bath robes. At check out the hotel even gave me a box of chocolates as it happened to be my birthday.

Hands down the nicest hotel I have visited - incredibly high standards of service and a beautiful room as standard. The hotel has a gym and pool with onsen as well as a couple of very good restaurants. It is also very close to the palace where you can burn off extra energy with a couple of 5k laps. All of this is located right next to Tokyo station providing great links to all the destinations you have to visit when traveling to this wonderful city.

I have just returned home from what I believe is my 7th stay at the Shangri-La, Tokyo. I know for sure I will be back, there is no reason to explore the other great hotels in Tokyo (I have been to some of them). Firstly, it has the perfect location on top of Tokyo Station, and walking distance to quite a few of the companies I visit in Marunouchi area of Tokyo. Secondly, I feel elevated to another atmosphere (also literally) in this hotel where one of the world's capitals all of a sudden feels far away once you enter the lobby level.Thirdly, it is so wonderfully calm in the Tokyo Shangri-La, it is an art to make that kind of ambience where service and attention is around you all the time, but you dont notice untill you need a something.Lastly, many of the excellent staff that were there on my first visit a year after the hotel opened are still in the hotel, some with different function now, but as present and service-minded as on my first visit.Yes, it is expensive to stay in this hotel, but it was worth it I say to myself every time I (sadly) have to leave.

Shangri-La’s hotel rooms are wonderfully generous in size, with good desk space. I stayed four days, with my husband and little girl (and helper), in interconnecting rooms, while my husband attended a conference in the hotel.Shangri-La, Tokyo is in Marunouchi (the financial district); a very different area, and pace, to the other side of Tokyo, Shinjuku/Shibuya/Harajuku/Roppongi Hills. But is a perfect place for a few days with a small child.Marunouchi is quieter, close to Ginza; surrounded by high-end boutiques and department stores. Shangri-la hotel is just across a lane from Tokyo station, close to the Imperial Gardens, and a train stop away from MOMA. Ueno, where there is a zoo and natural science museum, is also a short train ride away. Tokyo station's underground tunnels offered lots of little restaurants, specialty stores and access to the department store, Daimuru. Especially convenient for moving around with a small child in winter (Tokyo station is also stroller friendly. Ie has lifts. Not all stations do in Tokyo).My daughter and I spent our time just checking out cute merchandise, appreciating the perfectly packaged food in department stores, bought stationary from Ginza Hands, and visited the Imperial Gardens and science museum. Oh, I also saw a wonderful exhibition at MOMA, Tokyo. Shangri-La staff are perfectly pleasant. The hotel is a more than comfortable place to stay for business or for a few days with small children.

The hotel is in the centre near Tokyo station. Very very nuce luxury hotel and the breakfast is outstanding with choice for everyone. The rooms are very nicely designed, perfect. Also the staff are very friendly and helpful. I stayed there last year as well and simply nothing goes wrong in this place.Right outside the hotel there is aplace where you can eat good quick food.The only thing to keep in mind is that the hotel is in the 28th floor of a business tower, and the entrance by car is from the basement of this business tower. When you take a taxi, if the driver does not know the hotel specifically, tell that him the name of the tower only, orherwise he may not be able to see the hotel and you may end up turning around the tower few times. But in general, the hotel is perfect!

The lobby, bar and restaurant are very nice. The atmosphere is pleasant, relaxing and luxurious. The rooms are very nice. They are spacious, great views, modern amenities and a large shower/bath area. The hotel is in central Tokyo - right next to Tokyo Station. The location makes it easy to get around the city and to and from the airport. Since the hotel is a luxury hotel it is expensive. We were disappointed that although there was a Nespresso machine in the hotel room, there were no cups. The hotel charged you for tea and coffee, which was also extremely disappointing. It was unclear whether there was free WIFI or breakfast. Had the hotel had these things I would have rated it a 5 and highly recommended it. In addition, we had lunch in the lounge and the lunch food was not very good.

This is the best corporate hotel i have stayed in Tokyo. Stayed in the executive suite. Huge room with luxurious funishings. Good spread for breakfast selection, both buffet n ala carte. Short distance, 5 mins walk to the Tokyo train stations n bullet trains. It is close to everything that is required, restaurants, entertainment, shopping. Highly recommended.

The Shangri-La Hotel, Tokyo is located at Tokyo Station. On this trip stayed four nights. We were met at the train platform in front of our car. Check-in was a breeze. The hotel common areas are spacious and elegant! The staff is first rate, and work very hard to accommodate their customers! The concierge staff was exceptional even helping me in trying to locate a restaurant that I had visited in the past but could not remember the name. The restaurant had been located in the past for (2011) by the concierge at Shiba Park Hotel. The Shangri-La Concierge listened to my rough description and even called the Shiba Park Hotel, and was able to find the restaurant and book reservation for us! Their service was was exceptional with all other requests and in answering all questions. The dining services was exceptional, and breakfast was included in our stay. Breakfast offered both traditional Japanese Breakfast options and Western Style Breakfast. The rooms are modern with first rate amenities, and very large by Japanese standards. The views are amazing from the lobby floor and rooms. The hotel offers great access to Tokyo and other parts of Japan via JR Rail Lines, and Tokyo Metro. Needless to say I was impressed with the total experience at the Shangri-La, and have no reservations in recommending it to anyone!!!

This is one of the nicest hotels I have ever stayed in. The rooms are a good size, well appointed, quiet and very comfortable. The lobby bar has an amazing view of Tokyo and very attentive staff. The breakfast is expensive , but very good. The gym is small, but modern and there is a very nice lap pool. Great place for business and families.

This hotel is near the nihonbashi side of tokyo station, or follow the directions to daimaru mall. Once you exit the nihonbashi doors it is outside on the right handside, very nearby.The good point of staying at tokyo station area are the trains that take you everywhere. So getting the concierge or studying the railway and metro map really pays off.Check in was very smooth and was given a room despite a very early check in. The rooms here are large and have a nice view of tokyo. Some of the corner rooms even have a view of mount fuji. To see that you need hazeless blue skies and of course the correct room. The bathroom is also huge and well designed.I really appreciate the 24 hour gym too.Breakfast here is great... variety and quality is there but not cheap. Besides eating in the hotel there are plenty of options in tokyo station and the surroundings.

I have stayed in November for 5 nights at the hotel. I am already a fan of all Shangri-la Hotels,so as soon as i saw there is one in Tokyo, did not look even for other options. The service was great, The Reception Manager Kenji Tsubahara was very helpful, kind and warm. The usual Shangri-la hospitality is even enhanced with Japanese kindness. So as soon as you arrive at the hotel, you really feel as in your home,they make this very well.The location is good, but it depends on what you are looking for. I prefer to stay in calm places with a nice view and close location to downtown. Tokyo has main centers, it is very difficult to choose the best center, this one is close to Ginza. (5-10 minutes by walking).Ginza is considered a luxurious shopping area, I did not do any shopping but the restaurants,bars and coffeshops were great here. If you want to stay in craziness of Tokyo, Shibuya or Shinjuku may be more favorable for you. Shangri-la Tokyo is more in a calm and organized part of the city, but since the hotel starts at high level of the building, the view is fantastic. The rooms are very clean and very big. In the pictures it is not obvious but the room space is just very good. I tried the spa twice, Chi-Spa is great but very expensive as usual. At the Spa, for weekends they charge you more for treatments because there are a lot of people coming from outside to use it, but i kindly explain that i am a hotel guest and it is not very fair to charge extra for hotel guest as well, so they were kind and did not charge extra. Again we have tried all the restaurants, they are all great but very expensive. Tokyo Station is below the building, for people who will travel in Japan like us, this was also great.

The hotel is located right next to Tokyo train station and within walking distances to offices around that area. Service is generally good and tentative with minor exceptions at times. Room is spacious for Tokyo standard.

We stayed in an executive suite for three nights to celebrate my 40th birthday. The hotel is beautiful. The service is beyond fantastic. And, the location is great.Our suite had every amenity imganinable - two bathrooms, large living area, comfortable bed room, large rainfall shower/jacuzzi room, walk in closet, Bulgari bath amenities. The room had two large windows overlooking Tokyo with Tokyo Bay in the distance.The hotel is above the Tokyo train station, sort of between the Yaesu North and Nihonbashi gates. It is about 15-20 minute walk to the Ginza district (basically down the Sukiyabashi street I think) and across the train station from the emperor's palace. It's relatievly short train ride to Shibuya, the meiji shrine, and other popular destinations.But, what really set the hotel apart was the unbelievable service. They helped arranged reservations for lunch and dinner at some difficult to get restaurants. My wife was ill for one of the days. The staff helped us get some medication from the drug store. At one point we thought about going to the ER and the staff called around to get information for us. The staff repeatedly checked in on my wife and even sent some special tea and honey with a get well note to the room for her. They sent a gift and note to the room for my birthday as well. Finally, we had a lunch just before needing to head to the airport. The staff stored at bags at the bell stand and met us there after lunch to walk us to the Narita Express, ensuring that we would get on the train in time to catch our flight (Tokyo station is large and can be confusing). The staff continually was one step ahead of us in everything. Truly the best customer service I've ever experienced.

Absolutely amazing stay at the Shangri La Tokyo celebrating my first anniversary with my partner.We were met by a very friendly member off staff outside the shinkasen carriage that escorted us through Tokyo Station to the hotel.We went for happy hour at the Lobby Lounge which was a very pleasant surprise and throughly enjoyed our evening with a great view over the city and it's bright lights while drinking different cocktails and a couple of the lovely wines.Breakfast was one of the best I have ever had with great food presentation and quality.The room was very spacious and welcoming .A big thank you to all the staff that looked after us very well and for an unforgettable stay while in Tokyo.

Excellent service, spacious room, courteous staff. What can you ask more? The location is right next to Tokyo Station, which is convenient. But it is in a office tower, so there's no lobby to speak of on the first floor; you need to get up to 28th floor. Access by car is tricky in that you need to drive into the basement. Inconvenient and annoying for the price of the room. So it is a good location and a bad location.

This Shangri-La hotel is actually 5 or 6 floors of an office building converted into hotel rooms, so the check-in is actually on the 28th floor, with rooms on floors 30 to 35. On the "city-view" side of the hotel, which the website brags about "overlooking Tokyo Bay", there is actually a massive construction site with large cranes. The construction on the building which is no more than 50 meters from the window is now at about the 30th floor and will wake you with banging and drills at around 7AM. I have read in other reviews that when other guests have requested to change their room, they were charged extra. My view is that paying $800 per night for a room should allow you to have a decent nights sleep, and that by not advising guests about this issue before they check-in is misleading and dishonest.The front desk staff mishandled the check-in and check-out. When checking in, the woman told me my Visa card was not accepted, meaning that I had to use my Amex. Of course, beyond the embarrassment of being told that your card is rejected, of course anyone would need to check to see why the card company rejected the payment. So after spending an hour of my time and more than $100 to make an overseas phone call to the card company, they told me that the woman at the front desk processed the card incorrectly. After going back to the front desk, another woman confirmed that there was no problem with the card. When checking out, instead of just processing the credit card for the full amount of the room, the woman at the front desk said that I would need to fill out paper forms, from which they would get approval from the card company for the additional amount over the initial amount from check-in, otherwise I would need to wait for them to call the credit card bank (are we back in the 1970's??)! Eventually, another employee stepped in and said that they could process a new charge for the entire room amount and then after we left he would cancel the approved amount processed at check-in, which I guess would actually overcharge the credit card and then reverse some charge later. Since we were in a hurry I chose this option and left. By the way, at this hotel, they actually take your passport and scan it into their computer!! Good luck with trusting their protection against misuse of your personal information! There were other incidents where employees were trying to swipe my Golden Circle card to use points to pay for drinks (only problem is that the Golden Circle card does not have a magnetic strip, kind of funny I guess), and other more minor problems with the room, etc... Overall, the service at the hotel was very poor. For the most part the employees were kind, but I felt they didn't have adequate training. As for the rooms, they were pretty average (we had a premier and deluxe room), but the fact that the hotel does not inform the guests about the construction directly outside their window is in my opinion dishonest. We have stayed at Shangri-La hotels all over Asia for the last 20 years and this is by far the worst experience. Next time we will try the Four Seasons, which is just on the other side of Tokyo station.

Nice staff, very helpful and informative. We stayed in the Horizon Club Room. They helped us through the transportation, sightseeing arrangement and even kimono rental. My parents also enjoyed the tour pretty much. Highly recommended!

Travelled to Tokyo on business. Shangri La is hands down the best luxury brand in Asia and this property is fantastic. Well located near the underground and overground trains and walking distance to great shopping and the Imperial Palace. The staff are fantastic. The restaurant on site is very good. The rooms are great along with the views.

My wife and I loved the Shangri La. We stayed in a premium corner room and everything about the hotel was just about perfect. The staff was very friendly without being overwhelmingly in your face. Our room looked out over Tokyo Station and, even though we could see the trains going by, we could hear absolutely nothing. The Japanese restaurant was very good for dinner, and the breakfast buffet was very tasty. It's in a great location, next to the station, if you want to travel anywhere from Tokyo. We took a couple of excursions and it was very nice to be able to walk to the station without even having to cross the street. Tokyo Station is an attraction in and of itself as well, you can always go there for some shopping or great restaurants. I love the free wifi, I hate being nickle-and-dimed from high-end hotels and it didn't feel like they were trying to do that at any time.

Our 3-night experience with Shangri-La Tokyo was very disappointing. We booked a Tokyo Bay view room but there were orange cranes which spoilt the view as a new building right in front is in the midst of construction. We had to pay extra to "upgrade" to the other side with Imperial Garden view. The French windows were unfortunately not the cleanest. We checked. It looked like the marks are on the other side of the inner piece, i.e. not cleaned properly before installation. After one night, we informed the Horizon Club reception staff that our bed was too soft. The staff said all hard mattresses were out but they would put a board beneath our mattress for our 2nd night and would change to a hard mattress for our 3rd night. On the 3rd morning before lunch, we went to the reception to enquire. A different staff was there and we had to tell her what was agreed. By the way, a staff confirmed they have a policy of changing the staff every 3 days; it's very frustrating. However, the mattress turned out softer than the first 2 nights. This gave us a bad lower back ache. Something basic like a good night's rest was not possible for us even though we paid top dollar for a so-called 5-star hotel. Overall, the service level was at best average. The staff at Horizon Club reception seem very patronising. We have stayed in Mandarin Oriental Tokyo which is much more luxurious and no issues with service.

Back in Tokyo and back in the Shangri-La. Arrived early morning and the room was ready upon arrival arrival with my amenities arranged. The size is perfect with big bathroom, great bed, sofa and a great working desk. We had breakfast in the lounge and the staff served us perfectly and even recommended a extra cup of coffee to allow housekeeping to finish cleaning the room. That is attention to details.We stayed there for 3 nights and enjoyed the service, food and great hospitality. We have stayed in many hotels and Shangri-La and the Tokyo Shangri-La meet our expectations and then some.

We took an exec suite as our teenage daughter was with us. It's towards the higher end I've ever paid for a hotel room, but I can't complain about the space, quality, service, location, or anything else.Spacious - being our first time to Japan, we were slightly concerned about whether we'd have room to swing a cat, not that we brought one. Turns out pussy could have come too - plenty of room, lounge, dining table, 1.5 very spacious bathrooms.Food - being an exec suite, we had access to the somethingorother club. We quite often do that sort of thing, as it solves the breakfast problem and sometimes the dinner problem too if we're not too hungry. The breakfasts were exceptionally good. Evening snacks less so, but still perfectly fine.Amenity - the hotel is in the top section of a tall building with offices in the bottom. Consequently, there's no such thing as a lower floor. We were second top, and heard no street noise at all.Location - just around the corner from the Tokyo station, so you're right near the Narita Express to the airport, Shinkansen to the ski fields, or metro for all of Tokyo. *Very* convenient. That said, Tokyo station has about a million exits, so if you're starting from the hotel the staff will give you directions and you'll find the station easily. But if you're arriving by train, don't imagine you'll walk out of the station and see the hotel across the road. Your chances of coming out an exit anywhere near the hotel are practically zero, and getting it wrong could involve kilometres of stumbling about with baggage.Tokyo station is big and confusing. It's a fabulous transport resource, but *do* schedule in time to get lost and wander about. Twice it took us a good 45 minutes inside the station to get to the right place with the right ticket. Second time around, it's easy.There's certainly cheaper places to stay in Tokyo, but the Shangri-La is exceptionally user-friendly and perfectly located for transport.

This is how it's done. Great, central location. Immaculate service. Excellent breakfast. Very tastefully decorated room with everything through, including nespresso machine and excellent tea selection. Good, reasonably priced room service menu. I needed a haircut and the concierge walked 10mins with me to a barber to sort me out. Impossible to find fault, a super hotel.

This hotel has everything. Excellent location, spacious modern clean rooms, and an attentive English-speaking staff that bring the word "gracious" to new heights.I have stayed here before and consider this to be the best business hotel in Tokyo. I've always been blown away by the quality of Shangri-La hotels worldwide. But this has to be one of the best.Congratulations to an impeccable staff that keeps this hotel at the top of its game every time.

The stay at the Tokyo Shangri-La was a great experience. Everywhere I found extremely helpful and competent staff at the front desk, in the Club Lounge and in the Italian Restaurant (Piacere). The spacious rooms are nicely decorated (for those who like the warm Shangri-La colors) even with private espresso machines. Also the bathroom is big with tub and two type of shower. Everything is just clean.The location at Tokyo Station is perfect for the local public transportation system as well as for the high speed trains.Despite to the fact the price is at the upper end, I will come back.

Great hotel with warm friendly staff, including excellent concierge who organised restaurants and sumo tickets. Comfortable rooms with fantastic bathroom. Lovely view. Next to Daimaru, Tokyo station and bus terminal. Lovely lounge bar with yummy cocktails and amazing views

Ideal location if you're going for a business trip. Near Tokyo station and within a short distance from the financial district.Check-in and check-out were quick and efficient. As anywhere in Japan service is great and staff very attentive. My room was very spacious with a great view (the hotel is located on the 27 to 35th floor of a building), not as luxurious as the mandarin hotel closeby but location is certainly better at this hotel.Very comfortable room otherwise, nice bathroom, wifi connection was good.I regret the lack of choices for Japanese food on the in room dining menu.Breakfast at Piacere is great, buffet with plenty of choices on top of picking a main course. Try the lobster eggs benedict, excellent.A little bit tricky to give directions to taxi as there is no proper drop off location on the street level, (only in the basement level). So a bit confusing for taxi drivers who for 99.9% of them don't speak English.Bottom line, had a good stay and would certainly stay there again on another business trip.

Like a second home, the Shangri La Tokyo had been the choice of my stay for the past few years, and spending a week almost every month there, I had never experienced any problems with the service and facilities. This time around is the same, and would recommend highly to anyone who is looking for a good time in Tokyo.

Within 100 metres of Tokyo station, and situated on the higher floors of a skyscraper is the Shangri-la Hotel. From the airport one's first exposure to this supercity is Tokyo station which has numerous exits and is warren-like in it's structure. Leaving by the 'wrong' exit results in a 15 minute trudge around it's perimeter. Arrival at the hotel is , therefore, the equivalent of a ray of sunshine reflecting off a building on a grey January morning. The staff are polite beyond comprehension. The rooms- even at the cheaper end of the tariff -are splendid with views towards the bay,in my case, or Shinjuku and Mount Fuji if you are fortunate, from the other side. The lounge area is perfect for a spot of lunch or a soothing, early evening glass of buttery Californian chardonnay watching the sun set over the Tokyo Skytower. Outside of the 6 large stations, of which Shinjuku is the grandest with over 200 exits and usage by 3.5 million people per day, the city is calming and unthreatening at any time. Japanese music is the music of reticence , the soft voice is admired, and the way that the city extracts a calming order from palpable chaos is something at which to marvel. There is no mobile phone interference on trains, no eating in public and, outside of the areas in which the young congregate, there is an almost complete addiction to understatement. Rather like Shangri-la itself the mystery which lies at the core of Tokyo leaves one emotionally satisfied and mentally at ease. The eponymous hotel simply contributes in it's own remarkable way to the tranquility.

My first visit to Tokyo was a real pleasure. The shangri-la is very well located near Tokyo station which made arrival by Shinkansen easy and subsequent use of the metro fantastic. The service at checkin was superb and the room had every luxury imaginable and was in immaculate condition. The rain shower was pure heaven. We loved our breakfast at piacere and our dinner at nadaman. Our only disappointment was dinner at piacere where the service did not meet our expectation, which was a shame because the food is high quality. We were there over the busy Christmas period and the hotel probably needed a few more dining options to cater to travellers in need of a no fuss, satisfying meal.

Travelled on business and stayed in a club room. Chose this hotel for a change in style and location having stayed at the Palace, Mandarin Hotels on other visits. Service was very polished, obliging and discreet. Club lounge was well worth it - quality breakfast, canapes and drinks. Room very comfortable, lovely toiletries, quiet. Great views as the hotel is on the upper levels of the building. Was lovely to relax in club lounge before my evening flight after my late check out. Easy walk to shops - the famous Daimaru department store and attractive neighbourhood. Small but well equipped gym, nice spa. In all a very nice hotel and i would stay here again. I appreciated the friendly escort to tokyo station for the Narita Express - it gets a little confusing down there. In the station.

We love traveling to Japan and have stayed at the hotel now for the second time some 3 years apart. It is as we imagined. Service is excellent and the location outstanding for shopping and business. see you there!

This hotel was booked on location and the fact that we are members of the Shangri-la. The hotel is located perfectly, the service overall is as expected and the rooms are very nice. Standard fare but with an upmarket decor. I couldn't give this property the total praise it could easily deserve for an incident at check-in. Let me explain.We arrived at about 10am which agreed is before the alloacted check-in time, however we knew this and were happy to leave our bags and go out for a while until our room was ready. We were then told that our room category was not abvailable yet and that for 15,000 YEN we could go directly to a room that was available (Horizon floor). We declined and found that a little odd after just hearing the lady next to us offer her guest the same explanation at a cost of 9,000 YEN which he accepted. I mentioned this to our lady checking us in and queried it, as soon as she started to get confused the front desk manager came over and said "oh, it looks like your room is available immediately, you can go up now". I found this very odd for a Shangri-la and this was cause for concern. I will be following this up with head office as I feel something unethical is happening here. I don't mind paying for service and accomodation of this nature as this is the way we prefer to travel, but this has made me very weary.

My last stay in one of the most famous hotels of the Shangri La brand (the Wing at the Shangri La Singapore) had been a real disappointment and put me off the chain for a while, and thus, when I decided to give Shangri La another shot after some time, it was with some apprehension. In two nights, Shangri La Tokyo managed to completely restore my faith in the brand and offer me one of the very best levels of service that I have ever experienced (I am comparing, among others, to multiple Peninsulas, Mandarin Orientals, Four Seasons's, Park Hyatts, Ritz Carltons, St Regis's, etc). The stay was in a Horizon Club room and with Signature travel perks.The level of attention to detail is simply astonishing, from the little teddy bear or origami that accompanied my turndown service (I loved that!) to the three different types of bath salts that allow you to run a bath that effectively suits your mood (jasmine, chamomile, or rose)! The Horizon club benefits allow you to enjoy your breakfast as a room service set menu which is a very big plus when you feel jetlagged, or in the club itself with signature dishes that include a lovely lobster and potato cake benedict or a full Japanese breakfast bento as well as freshly squeezed orange and grapefruit juices. The food quality at the Japanese restaurant Namasan was also excellent. My brother lives in Tokyo and he and his girlfriend came to meet me at the hotel multiple times as it is conveniently located by Tokyo station. On one occasion, after dinner, my brother's girlfriend felt very poorly and the hotel team was extremely helpful, with the duty manager visiting her as she came to briefly rest in my room, and proposing to call a doctor. The next day, everyone was asking me how she was feeling and showed plenty of sympathy.The location is excellent - by Tokyo station (Nihombashi exit is the best) and within 10 minutes walk of both the Imperial Palace gardens to the West and Ginza. The rooms are large (about 50sq m), very intelligently equipped (fully automated blinds, fully centralised yet intuitive lights systems, etc) and the views are very beautiful from all sides of the building (my favourite was towards the Imperial Palace but some people will prefer the view towards Tokyo Bay and the Sky tree, in effect, it is very pretty on every side, especially as all rooms are between the 30th and 37th floor anyway!). Horizon Club rooms come with all the trimmings: wet area with both bathtub and rainshower and bay window to the room and outside views (and blinds that can be lowered if anyone is feeling modest!), Nespresso machine, pyjamas (shame for the polyester/cotton mix rather than pure cotton but the thought is already wonderful!), the usual Shangri La stationery kit (very convenient on a business trip), etc. That said, once again, what makes the place really special is the incredibly thoughtful and attentionate level of service - this is hospitality at its very best and an example many other luxury hotels should try to learn from.

I've stayed in this hotel multiple times. Hands down, it is the best hotel I've ever stayed at. From the food to service to room to location, it cant be beat. For example, I was getting a car to the airport. The concierge came to gather my luggage to bring it to my cart. As I was closing my luggage, the latch broke. Long story short, the host took me to the nearest mall to purchase a new luggage. While purchasing the luggage, the associate at the mall swiped my card twice for some reason, therefore the security for the credit card company blocked my card. They then swiped my second card which didnt go through, therefore I had no cards and not enough cash to buy the luggage. The Hotel host left his hotel ID and hat with the Sales Associate at the mall. We left without paying at that point for the luggage as I had to get to the airport. NOW THAT'S WHAT I CALL SERVICE. I will ALWAYS return here and stay no where else in Tokyo!!

This was our second stay in this hotel and we went back because we loved it so much. It is in the perfect location, within easy walking distance of the Imperial Palace and Ginza, and almost on top of Tokyo Station. You can ask for a room that overlooks the back of the station so you can see all the trains coming and going - it feels like having your own personal train set! On a clear day you get a very good view of Mount Fuji from those rooms too. It must be very well sound-proofed, though, because there is no noise, either externally or internally - it is a very quiet hotel. The rooms are beautiful and you are given lots of thoughtful extras - lovely Bulgari toiletries, beautiful kimonos to wear while you are there, and even clean white cotton pyjamas every night - it does make you feel very spoiled and special. The public spaces are wonderful too and I would definitely recommend the hotel's Japanese restaurant, which is an experience all on its own - excellent food, exquisitely presented and served by kimono-clad waitresses. The staff throughout the hotel are excellent - friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. We were on the Executive Lounge floor so we saw more of the staff there than in other places, and they were superb - world-class service in a world-class hotel - highly recommended.

Excellent in every way. There is attention to detail from check in to check out. Outstanding service, and oh so quiet, fabulous rooms. Relax with a superior spa service. Great location for shopping and conducting business.

We stayed at this hotel for four nights the end of November. We had a fantastic stay. The rooms are modern and large for city standards. The views from every room of the hotel are excellent, since the hotel starts on the 28th floor. The bathrooms are fabulous and I loved that you were given pajamas every night with turn down. The gym was also great. All new machines, a beautiful lap pool and lovely spa. Breakfast in Piacerre is excellent. It was one of the best omelettes I've ever had. Tea time in the lobby was lovely with live music. Dinner at Nadaman on our first night was a perfect way to settle in. Loved the location, just steps from Tokyo station and a 15 minute walk to Ginza. I would stay here again.

We stayed at the Shangrila Tokyo for 4 nights in Apr this year. This is our forth stay over past 6 years. Below is a quick summary from my recent experience - 1. Check in: there was an flexible front desk staff called 'mammi'. We had an Amex coupon that we used to book for 2 nights and the other 2 nights we booked with corporate rates. She refused to combine our booking upon arrival and told us we had to check out after 2 nights and change to another room. She told us that we had to pay more if we were to stay in the same room. We waited for more than 30 minutes at the front desk and she didn't escalate the problem but was very rude and insisted we pay and made other staff look at us as if we had not pay our bills or something. We had to escalate this to the head of the desk which we waited another hour, so we left our luggage while we went for our lunch at 3.30pm which we were starving. mammi's boss called us and apologised and resolved the issue. I told her how upset we were being the 4th times return guests. The rest of our stay was smooth as expected. But I would try to stay in another hotel closer to the main shopping attractions. Shangrila hotel is a little far from places like Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku etc, And for luxury shopping in Ginza, it's a 15 mins taxi ride which isn't cheap going back and forth each day. In terms of facilities, I do love the pool at the Shangrla, their gym is also good. Shangrila is ideal for tourists who travel out of Tokyo for a day trip or as connecting hub. We went to Haneda a few years ago and stayed in a luxury hot spring villa for a night between our stay at Shangrila.

This hotel is quite expensive and it delivers! This was a business travel trip and my booking was made at the Horizon level of service. The hotel is in a high-rise above Tokyo Station for quick access to commuter rail and Shinkansen (bullet train) as well as the express to Narita airport. I'm struggling to find just one issue with this hotel. I travel often for business internationally and this hotel is unmatched. This hotel is exquisite. From the moment I arrived the staff was one step ahead of me in meeting my needs. They understand western culture and are exceedingly gracious as is all Japan. I entered my room and was greeted by very relaxing music which calmed me immediately following a hectic travel schedule. My room was very large and I had more amenities than at home from the high tech toilet to the electronic window shades. My room was above Tokyo Station on floor 36. I heard no sound from outside. Upon my arrival I changed from my business suit to casual business attire for dinner on short order. I left my slacks draped on the bed. I returned from dinner to find my slacks pressed and hanging and the tea/coffee bar went to a cocktail presentation. Pajamas and slippers were waiting for me as well as a bottle of water and a glass by my bedside. My impression is the indirect Japanese message for Westerners at this hotel is to "relax, we have your back"I can go on and on.

Stayed here for 9 nights on our first trip to Japan for holidays and sightseeing and took daytrips with the Shinkansen. Perfect location just 2 minutes from main station (but absolutely no noise in the rooms as the hotel is on 26+ floor), walking distance of Ginza and max. 5 minutes to restaurants, several Starbucks and a 7/11-like store at the entrance of main station. Department store Daimaru with an outstanding food selection - grocery in the basement comparable to Dean&Deluca and restaurants in the top floors - is just 5 Minutes away. Walking distance of Ginza shopping district, Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park. Very spacious rooms with wall-to-wall, floor-to-ceiling windows, no sounds of neighbour rooms or from outside, well equipped, and a top bathroom area. Great rainfall shower with high water pressure, what I like. Sooo comfortable beds. Everything immaculately clean. Top service all around. Not just friendly and helpful and fluent in english, which is already asked a lot nowadays even in better hotels, but forward-thinking and caring. One example: On arrival I gave front desk a small piece of paper with my (potentially lethal) food allergies written in english and kindly asked to write down the japanese translations to have them on hand when visiting a restaurant. Okay, standard so far. But when I ordered room service a couple days later they knew about the allergies without me having to tell them - that's what I consider customer orientation. Perfect meet and greet service on the station platform when we arrived with the NEX Narita Express Train (we never were able to find the way through the at times confusing station upon arrival). And so on and so on - whatever we thought of, hotel staff took care of us. To make the most of any review on Trip Advisor you really need to know the typical places the reviewer stays and the standards of judgment. After 3.000+ hotel nights in my career I just want a clean and quite place and good service and do not really care about the room size or price in the first place. And a memorable experience is a plus, especially while on vacation. I do judge by peer groups and price levels: What could you in all fairness expect from a Hotel within its peer group – because else even good quality basic hotels had no chance for good reviews against top notch places.Having said that: This is a top notch hotel compared against any other place. Top hard product and a more than outstanding service. Just perfect. Would give six starts. Treat yourself with the tea ceremony if you have the opportunity.

This the best hotel i have been stayed in my life. Location is very good next to the Tokyo station just one minute walk.Incredible breakfast there are many choise best omlet. Very kind staff very helpfulHighly recommended

Stayed for 3 nights. My usual hotels Palace and Imperial were both full.This is a very good hotel in the centre of Tokyo business area. Easy access from both Narita and Haneda. But the airport limousine bus does not stop here. You need to get off at Tokyo City Air Terminal ( TCAT) and take a taxi. Or Taxi all the way from Haneda is 7500 yen. Shangri La has 10 floors in this tower building. Top Tokyo standard for sure. Effective and polite staff. Nothing to complain about. Good Wifi. Good mini bar. My friends room did not have a shower. He checked in late. Japanese standard is bath tub. Please note. I had huge rain shower.So ask for shower. The hotel is directly linked to Tokyo station. Many restaurants and shops. But all restaurants are all rather fast food oriented and not very good. But Ok and safe. Although this is a good hotel by any standard, it is not the place I come back to. It lacks atmosphere and character . It is not the place you remember after you check out. Breakfast is fine but bit expensive yen 4500. For tourist this is wrong area.

Great rooms, great service, great location! Shed a few more bucks and book the Horizon Club Floor. They treat you like VIP and serve quality breakfasts and cocktails! I just checked out yesterday, Dec 1 after a four day stay and will definitely book with them again next time I'm in Tokyo.

Without a doubt my favourite place we stayed during a ten day trip to Japan. The room is stunning and the views incredible (we had a bay view room on the 31st floor). The pool and spa in the hotel were a great perk - we went for a swim at sunset and the views from the pool across Tokyo were magical (the pool is surrounded by floor to ceiling windows). The bed was SO comfortable and big, and the bath and shower were great. A great night of luxury (we spoilt ourselves on our last night in Japan). The location is also great - about a 2 minute walk to the train station and Daimaru shopping centre. Would definitely recommend for those willing to splash the cash.

Stayed here for 6 nights. The rooms are amazing. Every possible amenity. The beds are so comfortable. The staff help you with any possible need. As an example Tokyo Station can be a very confusing place. The staff escorted us to our train and platform. Truly one of the finest hotels in the world. Excellent location. Beautiful hotel. Immaculately clean. Can't wait to return.

As a frequent business traveller, I've been to a lot of properties across Asia so it takes something a little special to stand out. The Shangri-La possesses just that, from the excellent location right beside Tokyo station (with connections to the usual train network as well as the inter-city Shinkansen lines) to the very generous sized rooms by Tokyo standards - or any city for that matter - to the attention to detail... I had used the kettle to boil water the first couple of days I was there for the plunger coffee in my room and the staff must have noticed, cause each subsequent day I would find the kettle set up, filled with water ready to go.The attention to details as small as this is something that most business hotels would completely miss, but for me, is indicative of the focus and attention the hotel places on their guests' individual experiences.Outstanding. Highly recommend if your credit card doesn't groan under the strain - the property is definitely not for the overly budget conscious.

This is my second experience stay with Shangri La hotel. My first was in Hong Kong Island, For Japan Tokyo, it location was true as mentioned by those who have given their remarks in tripadvisor. It is indeed super near to the Tokyo station. Shops, Departmental store (Daimaru), restaurants. raman street are all inside the station. Shops close at 8pm, but the restaurants close later by 10pm, but some at 9pm. You can find anime stuff, kids stuff, Hello Kitty and tibits. You can also find a small uniqlo, Tokyo banana is every where, if you walk further inside the station, it is also link to H & M (Not a very big shop) and other fashion and foot wear shops. I stayed in this hotel in late october 2014 with my mum, we are at 33 floor. Train station view. We have our breakfast everyday in the Italian restaurant "Piacere". Staffs are always carry with a smile everyday BUT, not all of them do. The rest i can tell that they are doing their best to make you as comfort and enjoying the meal as they can. I really appreciated. They can be communicated in English and some can speak mandarin. They serve good coffee and tea.The hotel room was big and comfy, it provide pajamas, Yukata, bathropes and slipper. So you don't have to bring your own during your stay in this hotel. Or maybe you can bring one or two if your itinerary don't stop in Tokyo only. For those who like "Ginza Akenono Mochi" (Da Fu), you don't have to go very far to find it. Inside Daimaru have a counter. Concierge was helpful.However, the hotel fridge was not cold enough, so if you want to store some food for next day or food that you want to bring back to your country, don't forget to bring along a food warmer bag that can keep the food from going bad and try to get some ice pack from outside. I got mine from a bakery shop, of course you have to buy a cake from them.

Super convenient; inches from the Tokyo Central railway as well as steps from two other subway stops. Great views, either towards the Imperial Gardens or to the Sky Tower, with spectacular night lights flickering. Friendly, if somewhat subdued service, even the most basic of rooms are spacious, welcoming and luxe. Amenities go on forever: In the bathroom there are razors, toothbrush and toothpaste, combs and brushes. In the main room there is a tech box with cables so that you can hook up (whatever device you have on hand) to the Bose sound system through the 42 inch LCD TV. If you need to know what happened to the yen yesterday or will follow in the footsteps of an asteroid across the western sky, there’s also a mini TV in the bathroom (which is three rooms, a toilet with a sensor on the seat for ups, downs, flushes, etc., a well-proportioned sink, and a shower/bath area which can be secluded with a blind or opened to elevate the experience across the urban landscape, if you will). The 300 thread count linens are lovely, there is a robe, pajamas and a kimono to choose from for lounging. So much pleasure! And your own private bar. Alas, you have to call down for ice and, in the entry level rooms, even tea and coffee are an extra, which just seems a little stingy at this price point. But still, this is dead central in one of the priciest towns on the planet. There is not much to dislike. Except, perhaps, the price, for these digs don’t come cheap. If you’re willing to ante up I think the reward is worth it. But is it worth it? The 20 meter pool, the expansive views, the $36 American breakfast? I’m not convinced. I liked it, I enjoyed my stay, I don’t have anything bad to say, except that next time I might stay at something close by that costs a tad less.

I booked this hotel for a quick 4 night trip to Tokyo. Location is most convenient right next to the Tokyo Station, so access to and from the airport is great, and the Daimaru department store is right above the station. Our welcome and check in was so professional. Our room was not ready, so we were offered another smaller room to relax and freshen up in. When we got to our room, we were just amazed at the view from the 33rd floor, had a corner suite. Bathroom was huge with an excellent range of amenities.The service was as good as one could expect, and the breakfast was by far the best we had experienced to date.The concierge was wonderful and the advice we received for restaurants etc was spot on. Would not hesitate staying here again.
user_name:
Larry W
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: It has been almost a year since I visited Tokyo for the first time and stayed at this unbelievably breathtaking hotel which memories still remain vivid in my heart and mind. With a room on a high floor, you will never wake up happier seeing the sun rise and coming back at night to an unforgettable skyline. The room itself is fit for a king and more with its abundant space (and a beautiful bathroom!). Breakfast spread was truly amazing and they were kind enough to agree to my special request of poached eggs every morning. The housekeeping staff also did an excellent job in arranging my toiletries that every person with a neat/orderly streak would be thoroughly impressed. On the last day, I had the privilege to be accompanied to the train station with one of the staff who helped with my baggage (which I really felt bad about as she was really petite but strong!). Perhaps the only downside was that I found the gym a little too small for a hotel of this standard but it is compensated with a heated pool which you could cover some laps after a long day of walking/work.  It is a perfect Tokyo trip dream come true!

My wife and I spent four nights at The Shangri La, Chiyoda, Tokyo in early October 2013. We could only describe it as potentially one of the best hotel experiences we've ever had. The hotel itself, is well positioned on one side of Tokyo's central rail/metro station however once your wrapped in the embracing arms and scents of the hotel (it has it's own signature perfume) you have no sense of being in the centre of such an amazing metropolis. The rooms are incredibly spacious and offer wonderful facilities, as well as superb city views. The staff were incredibly helpful and attentive, at all times. This is a high end hotel however it is worth the investment for the experience.

I'm finishing up my 6 day trip in Tokyo and I'm not sure it could get much better. I will be staying at another hotel for another 5 days with my family joining me from US starting tomorrow so we'll see how that goes. This is one of the nicest, quietest hotels I've stayed at- from a perspective of having traveled all over the world and 100+ nights in hotels/year. Great views, of an amazing city, but the staff is truly what puts it over the top. the rooms are incredibly nice, the bathrooms like that of a high end spa. No it's not inexpensive, but nor is anything in Tokyo, save for some quick food runs... Stay here, be amazed. Wow is all I can say. I had food here. Drinks here. Changed money here. Oh, and amazing location right next to the train station and shopping areas all around.

My husband and I were only in Tokyo for just over a day - arriving from New York one afternoon and leaving for Bangkok the following evening. The Shagri-La was the perfect choice given the fact that we were taking the train to/from Narita airport and that the hotel is located right at Tokyo Station. We provided our travel information to the hotel in advance and were greeted at the train track and escorted to the hotel. Our room was perfect with a beautiful view, and we enjoyed excellent drinks at the lobby bar. The hotel provided us with wonderful restaurant recommendations and made reservations for us. We also got great advice on how early in the morning we needed to leave to see the tuna auction at Tsukiji fish market (3:30 a.m.!) and made it right in time before the first group filled up (the first group of 60 people). In our short time in Tokyo, we tried some great yakitori, did a pub crawl of the Golden Gai (highly recommended!), had ramen in "Ramen Street" in Tokyo station, had an amazing sushi breakfast outside of the fish market and an unforgettable sushi lunch at Sushi Iwa. The location, service and recommendations of the Shangri-La made that all possible (and our decision to skip sleeping!).
user_name:
Jill F
New York City, New York

review_body: Have stayed here before and this hotel never fails. Service is exemplary, from start to finish. Airport collection and hotel staff - at every level - are very professional, attentive and helpful. The hotel itself is a sweet surrender from the chaotic surrounds of Tokyo - perfect location with major shopping and the financial business district at doorstep. Guest rooms are on the larger size when compared with others. I stayed in Deluxe category room, a beautifully appointed, mine had a fantastic Mt Fuji view - everything worked, and the best guest room bathrooms in Tokyo. Very good lighting, and a sliding door closing off the entire bathroom area; separate toilet room and a massive marble walk in shower (two shower heads, one hand held, the other a rain shower) combines with the soaker tub which is closed off with a glass wall facing the bedroom sitting area - and that Mt Fuji view - and/or for privacy, there is an automatic draw down shade. The bed mattress is superb for sleeping-in!. This property although scaled-down when compared to other "typical" Shangri-La properties, has a lovely, discreet, boutique property feel. Lobby entry (28th floor) and a very enjoyable atmosphere all the way around. I stayed here for business 3 nights and wanted to entertain a group of colleagues in the Lobby Lounge on a busy night - not a problem. Kudos to Lounge Manager and also Guest Relations Officer, Claudia Ho - event flawlessly executed and everyone had a great time - the stunning views from the 28th floor Lobby Lounge night sky was a fantastic backdrop. Enjoyed high-tea with 5 colleagues - very nicely executed. Room service was flawless - in room dining selection in my view (not a criticism) was limited although the meals I did have were all flawlessly executed. My own personal selections would include a more local flavor. Housekeeping very attentive. Will definitely return when in Tokyo.

I really appreciate to stay at Shangri-La in Tokyo first of all for the exceptional quality of service plus a very good location and great rooms with wifi everywhere. I will stay again here as much as possible.

This summer we are stay in shangri-la hotel for 3 nights ,Our room is deluxe king room with a Horizon club , Staff very professional and helpful, and to provide anything as soon as possible.Great location. Imperial Palace is a mere 10-minute walk away.The breakfast buffet was very nice ,also have some meal for vegetarian. everything is perfect .We would like to recommend this hotel for our friends when they stay in Tokyo. Next journey we will stay in Shangri-La Hotel Sydney .

The service from this hotel was exemplary from the moment the car picked me up to the time it took me to the airport. Fantastic bar and lounge, excellent room service, beautiful room with every possible amenity and incredibly comfortable. Stunning bathroom! If you can afford it, stay here!

The hotel management of this particular property takes premium hospitality and service very seriously! I am very satisfied with their genuine service and trying to accommodate all of my requests. In addition, in my view, the location of the property is very good and the rooms are very well-maintained. I booked a room at the Horizon Club and the manager of the Horizon Club, Ms. Tomoko, is very professional and understands well what premium travelers want. She is a very genuine person and made all our requests met from buying our train tickets when were going to Kyoto to supply us with a wire less device when our mobile devices had a trouble to connect with the local wifi network. She seems to be well-liked by all the guests there as she was always on the run trying to accommodate guests' requests. Again, this hotel is an excellent choice and I strongly urge you to make a booking there if you care about premium and quality service. Good job Shangri-La Tokyo !

We had 2 stays that bookended a trip to Japan and would highly recommend the hotel for anyone visiting Tokyo. Its right beside Tokyo station, so convenient when arriving from the airport. Also very convenient to multiple Metro lines. The hotel is the usual high level of quality you'd expect from a Shangri-La and the staff are very friendly and efficient. The rooms are excellent and have great views over Tokyo. Breakfast was very good and we ate in Piacere on the first night we arrived in Tokyo, it was very nice.Overall, a very good hotel in a great location for a first time visit.

Shangri La Hotel was the best choice for us in Tokyo. It was so close to Tokyo Station for the Narita Express, Shinkansen (bullet trains) & the metro all in one. Disregarding this, we would probably have picked it anyway.This hotel exudes elegance and feels like a boutique hotel backed up by wonderful staff providing impeccable service that greet you every chance they get. Always helpful & always courteous. If you are looking for a hotel that buzzes with a raucous lobby then this is not for you. We wanted a sanctuary after being in the crowds & this was perfect. A loud, obnoxious guest would stick out like a sore thumb here & most breakfasts we were charmed to see some elderly Japanese ladies decked out in their Sunday best wearing strings of pearls.The room was spacious & exudes a peaceful, luxurious atmosphere. Nothing looked worn or wanting maintaining. Japan was hit by a typhoon while we were here & if you closed the blinds you would never have guessed there was a raging storm outside.Housekeeping deserves a special mention as everything was perfect & we returned each day to a wonderfully made up room with caring touches to our belongings.All in all, a perfect representation of the Shangri La chain & James Hilton's description in his book "Lost Horizon". We travel quite a bit and the Shangri La Tokyo is a hard act to follow by any hotel that we have stayed at.

Somehow the management of this hotel combine all the amenities and facilities of a typical international brand five star hotel with a Japanese ambiance and approach. The helpful and charming staff undoubtedly have something to do with this. The rooms are spacious and well maintained. The hotel is very well positioned for the central Marunouchi business area. It is expensive but worth it.

I have stayed at the Shangri-La Hotel in Tokyo several times, and it never fails to impress. The location, right next to Tokyo Station, is perfect. Check-in is fast, efficient, and friendly, without being over-familiar. Rooms are generously-sized, with wonderful light whichever way they face. On this occasion I got the rather euphemistically named "harbour view" - really just a city view of Nihonbashi - and missed seeing the Shinkansen trains pulling into and out of the station below - but that's me. Everything in the room works. There is full connectivity in a panel by the desk. The bathroom is amongst the best of any hotel I've ever been to: by putting in a large window, it feels light and airy. (There is of course a blind.) Having the pool on a high floor is also a feature of Japanese hotels, but the spa and gym facilities are impeccable, with attentive and friendly staff. Lastly, it happened to be my birthday, and I came back to the room to find a bottle of wine, glasses, and corkscrew, but most notably, a hand-written and illustrated card. I would not stay anywhere else: all hotels should aspire to be like this.
user_name:
alexgjohnson
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel lives up to its rating in every way and from the moment we arrived at Tokyo station.We were met by a lovely lady from the Shangri-la bell staff on the platform as we stepped of the Shinkansen at Tokyo who escorted us from the station to the hotel in a matter of minutes rather than us trying to find the right exit to find the hotel as the hotel is outside of the station.(Tip) if it is your first time to Tokyo and you want to be met at the station a quick e mail of your arrival details is all it needs to the hotel.As we had booked Horizon Club we were escorted straight up to the Horizon Club Floor and shown straight in to the lounge where we were asked to help ourselves to the complimentary sandwiches and cakes they were serving at lunch time, they took our order for drinks and we sat down to relax after our journey.Check in was completed in a matter of seconds and were advised our room was ready and when we had finished our drinks and food and at our convenience we would be shown to our rooms our luggage had already been taken to our room as soon as we arrived at the lounge.We were escorted to our room and shown how everything worked and if we needed any assistance with anything to let them know and they also enquired what time we would like evening turn down service.The room was large and spacious with a large bathroom and plenty of wardrobe and cupboard space available also pyjamas, dressing gowns and slippers are all provided in the room and has all the usual great amenities provided by Shangri-La.Every morning if we were in the room at about 10 am we were asked what time we would like our room to be serviced it is not many hotels who ask what time would you like your room to be serviced and on the 10 nights we were there it was spotless on every occasion.In an evening, drinks and food are served in the lounge complimentary and it makes a nice start to the evening to be able to relax with a drink before going out for the evening.Everybody we encountered in the hotel from housekeeping, bell staff, reception, concierge, staff in the restaurants and all the wonderful staff on the Horizon Club lounge all spoke perfect English.The hotel has a business centre which I personally did not use but I am sure being a Shangri- La will be more than adequate.The fitness centre and gym was also excellent and there is also an indoor swimming pool with a few sun beds around it if you wish to relax.We had breakfast in the restaurant and in the Horizon Lounge and in both locations it was excellent. It is buffet style but there is plenty of choice and for hot dishes the staff take your order and served at your table after being prepared by the chef. So there is certainly not the usual food that has been sat there for some considerable time.The location of the hotel is excellent right against Tokyo station and also close to several Metro stations within a 5 minute walk from the hotel and the main bus terminal is certainly no more than a 5 minute walk so again easy access around the city and sights of Tokyo.The Imperial Palace is about a 10 minute walk from the hotel so again a nice location.While in Tokyo we did a tour to Mnt Fuji and our tour did not pick up at our hotel the pick up point was just the other side of Tokyo station at another hotel and the hotel asked if we wanted to be escorted to the hotel, this we declined as it was a 5 minute walk and you could see the entrance to the pick up point from our hotel but I did see others take this up again service that you don't get everywhere.Our room overlooked Tokyo station and as all the rooms of the hotel are high up there is certainly no problem with noise from the station. A room looking over the station also means there is a good chance of seeing Mount Fuji from your room if the weather is clear enough. We saw it on a few days during our stay.I could not find any fault with this hotel and can't wait to come back to Tokyo just to stay at the same hotel for the service and staff.

Five-star luxury combined with classic Japanese hospitality. You can't get any better than this. This hotel is a real gem. The room is enormous (for Tokyo), and the amenitites are first-rated. Eventhough the price for the stay was high, it was worth every penny. You really get what you pay for. The staffs are superb. Very polite, very kind, and really genuine. The room is well decorated and the bathroom is spa-inspired. We did afternoon high tea on Sunday and it was memorable. In fact, it was one of the highlights of our trip. The location is also very covenient. It's right at the train station but is very secluded from all the Tokyo noises and traffics as the hotel itself is located on the high floors of the tower. I would stay here again when I return to Tokyo.

Had an excellent anniversary stay at the Shangri-La hotel. The hotel is located right next to Tokyo a station, which is very convenient. The stay began with two representatives meeting us at Tokyo Station and escorting us to the hotel. Check in was quick. During the walk, we offhandedly mentioned it was our anniversary and found a complimentary bottle of champagne in our room when we got back - excellent touch. The room itself was wonderful, big and luxurious. The food was excellent. The staff couldn't have been any friendlier or more useful. Perfect English across the board. The hotel is pricey, but highly recommended.
user_name:
Jose L
Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

review_body: Friendly staffs and excellent quality Japanese restaurant in hotel. Staffs are very thoughtful, it was raining when i want to step out from hotel, staff run after me to offered a umbrella, also my supplier have send a parcel to the hotel and not knowing that i have checked out on the same day, the check in counter staff remember which hotel i mentioned during checked out and they arranged the parcel to re-deliver to the next hotel that i was staying. IMPRESSED! Rooms are spacious too as comapre to many other hotel in tokyo. Breakfast options are great!

This is the second Shangri-la that I tried in a short time, and I am impressed. Our room was a Horizon Club room, therefore we took advantage of the club floor lounge and of the special treatment. We arrived very early in the morning, but our room was ready and we could check-in directly in the room. All the staff was super friendly and careful to attend to every need. Breakfast in the lounge was excellent. Our room was very comfortable, with all the amenities you expect in a hotel of this caliber. Location is adjacent to the humongous Tokyo station, and at walking distance from the Imperial Palace and to Ginza. Definitely to reccomend

Back to Shangri La Hotel in Tokyo and this is like the second home to me. Everything was perfect as usual, and the staff was taking care of things to the finest details. Truly enjoyable experience and highly recommend.

Very comfortable and spacious room. Great location and even better service.Nothing was too much trouble for any of the staff. All immaculately clean .The Spa and treatments were very spoiling .Only slight criticism was that my room overlooked the station and you could hear the trains despite being quite high. On my return, I will ask for a room on the other side of the hotel.Definitely recommended

At the end of a month travelling independently around Japan, we finished up with a five day stay at the Shangri-La. We had read so much about Tokyo and it's huge range of hotels, so for our first visit we decided to treat ourself to a stay in this wonderful hotel. The location at Tokyo Station proved to be excellent, with access to transport very easy ( once we understood the metro system). There were many restaurants around for those times when we didn't want to venture far. The room was huge, with massive bathroom, comfortable lounges and chairs, very very comfortable bed, great view. On the last night we actually cancelled another hotel room prior to our flight out so we could stay another night at the Shangri-La. Perfect, we had a couple of drinks in the bar, fantastic view, but rather expensive, but who cares? Would stay there again. Great service, typical Japanese as the staff couldn't do enough for you. Absolutely immaculate. Can't wait to go back to Tokyo.

We stayed in this hotel several time and am glad trip advisor put it as number 4 in whole of Tokyo. First it is so near Daimaru, and Tokyo station and also near to subway station. And the rooms are big comfortable. I used the swimming pool and the steam bath, it is immaculously clean. The bathrobes are soft and warm to wear after the swim. The breakfast can improve a bit. The concierge can improve also, my son asked the concierge to book a jazz place on Saturday the lady was not helpful. An excellent hotel will know how to recommend places for us to visit.

Stayed on club level 36 in the deluxe king room 3607 looking down Tokyo station and Imperial garden. The Horizon Lounge provides cocktail, wine, champaign, beer and some food at cocktail time, they were very good. The room was spacious and super clean, luxury furnished. I was glad found the amenity has changed into Bvlgari. We took breakfast at restaurant 'Piacere', this was wonderful. This stay was for our 10th anniversary, we had a heartful message card from hotel and they helped us for the best before the stay.Club floor is not cheap, but it's worth every penny. Specially recomend the breakfast at Piacere.

This is the third time I stay in this hotel, the manage hand written a note to welcome us. It makes us feel kind of special. They also give us good fruits. Some hotel gives us fruits like kind of left over. Shangarila gives us good seasonal fruits, it seem like the hotel is meticulous about small details. No wonder the rating of this hotel is so high. I love the orchid besides the bed. Shangrila has beautiful orchids all over the world. The hotel is near the train station so it is very convenient. When we arrive the hotel it is kind of late so we walked out to Daimaru for dinner. We love to visit this hotel again for our next travel. The hotel is immaculately clean, i felt refreshed once I entered the hotel after our Fukuoka golfing trip.

Everything was simply perfectly I cannot fault it.Very attentive staff. Nothing is too much trouble. Rooms are superb and very clean. Perfect heaven in such busy city.This hotel is positioned very well. You can explore with ease.Food in the restaurants is excellent. If you like Japanese, please op for that. Their Italian was good but not as good as in Italy. Perhaps I am being overly critical here.Highly recommended hotel. Will return without any doubts.

The Shangri La Tokyo is not cheap, but is a great base for exploring this exciting city. Easy walking distance from TOKYO station, the lobby is actually on Floor 28, with a small entry foyer only on the ground floor. Rooms are very comfortable and the breakfast service excellent. We had dinner here once (at their Japanese offering) and found it a bit disappointing, but otherwise a great place to stay

Wonderful hotel! Staff very helpful! I had a butler who did everything to help and to provide anything as soon as possible. The concierge was also very helpful. The breakfast buffet was very nice and the breakfast in the room also top! The bar/restaurant in the lobby were fantastic and the view from the city wonderful!They have a very good Italian restaurant and of course a Japanese restaurant that were worth having dinners there!I do recommend anyone to stay there!

Stayed at the Shangri-La for 4 days, and left with a clear understanding of the differences between 4, 4.5 star pretenders, and 5 star properties. They really nailed the first impression; from the warm greeting, to the elevator to the sky lobby, to the simple check in, to the thoughtful snack plate laid out in the room (very useful after a 12 hour flight). Of course, the bed was comfortable, the view from the 36th floor unmatched. From there, the little things begin to make a bigger impression; the thick, wooden hangers; the multi-functional coat stand, the electronics kit allowing all manner of devices to sync with the BOSE sound system.Beyond the room, service from the multi-lingual staff was exceptional. Every need was met, and no questions were left unanswered. The pool/fitness area was like a mini-resort in the middle of Tokyo; much appreciated considering the humidity during my stay.Finally, the breakfast at Piacere was great. Planned on doing it once, ended up having it on multiple days. There's nothing quite like having an extravagant breakfast while overlooking the Japanese Imperial gardens; truly memorable.

The hotel is very beautiful, but its location is not the best when you are on vacations and in case you don't need to take the Narita Express, JR or Shinkansen trains. Subway station is very far and there is nothing interesting to see around the hotel. I was staying one night and asked for a 2pm late checkout and they couldn't get it, but they offered a 1pm. Better than nothing, but the reception staff were not as nice as they could be when communicating that it wouldn't be possible - they were like whispering between them in Japanese... I didn't like that. The room was very good, but be careful with the 'Imperial Garden View' as the hotel is far from the Imperial Garden and you can barely see a green from the room... Also, I think they gave me a 'accessible room' and the bathroom was a single piece, without a separate shower. Also, the sink was very low... The breakfast was perfect as well as the service and food of the Piacere Italian restaurant (which is very beautiful and elegant). Great spa and and ok Gym. The windows at the pool area were dirty and so it was almost impossible to see the view... I think the hotel is very good, when in a business trip and if you want a easy access to trains (not subway).

Centrally located within walking distance to Ginza, Tokyo train station, Tokyo palace and many shops and restaurants. Excellent breakfast buffet and lounge on the lobby level as well as helpful friendly staff. Awesome gym facilities and pool.

We chose the Shangri-La Tokyo because of its central location next to Tokyo Station (we knew we would be travelling from there a lot),the reviews here, and the rooms we saw on their website. The Shangri-La offers a service where they will meet you at the Tokyo Express Station from the Narita Express train since it is impossible for a tourist to find the right exit since it is a 10-15 minute walk in the station. We emailed the hotel with our train time and car # when we bought our train tickets at the airport.As soon as we got off the train we found our escort/guide from the hotel who was very nice and took us and a bunch of our bags threw the maze that is Tokyo Station. He was very nice and helpful and led us to the 37th floor where there was a special dedicated check-in area for guests staying in Horizon Club rooms as we were. I did want to quickly get to the room and take a shower after our long journey so the 5-10 minute wait to check in was a little annoying but there were snacks and beverages in the lounge which helped The staff was very accommodating and pleasant. I had booked via Amex Fine Hotels and Resorts and asked about a room upgrade. They told us one was available but it was a smoking room and a smoker had just checked out that day so we passedThe room itself (Horizon Club Deluxe Bay View) was beautifully styled, a very nice size with a great view. The bed was very comfortable and room was quiet The only glitch was the lighting controls on different side of the beds were not working quite properly - one set only turned off the lights and one only turned them on - we were able to cope with this minor issue.We had breakfast each morning in the Horzion Club Lounge which was very peaceful and never crowded but with a dedicated staff of 4-5 who made us feel very welcome each morning. The menu was diverse with Western egg options and Japanese choices along with a buffet of breads, fruits and the BEST PASTRY I HAVE EVER EATEN. It was essentially a cronut but far better than the ones sold here in NYC. The orange juice was also delicious although I am not sure why all beverages were filled only halfwayWe used the concierge to book some tickets to a very popular art show. The first person we encountered did not know the details well but then the official concierge gave us the right information and got us tickets.The wi-fi was free and high speed - one of the best in a hotel I have been toAll in all our stay at the Shangri-La made our trip Tokyo comfortable and luxurious
user_name:
eddielouie9892
New York City, New York

review_body: This is the best hotel ive ever been, and ive traveled alot, the rooms are amazing, the view, food, the spa could be ranked the best in the world, pricy but worth every single penny, definately recommend it, had an amazing stay, everyone talked english, maps for everything.

The Shangri-la accommodation was a highlight of our Tokyo holiday. We were welcomed at the train station off the Bullet Train by the concierge and guided to the hotel, and efficiently registered and taken to our room. The rooms were fantastic, stunning views and highly appointed.We did not eat dinner at the hotel, preferring to interact in local restaurants around the area, however the breakfasts were extremely nice.Overall the staff and service were outstanding throughout the hotel... Apart from the house bar where the service was terrible, taking over 20 minutes to get each of our two drinks. Needless to say we didn't bother with that again.We thought the hotel location adjacent to the Tokyo station was a real feature, we travelled on the train all the time.

Service standard were not consistent. Upon check in some staff were warm and friendly while some were cold and impersonal. Room was huge, opulent and luxurious but that was expected considering the price that is charged. I was a little disappointed in the location.
