Although it is located next to Tokyo station, it's quite a long walk to the main train lines that would get you to the common sights. My husband and I stayed at the Shinjuku area previously and we're probably used to the superb location and easy access to sights. We however found a gem of a yakitori place just a short walk into the station beside the hotel. Small little place full of office workers with lots of character. Do go and try if you're staying here.The hotel was nice enough to keep our luggages while we went to Mt Fuji for a night before coming back again.

Stayed here on business for 4 nights with a mix of limiting factors and some real positives. Check-in was far from smooth, and I still don't understand how some rooms can be both smoking "and" non-smoking; some people have allergies and sensitivities to cigarette smoke, so if a guest smokes in a room, then it should be categorized as smoking, no exceptions. Both sides of the hotel have good views - one is of Tokyo station and Marounouchi with glimpses of The Imperial Palace, the other is of Tokyo Bay and the Sky Tree, but the key point is that the check-in staff should not propose what view they or the hotel believes to be the best but rather ask the guest their preference. A la carte service at breakfast was hit and miss, and over the course of our stay several of us experienced long waits of 30 to 40 mins for eggs at Piacere. Having said that, the quality of the food and general level of service in all the hotel outlets was extremely good, and the piano bar in the lobby lounge is very relaxing. The rooms are excellent, particularly the refreshing rain shower and the super comfortable bed. Also enjoyed the location in Nihonbashi right next to Tokyo Station, and a short walk to Ginza and Marounouchi. A hotel porter will meet you at, or escort you to, the platform if arriving or departing by train - a nice touch. Nearly all taxi drivers know the hotel. One staff member that I would like to specifically mention is Handa-San in the club who was first rate. Summing up, a great hotel that I would definitely return to, but would recommend easing up a little on the formalities and prioritize on the primary objectives of most guests utilizing a hotel. Thank you.

Stayed in the horizon club Bay view room for 3 days.. had a fantastic view of the city (tokyo sky tree) and part bay area. Spend every night watching the skyline in out room.The lounge was fantastic! Service was great and is not crowded at all. Breakfast variety is close to what was offer at the main breakfast area. Only lounge so far was to not ask your name when going to the lounge as they knew your name and room number area!! such attention to details!!Rang for cardboxes for EMS as we done alot of shopping, guess what they appear within 3 mins and brought us different size of boxes for us to use!The service is excellent. They will make sure u get to the place you intend to go (if u take a cab they will speak to the driver in japanese).In one word. Perfect. Hard to beat on the details to put in to ensure your stay is perfect.

This hotel is way up on our list of our favorites in the world. We stayed there in May when we ended a cruise in Tokyo. We arrived at about 10:30 a.m. and our rooms were ready. The service at Reception set the tone for our stay. The friendliness and helpfulness of the staff were fantastic. They made every effort to fulfill what really was an unreasonable request on our part. We asked them to try to find a private guide for us for the next day which was a national holiday. They tried until late in the evening and were extremely apologetic when they couldn't find one for us. The rooms were amazing and every amenity was supplied. In addition to kimonos we were also given wonderful pajamas. The bathroom was the nicest we have experienced. The hotel is located in a great area. A very short walk to the Imperial Gardens and to the Tokyo Central station. The food in the hotel was excellent and the breakfast buffet had a array of great choices. Any time we left the hotel, we were given a little card which had our destination written in Japanese along with the name and address of the hotel. This gave us a sense of security in a country where we could neither read nor speak the language. What I will remember most about this hotel is the staff. From the moment we checked in, they remembered our names and we were always greeted personally when we stopped by Reception. I would not hesitate returning to this property.

In big cities we always love to stay in a hotel with a Horizon club, the rooms located on that floor always have private check-in and a lounge where only the guests staying on this floor can have breakfast and there are snacks and drinks available all day.A perfect way to start or relax after a busy day in the city.The rooms are perfect, luxurious and service is great!Location is fantastic. You can safely walk to the Ginza shopping area with nice restaurants and also the train station is nearby.Loved it and we will definately stay here again!

Everything youve heard is right! The beeakfast was dreamy and the staff was very nice. Be sure to have dinner at the tipanyaki resturant. You wont regret it.One thing is easy to notice is the many nice artworks in the hotel.

From the moment we arrived, the staff could not have been more friendly. The hotel is is excellent condition, is well located just at Tokyo Central Station and has great facilities including an up to date pool and gym. We bought train tickets back to Narita and were escorted, at no extra charge, by hotel staff all the way to our train. It was an excellent touch and made such a memorable impression.

The Shangri-la is an amazingly beautiful hotel. The staff is phenomenal - will go out of their way to help you. Point in case, I asked the concierge which train to use to get to the Edo-Tokyo museum and instead of providing me a map, he walked me to the train! (Tip: hotel staff will pick you up on the platform at the train station when you arrive from Narita and will take you to the platform and drop you off for your return train ride to the airport.)The rooms are huge for Tokyo and completely staffed with anything you might need. Breakfast room service is fantastic. And I loved how close the hotel was to Tokyo central train station. My home away from home was the Starbucks just inside the train station. Love Tokyo and love the Shangri-la!!

Great central location next to Tokyo station. Extremely attentive service from English speaking staff. Large rooms and great amenities. Gym and pool small but nice. Breakfast buffet was amazing and included full a la carte menu items. Highly recommend!

Whether it's after a 1 in 25 year snowstorm in February, or after climbing Mt. Fuji in July. Or after a rigorous business meeting or after a long trans-Pacific flight, the Shangri-la has proven to be the sanctuary amid the overwhelming city of Tokyo. Upon entry, you are immediately enveloped by the trademark Shangri-la essence. Unlike other Shangri-la's, this hotel is small, intimate and occupy the higher floors for panoramic views. The staff make it a point to greet you by your name and welcome you as if you're in a ryokan. The bed and amenities provide you with much needed relief. Breakfast at Piacere and dinner at Nadaman take your senses to new levels of delight. And oh yes, it's next to Tokyo station - a starting point to get to any place in Japan, or the world.

Stayed here at the end of our Ski holiday for a few nights and was a perfect way to relax in luxury. Can not speak highly enough of this hotel......it's location, rooms, and staff were all totally amazing. Would highly recommend staying here if you want a little luxury. Soaking the day away in the amazing tub was just fantastic. The turn down service was a lovely added extra with the little things like the bookmarks with beautiful inspirational sayings left on your pillow. The Shangri-La certainly knows the true meaning of service and luxury.

The hotel is easily a six star property with excellent service! Convenient location, wonderful staff. Especially Mr Takayuki Yoshioka who is an extremely knowledge concierge and recommended great places

Hotel is conveniently located at Tokyo station which is great for subway travel. There are many shops in the Tokyo station underpass including a Ramen street. The room was comfortable and clean. I didn't like the bathtub shower. There was no standing shower option. While the hotel staff were generally polite and helpful, I did not find consistency in the concierge's service level. At times, it was good and gave useful recommendation which I really appreciated. But I encountered poor service on a few occasions. I couldn't be sure if they were the actual concierge staff or just counter staff standing in. Regardless, I do expect a level of professionalism and ability to provide recommendation service. And in those instances, I was very put off by the attitude and aptitude. The gym was very small and very dim. It was kind of eerie using it late at night as it was so dark. The walkway outside the rooms was also very dim.

The shangri-la Tokyo is not a cheap hotel but neither is it a very expensive one. It's very conveniently located right next to Tokyo main station which means having the convenience of all the shops and food establishments if you don't want to walk too far. It's also a short walk to the Ginza district which would have been pleasant if not for the extreme heat! If you're not used to Japan, the greetings on arrival might be a bit strange as everyone bows to you even after you have got I to the lift. This is very nice once you are used to it and now feels so strange when I am back home and nobody does it! You are made to feel special even before reaching the reception and so much attention is paid to you at the g/f lobby.Now, again if you've stayed in some hotels in Japan, quite a lot of them have small rooms even at higher prices. For around the average price you would pay in Europe I got a room about 2/3 the size of my house(my house isn't too big!). All the amenities are there for you so you really don't need to bring even a toothbrush. Also being at least on the 29th floor give as an excellent view of the city especially at night.The service was excellent and very discreet. Things are always there for you most of the time without even having to ask. Anticipation of needs I believe. The overall experience was very good coupled with the fact that it is very centrally located for walking and for transport links. Would highly recommend(for the price range)

Adjacent to Tokyo Station - which is huge with miles of underground walk ways.No problems checking in at 1pm. Beautiful room. Spacious with great views & expected accessories - with the exception of a iron for some reason.One small gripe, turn down service was incredibly early. Before 5 pm one evening.Fantastic breakfast selection in the restaurant.Definitely good for some pampering if you want to splash out during your stay in Tokyo.

This is the second time I stayed at this premises, and I fell love over and over again. If you are looking for a business hotel, then, this is an excellent choice. The location couldn't be more strategic, its next to the Tokyo Station, in Marunouchi district. Train from Narita is very fast. Just let them now that you are coming and they will assist you right away from the time you step-off the train.The lobby is on 28th floor. I like the smell of the hotel. Its very relaxing. As for the room, it' huge. It's modern and has all the amenities that you would expect from a 5 stars hotel.The only criticism is the room has no walk-in closet. Its just a wardrobe cabinet, opposite to the bathroom area. The spa, gym and pool is on the 26th. Love the pool. The gym is OK size and quite well equipped. Love the sauna and whirlpool . It has jet showers that massaging you from many directions :)But the most satisfactory is it's staff. They are very helpfull and efficient and polite. They always give me the best advice should I need one. Really satisfied!The F&B is also excellent quality. Really is a great service!

What an amazing hotel! Incredible service, delicious breakfasts, heavenly indoor pool and spa amenities, etc. While traveling in Tokyo in July heat, Shangri-La was our beautiful and calm haven to help us relax and restore our energy for touring this dazzling city. With three full days to tour Tokyo, we needed to move. Although the hotel appears to be located in a business section, having easy access to Tokyo Train Station and local subways made it worthwhile. (Then again, we were a mere one mile from fashionable Ginza.) If you're like me and you notice smells, you will find that the hotel fitting your olfactory needs, especially in a city that has not heeded the no-smoking mantra of California. We liked the scent so much so that we even purchased their room spray and reed diffuser. One little nit-picky issue, since all else was impeccable: They need to clean certain areas of their carpets. Yes, we will return to this wonderful hotel and their other venues, if given the chance.

My job takes me to Tokyo about once a year -- there is no place I would rather stay than the Shangri-la. Located conveniently walking distance from both Tokyo station (where the Narita express arrives) and the financial/commercial center, everything you could need is easily within walking distance of the property.The hotel is located on the upper floors of an office building, meaning you are well insulated from the hustle bustle of the city streets. Each room is well appointed, with a particularly unique and large bathroom -- the bathroom features a "shower room" with the shower and tub behind a closed door (meaning if you wanted, you could technically try and fill the tub with water from the shower). Likewise, the room itself (i had a basic king sized room) is generously sized, with a nice couch/sitting area located along the window wall, complete with small table for a drink/snack.When travelling on business, all I really need is convenient location, a good night's sleep. and good food available at the hotel should I choose not to venture out for the evening -- the shangri-la offers all 3. while i have not stayed at the various other hotels located in a similar city area, i have no interest in staying at any of them as the shangri-la has been nothing short of excellent during my visits to the Tokyo city center.
user_name:
jpg28242
New York City, New York

review_body: I wanted to find a great hotel where we would not be bothered by cigarette smoke (my husband is allergic), so we ended up at the Shangri La. What a great choice (unless you are on a budget, which we decided not to be because we were celebrating).The hotel is right next to the Tokyo station, with a small but nicely appointed street level lobby where you are immediately directed to a fast elevator to the 28th floor. There you find the actual lobby with a couple of restaurant (we had a delicious, although very expensive, breakfast at Piacere). Our room was on the 35th floor. The room was very nicely appointed, with a spectacular bathroom (the walk in shower/bath is to die for) and all the stuff you might have forgotten to pack, including slippers and pijama. It is also spotless and very, very quiet.If there is anything you need (e.g. iron), they will bring it up within a minute. Service is excellent, and staff has the best English we found in our two weeks trip. Overall, location and the quality of service and of the room make this hotel an absolutely excellent, if not economical, choice for visiting Tokyo.

We had a fabulous room with view on Tokyo Station and the park of the Imperial Palace. Amenities are excellent (including firtness center and pool), the staff is superb, the food outstanding (great breakfast buffet and at the Italian restaurant they had a French chef for the night we went to eat there who did e special dinner - perfect). Staff was very friendly, particularly at the Italian restaurant. There is really nothing negative that I could think of.

The lobby is not large; it is located on the 28th floor of Marunouchi Trust Tower. But it is well appointed. The beautiful golden artwork behind the check in counter got my attention, as well as many other Oriental artwork around the hotel.The room (we stayed at the Imperial Garden View deluxe room) is huge, bright and nice. The bathroom, with separate toilet area, is especially large, which is a rarity in this city. The furniture are not obtrusive. They are well placed and functional. Attention to little details must be complemented, e.g. extra towels, clothes steamer, black-out blind, etc. The bed is plush and comfortable, ensuring sound sleep at night. The gym is not big, but well equipped with modern equipments. The attendant places a bottle of water and fresh towel, and clean the equipments diligently after each use. It is adjacent to an indoor pool and changing facility that houses a jacuzzi and dry sauna.Breakfast buffet is served the lobby lounge and at Piacere Italian restaurant. The spread is not extensive but everything is well prepared and delicious. You can order various egg items off the menu, in addition to traditional Japanese breakfast bento and Chinese congee set. The restaurant offers seasonal, local ingredients to complement the menu. The other restaurant at the hotel is Nadaman, which is a part of an upscale Japanese restaurant chain. While the menu might be the same with other Nadamans in the city, this one offers eating in unique ambiance, surrounded by Oriental artworks.

Well located next to Tokyo station with the best service you can expect. Wifi in the room and all set of plugs and cables for computer to make it easy when traveling for business. Everything is done for you to feel comfortable. Good service at the conciergerie.

Our stay at Shangri-La in June 2014 was unforgettable. Location is perfect, and our room was so beautiful! We particularly enjoyed the lovely bar lounge and excellent breakfasts. I couldn't believe being met on the train platform by a beautiful lady in uniform who led us through the crowd to the hotel. We had not requested this service but because the concierge arranged our train travel, it happened. The best advice I can give is "Use this concierge!" It will be well worth the gratuity you will surely want to leave behind.

The first thing to say is that this hotel is both beautiful and in a central, convenient location of Tokyo. Having said that, for a five star hotel and for its price, it just didn't take my breath away. I was expecting luxury and instead, I found a very corporate environment where staff were as polite as they needed to be but didn't make any effort to go above and beyond. My husband and I told the hotel that we were staying there on our fourth wedding anniversary, and yet we didn't even receive so much as a card in our room! For anyone else who has ever stayed in luxury hotels, you'll know that generally a hotel will go above and beyond giving anything from cakes to flowers to cards and special romantic meals in the hotel restaurants. We stayed there for twelve nights and it was only a couple days before we were due to check out that we received a note through our door asking us if there was anything extra they could do for us as we were staying for such a long time. I think generally they are used to only short stays, and from businessmen. That was certainly the vibe we got--everyone seemed to be there on business, probably because of the area. There weren't the niceties or personal touches of luxury stay. On one occasion, our room wasn't cleaned at all and there were no fresh towels when we got back from a long day in the city-- they said that we had our 'no disturb' sign on, when we clearly had not. One morning we were woken up at 7:25AM by a fire alarm, which shouted that there was a fire on the 35th floor. This went on for about 15 minutes. We were heavily jet-lagged, panicked and quickly grabbed our passports from the safe and threw on our clothes from the day before, running to the lift to get out of what we thought was a burning building. When we made it down to the lobby the staff were standing around with big grins on their faces and told us that a hotel guest had pulled the alarm by accident. As it wasn't peak season and I believe all guests were being kept on just three or four floors, why hadn't they sent someone up to each floor, just to stand by the lifts to put guests at ease and tell them everything was ok and to go back up to their room? All of the guests were in a blind panic, and the staff were just standing there as if nothing at all was happening. It was incredibly irritating and the only apology was, again, a note put through our door later that evening. The TV remote didn't work. The light in the bathroom flicked constantly, which we told the concierge about, but it was never fixed. It stayed faulty for the entire 12 days. We paid for a garden view, but our room actually overlooked a train track. I could see a corner of the imperial palace garden, but only with binoculars. This was very misleading on their website.The pool/gym facilities only stay open until ten in the evening. For anyone expecting a pool with views of the city, this isn't it. It was a very small pool with lanes set up, very much for fitness and definitely not a pool for lazing around in or enjoying views over the city. Just being honest! Everyone else seems to think the service here was great--really wish I had experienced the same. I'm not incredibly picky, but I do stay luxury 5* everywhere so that I feel I'm a bit of an expert in this area. I give Shangri-La a three because you don't remember necessarily everything about a trip, but you do remember how the hotel staff made your feel. And Shangri-La only made me feel 3*.

Once in a while, you need to pamper yourself. Spend one or two nights at this beautiful luxury hotel, it’s worth every penny! Needless to say, spacious room with large window, comfortable bed and breathable quilt, conveniently located right next to the North Yaesu Exit. If you are arriving using the Narita Express, don’t forget to make use of their concierge service. By appointment, their staff could meet you at the Narita Express platform and take you and your luggage to the hotel! Will I go back? Yes!

Undoubtable quality and service as all Shangri-La hotel has. Also near to Tokyo station. The front desk is helpful and warm, also is staff in Picere restaurant. Several staff can speak mandarin. Good internet.

Top of the treeA big upsize surprise. The one side of the hotel has building works and so I believe these rooms for the moment are out of action. I was not that happy with my room as I wanted a view of the city and mentioned this to the concierge, when he ask me how is everything? Boom bang wallop and the room manager comes to see me and without any problem they moved me. No hesitation, deviation, or repetition. It was done in just a minute. This Tokyo branch cares about service and I was very impressed. The rooms are lovely and it very close to the station. The station is a stones throw away but very complicated. So phone the concierge when you on the Narita express they will come and get you. The train is all reserved seating and hence you tell them your carriage and at the station at your carriage the hotel experience starts. Highly recommend.

It was excellent from the meet and greet from the platform of the train station till sent off at the same platform. I was greeted in person by the guest relations manager at the entrance of the hotel, and we completed check-in process at the room, even it was 9am in the morning. The room is spacious and comfortable, it has all the things I would need or more. The location is perfect with train connection to all parts of Tokyo and Japan.
user_name:
Tee Wee J
Hong Kong, China

review_body: The front office team of the hotel, especially the concierge, are amongst the best I have ever had the pleasure of engaging. The rooms were spacious with stunning views of the city. The location right above Tokyo Station was great for traveling around Tokyo and beyond. Thank you for a wonderful holiday in Tokyo!

The hotel is in a tower located just above Tokyo Station. Arriving from the Narita airport is a bit tricky to find it but hotel offers a complimentary escort service right from the train platform to the hotel. All you need to do is notify the hotel in advance for the exact train and time of arrival.Lobby is on the 28th floor and all guest rooms are above, which means that you definetly have a room with a view. Staff is very attentive, cordial and helpful. Rooms are spacious, with big marble bathrooms and warm colours. Location of the hotel is great, very central, in the business area, a 10 min walk from Ginza.

I stayed here for three nights for business and had a great experience. This is my second time staying at this hotel and I can easily say that I will return as often as I can, even for leisure. The rooms are very large by Tokyo and even Hong Kong or Singapore standards, and the decor is calm, muted and pleasant which is what you want to face after a full day of business meetings. I had a chance to try out the pool and gym this time and it was very relaxing swimming in an indoor pool, looking out at the lights of Tokyo. Breakfast was not included in my rate and is quite expensive at Y3,900 per person at Cafe Piacere - however the quality is amazing. Wifi can sometimes be a bit "on-off" but this was not a major headache for me.The location is right above Tokyo Station so coming in by the Narita Express train is no problem, and if you're flying in by Haneda, it's even closer. I recall it took me less than an hour from getting off the plane to entering my hotel room! And of course, being above Tokyo Station is a boon for those who love food because there are endless choices at the ground floor and even more in B1.

My husband and me like Shangri-La Tokyo so much that its name pops up every time we think of visiting Tokyo. Though right in the central city, apart from convenience to everything like shopping, imperial garden, restaurants and train service, it also gives you a resort experience. Right entering the hotel, we feel like shut out from the hustle and bustle of the city and ready for relaxation of body and mind. Food at Nadaman and Piacere, Chi Spa, Horizon Club facilities are all of first class standards. Staff speak good English and always do their best to serve. Each stay will just make our appetite for staying there again stronger.We want to thank the General Manager, Mr Jens Moesker, for his warm hospitality. You have a good team, congratulations!Mr and Mrs Liu

We had a very pleasant stay for two nights. We were greeted in the lobby with a warm welcome and guided to our room for an effortless in room check in. The room was very spacious with the usual Shangri-La charm, and every amenity and small detail have been thought out well which made for a very comfortable stay. We stayed on level 37 in a Horizon Bay View Room which had a great view of Tokyo, but very limited view of the actual bay that was quite a distance away filtered behind other buildings. The only negative comment is that maybe the room name need to be updated, if you like water views and book a "Bay View" room because of it’s name, do not expect to see much of the actual the bay. The Horizon Club lounge provided a great place to sit back on enjoy the view, relax with nice glass of wine and very fine food between 5:30pm and 7pm. The Horizon Club Level cost a little more but I highly recommend it to enhance your stay.

Top location right outside the central railway station makes it so easy to access any destination. The famous Shangri-La service is exceptional. Make time to check out the art collection just walking around the hotel.

My wife, daughter and I stayed for 3 nights in this great Hotel and enjoyed it thoroughly. ShangriLa always delivers on service and facilities and this location represents the brand very well. The Horizon Club room was well worth the extra cost. Location is great - central to everything and easy access to Tokyo Station. Breakfast was fantastic at both Piacere and the Club Lounge.

I wanted to be close to the station and the Shangri La certainly is. All that you would expect in this bracket and brand, especially the service. If I were being picky, the reception is at a counter bang in the middle of the lobby and other hotels sit you down in a side room with welcome refreshment. It's nothing to die in a ditch over, but it's something that others in this price bracket offer and is a more personalised touch. Spacious room with full amenities and great view.

Superb hotel, good situation (tokyo railway main station)Good view from almost all rooms, good service. A true shangri la hotelMrt at tokyo station Did not try the breakfast because i was rushing but lot of food stores at the station

After considering the Four Seasons, our travel agent suggested the Shangri-La instead. We were with our 14 yr old and 13 yr old children and enjoyed the convenience of connecting rooms. Rooms were spacious and well appointed. The entire staff was so helpful, gracious and accommodating. Gym was a nice benefit; not large but had all that we needed. Lap pool also. Enjoyed the breakfast buffet every morning and drinks every night at the lobby bar. We especially liked how convenient the Shangri-La is to Tokyo Station. We found it easy to make our way back to the hotel from our separate visits to Hakone and to Kyoto and to access the JR train lines to get about Tokyo. The kids loved exploring the train station and especially getting treats at the Daimuru food hall. They found it easy enough to train their way back to the hotel on their own from Shibuyu/Harajuku. Where else can we let our teens do that but in Japan? After staying there for 4 nights, it felt like home. Highly recommend!

We stayed for 5 nights (Split 4 and 1 after a side trip to Hakone) and had the kind of experience you would expect at a 5 star hotel. Rooms were spacious with impeccable furnishings and magnificent views of Tokyo, we could see all the way to the bay from our first room. The quality of the breakfast was as high as any of the luxury hotels I've stayed in around the world. Staff is outstanding and we utilized the escort service from Tokyo Station three times (this is one of the reasons I selected the hotel).

Shangri La is my favorite hotel chain and this one did not disappoint. Great hotel with the most wonderful rooms and service. Also, well situated next to Tokyo Hotel. The breakfast was delicious--a bit pricey, but well worth it. The front desk and the bell staff were very helpful and made the visit to Tokyo easy for a tourist.Definitely stay here
user_name:
kra m
New York City, New York

review_body: I have stayed in the Shangri-la Hong Kong and this one by Tokyo Station is not bad. Although it did not have that impressive atrium, it was a very elegant place especially with all those chandeliers. The room was impressive with a fantastic view. On the 32nd floor, I was able to see Rainbow Bridge and Odaiba. The bathroom was extraordinary. The one thing missing there is having a small tellie by the sink. Of course there could have been one in the other more expensive rooms. The 50000 yen room/night included breakfast buffet. The buffet was delicious and generous with lots of food and great service. But then, that should be expected. This is an upscale business hotel with practically no lobby. Can get crowded by the lounge area. Have to go to below ground floor to get a taxi. No problem because they always have one waiting for you.

This hotel was incredible. Everything was just so. I would particularly praise the service. The staff remembered us and our preferences. Most impressive was the fact that we left luggage while we traveled to Kyoto for 4 days. When we came back there was a big hello and the bag was already in the room by the time we got there. The location is also great since you are right by the Tokyo subway and rail hub so every time you go somewhere it is a cinch. In example, when you exit the train from the airport, you can walk in 2 minutes into the hotel. On and on - a great hotel.
user_name:
sbear1
New York City, New York

review_body: Second time staying here. Stayed 3 nights. Practically perfect business hotel. Location is wonderful. Service, etc is top notch. Only 1 complaint. The mattress is too soft and I get a bit of backache sleeping in it. Same problem as my previous stay. Suggest changing mattresses to slightly firmer ones.

Good hotel in a very good location 0n the 26th to 36th floors of Trust Building.. Rooms are spacious, with great views (superior room). Staff excellent. In-house Japanese restaurant excellent, but portions small.Beware of some concierge recommendations if you don't want to end up in a tourist restaurant.Great stay.

Our first trip to Japan was WOW thanks to our stay at Shangri-La hotel. This is by far one of the best hotels we have stayed in world-wide. All of the features in the room was just a finger-tip away. Par Excellent!

Great Location above the Tokyo Station, helpful staff with superb japanese hospitality, great amenities, Best available rate was way too pricy but guess they are priced due to demand and supply. Indoor Swimming pool great for winter but for summer outdoor is best!

My husband and I have stayed at quite a few hotels in both Yokohama and Tokyo, normally for extended periods of time.We are presently at this hotel for two weeks and from the moment we walked into the hotel, I was impressed. Firstly, my only criticism, and I mean my only one, is that despite my husband having spent a very extended time here before, we weren't given any kind of recognition for this. I think some kind of upgrade should have been offered as my husband, while he is on a business trip, is given a choice of hotels and decided on this one after a previous stay.The good points about the hotel are:The staff are never overwhelming. I have stayed in other hotels where you spend your life bowing back to staff. It can be quite exhausting!We were allowed access to the health club which is normally $50 a day here in Japan which is prohibitive for a long stay. The pool is spotlessly clean as are the hot tub and all the facilities.The beds are unbelievably comfortable and given the volume of visitors it is nice to have no second hand blankets and bedspreads which, in other hotels, have been stained with goodness knows what. Only sheets and duvet covers, all washable are provided.The TV system is very convenient with an HDMI plug in provided. A must in Japan for watching Netflix as there is little English TV.The rooms are quiet with triple glazing.The bathroom wall is glass with a remote blind so that with the blind up you can see through the whole room and this makes the whole experience much more spacious.The view over the palace gardens is lovely.The carpets are clean! At the Intercontinental in Yokohama (not a cheap hotel) the carpets were filthy and we were told they were too busy to get a window of opportunity to clean them. Not an acceptable excuse!The breakfasts on the room service menu are reasonably priced and arrive exactly on time. Important for my husband who commutes to Yokohama every morning.On that note, my husband chose and hour long commute so that we could stay in this hotel as opposed to a ten minute walk had we stayed in a hotel in Yokohama. He was really impressed with his previous experience.I am here for another ten days and am sure my stay will be really pleasurable.I would definitely recommend this hotel and look forward to my next trip!

An outstanding experience from the start to finish. Stunning room with fantastic views over the city. Perfect location for shopping and site seeing. Service was second to none but you would expect that level from a hotel of this standard.

stayed here for 2 nights. the location is fantastic with 2 mins walk from tokyo station.Room is spacious and comfortable. Staff are polite and helpful. Breakfast is delicious .The views is amazing .Downside: 1.deposit wasnot cancelled until I called the hotel ,it should not happen at this kind of 5 star hotels.2 very expensive.

Spacious, comfortable room with a glass wall overlooking Tokyo.Friendly and polite staff. Stylish bar with stunning views on Tokyo at night. Very clean. Centrally located: right next to Tokyo station, 20 min away from the fish market. Reminds you of the Lost in Translation movie.

This hotel is close to the Tokyo train station. You can walk easily from the bullet train to this hotel. If you let them know your arrival time, they will meet you there. The service is superb from start to finish. The location is near Ginza where you can find great shops and restaurants. The concierge desk will help you if you want to travel by subway which is easier than you might think. the breakfast is great in keeping with the high standards of Shangrila. there is some construction in front of the building which makes the entrance not as clear as it might be when it is completed. The hotel is on the upper floors so you have great views of Tokyo no matter on which side you are located. Its a bit a of a trip to shinjuku but you can do it by subway without any problem.

True 5* experience from the ever helpful staff through to the outstanding food and club rooms.We were met at our train carriage itself! and escorted to check in within the horizon club. As it was our wedding anniversary they provided complementary wine in our rooms. The entrance to the hotel is not obvious but adds to the charm as you feel you are entering a secret invitation only establishment.

Flawless hotel, lovely view, my children were made welcome, the concierge booking system for the Narita Express seamless, the room lovely, especially the bathroom, the bar gorgeous and classic, staff were warm. Only downside was that the beds were too soft!

From arrival to departure our stay was excellent, the staff attentive and acknowledgeable, the room wonderful, food great, location perfect. With my husband working I was on my own, a little worried to be in a strange city but my stay in this hotel helped me on my way.

We normally stay at the Peninsula Hotel in Tokyo, but since we heard rave reviews about the Shangri-La in Tokyo, we decided to give it a try. The customer service is impeccable, as is the overall aesthetics of the hotel. Although the room design is not as elegant as the Peninsula, I loved the bathroom layout and the overall more intimate feel of this boutique hotel. Looks like we have a winner with the Shangri-La!!

Stayed May 10-13 inclusive. Had good experiences with various Shangri La hotels throughout Asia, so wanted to see if this compared to others we had stayed in Tokyo (such as Hyatt, Hilton, Peninsula). Upshot - exceeded expectations. Room was great - corner on the Horizon floor with top notch amenities (Bvlgari and Nespresso which was promptly refilled), wonderful assortment of goodies as a welcome gift. As I had indicated we had a child of 5 as well, the hotel had provided special amenities for the little one such as little bedroom slippers, personal packs of shampoo, moisturisers, soap for kids, a kids toothbrush, the Shangri-La bears were a nice touch for her, and so on. It was unexpected. Fruit always available. The Horizon club did not disappoint and we used it extensively. They catered to your needs very well. The breakfast selection is good and specialised since we could order off the menu. As usual, the service impeccable and the staff always polite and very courteous - that's what I call service with a smile since they made you very welcome. The hotel reception is located on the 28th floor so it was a bit unusual in that we always had to take 2 elevators to get to the room. Being next to Tokyo station is great as that meant getting around very easy. Since we flew in via Haneda, the convenience of being at the Tokyo station becomes very apparent since we did not have to take too many trains to and fro (the monorail to the JR Line and vice versa). Hotel within easy walking distance to Ginza so that was convenient. Certainly I would say this was an extremely pleasurable stay and no doubt we would stay there again.

I stayed at the Shangri-La for two nights at the end of April. This was my first time in Tokyo so I can't speak about other hotels in the city. I can only say that when I return to Tokyo, my first choice will be the Shangri-La. The front desk staff was welcoming and efficient. Within a few moments, I was escorted to my lovely room (particularly appreciated after a twelve hour flight). The room was large with a very comfortable bed (pajamas supplied at evening turn down), a large closet, masses of storage space, a Nespresso machine and a gorgeous view of the city skyline. The bathroom with its large shower room, Japanese toilet and space was wonderful. I enjoyed the breakfast. It was varied and delicious. I ate a light dinner in the bar one night. The bar was busy but not noisy/crazy. Food was very good. If you really want to splurge, I recommend the Wagu Beef Burger--to die for. When I checked out, a front desk staff member accompanied me to my waiting taxi and made sure that the driver understood exactly where I needed to go. She waited, smiling and waving good bye, until the cab left the hotel. Wonderful experience.

I can't say enough to explain how beautiful this hotel is! This was my first time staying in a Shangri-la hotel and I immediately loved it. The location right on top of the Tokyo Station complex is incredibly convenient. When we first arrived at the station, it was a bit difficult to navigate our way to the hotel because of the vast size and the complexity of the busy station. Remember to look for the 'Nihombashi Exit' and you will be fine. The hotel was literally steps away from this exit. Although the hotel was housed in an office building on the upper floors, it had a dedicated ground floor lobby with express elevators to the main lobby.The hotel was beautifully decorated with a modern, contemporary feel. The only thing to fault was the size and scale of the main lobby. It just did not match up with the grand and luxurious feel of the hotel brand. I guess it's because of Tokyo's sky-high land value, especially in this very heartland of the capital. It might make better sense to understate the scale of the main lobby for the sake of efficient use of space. For the same reason, we initially expected the room to be matchbox tiny but we were wrong. We stayed at the 'Skytree view room' and we had no complaints! The size was spacious enough to put a king-size bed, a big lounge sofa, a large working desk and a huge bathroom. The bathroom had a separate tub and a rain shower. I love the view from my room. The Tokyo metropolitan cityscape from high above was mesmerising. We had buffet breakfast at the restaurant one day and american breakfast at the bar the next day. We had drinks in the hotel bar one evening. The service was top notch and the quality of the food and beverages was impressive. Staff members were warm, friendly and proactive to make our stay comfortable. We made the right choice to stay in this hotel and had a wonderful experience there.I will be happy to come back the next time I visit Tokyo.

Stayed here for a couple of nights in a Horizon Club premier room. Location was perfect and minutes away from Tokyo Station. Staff met us directly on the train platform on arrival and escorted us and our luggage to the hotel. On departure, we were also brought directly to the Narita Express train platform. In fact, we were a bit late on that day and we owe a big thank-you to Yuki who nearly broke her ankle running in her heels with us to the train platform all while dragging a couple of suitcases. The room was large with a nice view of Tokyo Sky Tree. The bathroom had a gigantic rain shower and a Japanese toilet that had more functions than the one at the Four Seasons. Blackout curtains, a comfy bed and pyjamas laid out for you at bedtime made for a great sleep. Breakfast was included with the Club room and you could have it delivered to your room if you wanted. WiFi was fast and free. The concierge was efficient at making restaurant reservations and booking bus and train tickets. The only flaw, and I'm really nitpicking here, is that while a Nespresso machine was provided, you had to pay for the coffee pods. The Four Seasons Tokyo and Swissotel Osaka provided free pods.

City view rooms are very nice. The location of the hotel is very convenient as you are in the trainstation in a coupple minutes after check out.Overall staying experience is very lovely and staff are very nice.I definitely recommend this hotel for your stay in Tokyo

My wife and I returned from a 3 week Asian vacation yesterday, which concluded with a stay at the Shangril-La. We came into Tokyo station on the Shinkansen express train from Kyoto after having mistakenly boarded the wrong train when we departed (an easy mistake to make and a story in itself). Nonetheless, the first sight that we encountered when the door opened was the smiling Shangri-La representative, who guided us and our luggage smoothly and efficiently thru the maze that is Tokyo Station. This much appreciated service had also been provided a week earlier when we had arrived at Narita on a red eye from Hanoi. This in itself, along with it's proximity to the station is almost reason enough to stay here. However, the story doesn't end there, as this is an absolutely topnotch luxury hotel. The hotel excels in every important dimension, including rooms, facilities (we loved the pool), food (excellent breakfast buffet), and most of all, the service. We've stayed in luxury hotels all over the world, but this place rates near the top of the list for graciousness and attention to detail. It also didn't hurt that during our initial visit our room was available immediately upon arrival at 9:00am, or that for our second stay of one night (prior to departure home) that we were upgraded to a stunning corner jr suite on the 35th floor, with a sweeping view over the Imperial Palace. This touch of opulence was just what we needed before facing the end of our vacation and the long flight back to Boston. This hotel is not inexpensive, but you certainly get what you pay for. We will definitely return here when we are next in Tokyo, and it will be a very easy choice to make.

Stayed four nights April 27-May 1, 2014. Regular king room. Spacious, comfortable. The staff all around could not have been nicer. The atmosphere is subdued, unobtrusive luxury. Prices for breakfast too high, and we did not have it included in our rate, so went to Starbucks in the Tokyo Station next door. "Escorted" service from the Narita Express when arriving in Tokyo Station priceless, especially if this is one's first trip to Japan.

My husband and I visited Tokyo at the end of a two week visit to Asia. The Shangri-La Hotel was the perfect resting finale to our vacation. The room and staff was very welcoming and comfortable. All our needs were anticipated without exception. The hotel was very well located for our needs, within walking distance to the Imperial Gardens, Ginza area and right next to the Tokyo Train station which made it convenient to the entire city attractions. My only complaint was that upon arrival we wanted a simple meal as it was late and we were tired from our travel. The concierge was unable to suggest a nearby casual restaurant that would cost us less than a couple of hundred dollars. Once we went to our room and I checked the internet I was able to locate several buildings in the Marunichi area that was 5 minutes walking distance and had several choices. Other than that the staff was most solicitous and satisfied every need.

After travelling around Tokyo and Kyoto for 9 days, we decided to stay the last two nights in Shangri-La. It was a great way to end our holiday in Tokyo - room was luxurious, spacious and our two kids just simply loved lazing in the room. The concierge staff were all very helpful and spoke excellent English. Excellent location next to Tokyo Station and using Nihonbashi exit, it is less than a minute walk to the hotel.

Great option for a nice stay at the city... Localization is great, in the central area of Tokyo, just by the train station and underground with restaurants, bars and shopping at walking distance.The bar is great and has an amazing view...Rooms and breakfast are great.Concierge service is very good - they try to support even in details such as getting bus tickets without any extra fee charged.

Stayed in the hotel 6 times, about 15 nights. Most comfortable location next to the Nihonbashi exit of the Tokyo station. The hotel occupies the top floors from 29 to 35 of an office building from where you always get magnificent views of Tokyo. The pool and gym are on the 29th floor facing the Koukyo (Imperial Palace). Friendly and helpful personal. Excellent guest room design with wooden walls and most comfortable bathrooms of the highest Shangri-La standards... Rather expensive but worth the pleasure you get staying there.

I stayed in this hotel for a out 6 to 8 weeks on and off while doing work in 2011 and 2012 and go back very regularly when I am in townI love the location over tokyo station. A few of my favorite ramen shops are on ramen st. Which is a close underground walk away. And my favorite isakayas in in the shin marounuchi building around the corner. Service is impeccable but that is almost defacto in tokyo and for shangrila. The rooms are nice and large. Breakfast has a nice mix of choices between Japanese and western style. The lounge is not as nice a place to chill out as the lounges at the peninsula and the mandarin but that is a minor quibble.

Not many hotel stay can rival the Shang in Ginza -- it's right next to Tokyo station, in the middle of Ginza, impeccable service, great view, amazing room! Room service even left PJ in our sizes (for adults) when they turned the beds. Our kids spens the whole time sitting next to the window gazing the skyline. A great stay to end our trip in Japan! Thanks to the Shang!

My partner and I recently stayed at this hotel and were unfortunate enough to call upon medical support during this stay. The hotel staff went above and beyond to provide care and extra services for my partner including the organisation of an english speaking doctor and extra late check out. Our sincere thanks to Yasushi Nagano and his staff for exceptional care and understanding during a difficult time for us.

After staying at many Shangi-La hotels over the last few decades this was one of the best. It's fairly new and next door to Tokyo Station with Ginza a few blocks away and Imperial Palace about four blocks. Outstanding service from everyone ... management and staff. Although I've had several trips on Japan subways they always took me to my platform if I asked, so no worries or stress. Bar and lounge are very nice and breakfast always a pleasure. I will always go back here when visiting Tokyo.

Great hotel - located just above Tokyo Station so it's really easy to get around and explore the city.We stayed for 6 days as a family with children. The hotel gave us a slightly larger room and an extra roll-away bed which helped and it was still more than enough for us.The breakfast buffet was physically small in size, but delicious and had more than enough choice. Service was impeccable as expected from this amazing hotel chain.As always, the Shangri-La provides top class service in a very professional manner. This is not a young and trendy hotel with a great party scene, but a great 5-star hotel with all the top notch creature comforts and service level from all members of staff.Be warned, if you are looking for a resort styled hotel with lots of activities for kids this is not the one. I am not sure how many you will find in the middle of Tokyo... We just used this as home base and travelled around the vicinity.

A rather small Shangri-la, but bin in terms of location and service. The rooms are huge for Tokyo, very elegantly furnished. Service is great, and the Concierge ist most helpful and get you anyting you want (inlcusing printing out everything including maps with adresses, because it seems the only english speakers in whole Tokyo are working at Shangri-la..) The Hotel is located next to the train/MRT station, which is an additional benefit. Spa is also outstanding.

My family and I have stayed in a few hotels in Tokyo before and I find that ShangriLa has the best location. We took a bullet train from Nagoya and the hotel was just right next to the JR Tokyo main station. No doubt the station is a very big one and the walk was probably about 10-15 mins but it was all mainly inside the station. From this hotel, we can take the Ginza line from the Nihombashi Station just a short walk away or the Tozai line from Otemachi station which is practically outside the hotel. Of course the JR line from the JR Tokyo station. However the Marunouchi line from Tokyo station is a bit far to walk which is on the other side of the JR station.The hotel is very luxurious. The room and the bathroom is big and comfortable. My husband says that the bed is very comfortable. I find that the pillows are a bit soft. I could have it changed I guess if I had requested. However I don't see a pillow menu in the rooms though. The lady at the concierge was very helpful when I asked her to confirm another accommodation in another city.Overall my family and I are very satisfied with the stay even though the rates are a bit expensive and on top of that the government has just implemented a consumption tax.We were very unlucky to have missed the cherry blossoms by a week. But we still see a few trees here and there.We will return for the cherry blossoms another year !

Hotel's are generally of a high standard in Tokyo and the Shang doesn't disappoint. The rooms are well appointed and relatively spacious by Tokyo standards.The location is excellent both for tourists and business alike. Service is excellent as again is the norm in Tokyo.Only gripe I would have is a pretty dull lobby bar which leaves you feeling rather flat. Beware the blackout curtains if you have an early meeting or make sure you have a loud alarm!

Very near greenery same time very near shopping 10 min walkingdistans bothalso rent a bike from hoteland go round very broad pavements and you can reach many attractions in Tokyou, also just by trainstation very convinient take trin from airport, car can take hours

During 10-18 April 2014, we (4 adults 2 children) stayed in this hotel twice (11-13 and 15-18). Overall, the hotel and staffs couldn't be any better (they treated us like they can read your mind) for example, my daughter look at the bear (its mascot I think) they gave us 2 bear on our bed at that night, or when we arrived at its lobby floor (28th) someone always keep the connecting elevator ready for us. Location was perfect, we could travel to anyway in Japan without to worry about how to get back to Hotel after arriving at Tokyo station because it located next door. And, I would like to use this chance to special thank Mr. Takahiro Mochizuki and Mr. Atsushi Shibata (Front office supervisor and manager). They helped us to get rooms with reasonable deal (after the booking canceled mistakenly by Agoda.com) without them we wouldn't have chance to checkin to Shangri la when we get back from Osaka on 15th April, Thanks again both of you sir.

a wonderful hotel, top class !A very nice room, large and complete bathroom a luxurious hotel with a large swimming pool.Service excellent, all was anticipated for my comfortunforgetable ! Can't come again in Tokyo without staying in this hotel

I have had the good fortune and pleasure of staying at this hotel on several occasions and of all the luxury hotels I have experienced, the Shangri-La stands out as the best experience. My family (wife and 2 kids) joined me on this trip and they all thoroughly enjoyed their stay. The location is perfect for exploring this magnificent city and after a long day's sightseeing, the hotel is the ideal place to return to.

This hotel cannot be faulted. It is in a great position next to Tokyo station. The rooms are beautiful - large and well equipped. The staff were professional, helpful, friendly and charming. I could not recommend it too highly.

All the great things that others have said about this hotel are all true. There is a great indoor pool. You will be lent a swimming cap. The water and room temperatures are just right. The pool must be about 25metres- so its good for lap swimming. There is also a great steam room, and hot tub. We tried a massage at the "Spa" and found the masseurs to be very skilled- compared to some other chain hotels we have stayed at. There is free high speed wireless internet in the rooms. We stayed in a Horizon club room, which includes lounge access. We were given the options of having breakfast in our room, in the lounge, or in the main hotel restaurant on the lobby level. We found that the menu was exactly the same in the lounge and restaurant- and very good too- but the Horizon lounge is more relaxed, more attentive, and has a better view. It rained a bit during our stay, - there were always umbrellas available for us at the door (with a smile of course!)It's a great hotel with great staff.

Stayed here four nights on a family trip to Tokyo. This is a high rise business oriented hotel. It is very nice but also very formal. The rooms are large and very well equipped. the staff is very friendly and helpful. The breakfast service was nice and the view excellent. I feel this hotel is a little stiff and not very warm. It is very nice and the staff is great but probably a little too fancy for my tastes. The location is nice as it is right by the main train station. This is good for transportation links but otherwise the area around the hotel is business oriented and relatively un-remarkable. Plenty of restaurants etc. in the train station, which is huge. I was a bit annoyed because we requested near or adjoining rooms for my kids and the best they could manage was a room at the opposite end of the hall. It was OK but I felt they could have done better to honor this request ahead of time. By the time we checked in, it they could not move us closer. Overall, a great choice in Tokyo.

Elegant hotel with beautiful, expansive rooms. Excellent service and conveniently located a few steps from Tokyo Station. Just as we expected from this high end hotel group - wish we'd had another night here.

I spent three nights at this hotel whilst on a tour of Japan. This was the first hotel we stayed at on our trip. They arranged a driver to meet us from the airport and whisked us to the hotel, stress free transfer, perfect after 12.5 hour flight from the UK.The hotel staff are incredibly helpful and friendly, the rooms are big enough and luxuriously appointed, the bathrooms are massive, large wet room style with huge 20" deluge rainfall type shower heads.Being on the 32nd floor the views are great.The hotel is in the business district and very much has a luxury top end corporate feel to it. This isn't a bad thing if you you want soft landing into Tokyo as they sort out everything for you and the places oozes quality and for me was perfect stress free start to my trip in a city completely new to me. Breakfast also worth mentioning, huge choice of everything.Waiting and bar staff remember how you like your food, drinks etc and it's all delivered in a friendly relaxed way.Staff to guest ratio feels right, whenever you need something there always seemed to be someone there ready to help but you never noticed or feel like staff are hovering. You're always addressed you by name and I don't think I was asked for our room number once, they are that on the ball. We had front of house speak to us at least once a day to check everything was ok and gave us useful tips and pointers on where to go. There are hallmarks throughout of an excellently run hotel. Small note; by Tokyo standards it's not expensive but coming from the UK it's definitely not cheap. We spent 3 nights, we dined one night in the hotel restaurant, hit the bar a few times and there wasn't much change out of £2.5k. I wouldn't hesitate staying here again.

From the great location to the flawless service the Shangri-La gets it right in every department. There is something beautifully understated about the hotel and the atmosphere. The simple elegance and refined surroundings are also reflective of the attitude of the staff to the guests. If you are looking for the vibrant glitzy buzzing lobby atmosphere of your traditional 5 star hotel this is not the place for you. Think of it as an incredibly discreet and well run luxury apartment with the additional aspects of service that a 5 star hotel can offer. Great breakfast on offer too!

we chose this hotel because we were arriving in from Osaka on the bullet train and this is above the station where they arrive in to. Also we were getting the airport train, the Nex (Narita Express) back a few days later and that train also leaves from Tokyo station right above the hotel so all in all it was a very convenient choice. Not the cheapest hotel in town but a lovely choice for the end of our Japanese holiday. It is more upmarket than we would usually choose but we thought we would treat ourselves. So a great end to a great holiday.

We spent a total of 5 nights at Shangari-La Hotel Tokyo during the Chinese New Year holidays. It was a very pleasant stay, as the rooms, staff and service, were as excellent or better compared to other Shangri-la hotels we have visited. We stayed in a Horizon Club Premier Room (i.e. corner room) on the 32th floor, where we were able to overlook Tokyo magnificently, as the room has two spacious windows since it’s a corner room. The room was well-equipped with coffee maker, Wi-Fi, mini bar, etc. The bed was very spacious and comfortable also. We had access to the exclusive Horizon Club Lounge on the 36th floor, where we frequent every late afternoon for a couple drinks and snacks before dinner. We really enjoyed the lounge, as it’s is very private and the service outstanding. In addition, all staff in the hotel spoke very good English and were professional. We also wandered down a couple times to the lobby lounge on the 28th floor. It’s also a great place to enjoy cocktails, beer and canapés. As the hotel is associated with an office building, there were quite a few professional Japanese folks talking business at the bar & lounge area. Because of the prime location of the hotel, we were able walk to local Japanese restaurants which served anything from ramen, noodles, & rice. However, we also had a very splendid romantic dinner at Piacere, which is the Italian restaurant in the hotel offering authentic Italian cuisine. During the dinner they offered Bellavista Brut champagne, a decadent chocolate cake and Nicolai Bergmann Designed Flower box. We were not able to eat the chocolate cake, as we had other dessert which was included in the set menu, however when we went back to our room after dinner, the delicious chocolate cake was sent by the staff to our room.We also had a chance to eat in the high-end in-hotel Japanese restaurant Nadaman. Everything from beef to seafood, wine and tea were splendid. You will definitely have to give it a try! What made our stay so special was the incredible service oriented staff Shangri-la Tokyo has. It all began the moment we stepped out of the airport, as Shangri-la staff were already waiting for us to escort us to the private car to the hotel. They were very patient and friendly when we were seeking suggestions for activities in Tokyo. You can feel and visual notice there’s a very strong management team running this hotel. In summary, a very memorable stay, and I would highly recommend Shangri-la Tokyo to anybody who plans a trip to Tokyo!

We chose horizon club room, the room was spacious, the service was 5stars rated, the club lounge was great with special check in and check out, staffs were friendly and extremely polite and helpful. The cocktail hours were great with good quality appetizers and good selection of wines and real Champagne.

Extremely convenient for Tokyo station but high enough to avoid any noise. This is a luxury hotel with all creature comforts and good service, as one would expect. The food is good and the rooms comfortable with everything you would wish for and need. But it's not a 'fun' place. There are probably much more exciting hotels than this one. Choose this if you are happy with a bed factory that truly works and you don't have to ask for anything twice.

For some years now I've been making the Mandarin Oriental my favorite end-of-trip hotel in Tokyo. It had become a tradition to stay there on my final night. However, the last time I stayed there I was disappointed in the service so decided to try something new. At the time I was making my plans the Shangri-La was above the Mandarin in ratings, and it was even closer to the Tokyo station, so I decided to give it a try. I was VERY happy that I did.To begin with, you are extravagantly greeted, both at the street level and the lobby level. The lobby is on a higher floor (I can't remember exactly on what floor it was, but it was quid lofty). I had joined their "Horizon Club" and was ushered into a nicely appointed lounge where I checked in. I had to wait a few minutes to be able to go to my room, but they could have left me there for hours because of the delicious snacks and unlimited supply of alcoholic beverages that were offered. After a very short wait, a very helpful and gracious staff member escorted me to a very large corner room which, although a bit smaller than the suite in which I usually stayed at the Mandarin, didn't seem at all small, and was indeed quite spacious, with a fantastic view of the city of Tokyo, with the Tokyo Sky Tree towering over the whole thing. I even had a good view of the aforementioned Mandarin. There were elegant snacks (fruit, etc) waiting for me, and the room promised a luxurious final place to rest before heading home. It featured a huge bathtub with a great view of the Tokyo skyline, and even had a "washlet" toilet which did just about everything automatically.I had maid arrangements to meet with friends at Piacere, the hotel's excellent restaurant, and we were given a "semi-private" table which, although not in a different room, was at least separated from the rest of the "madding crowd." The food, by the way, was top notch, and was appreciated by everyone. They even had my favorite gin!After lunch my friends left and I came back to my room to relax and enjoy the luxury of the place. Instead of traipsing around Tokyo, I just took the time to bask in the glory of this superb room. I was amused by the reading material in the room. In addition to a vast array of magazines, they also had, instead of the ubiquitous Gideon Bible, a copy of "The Lost Horizon" which, I understand, is a story about Shangri-La.The next morning I had a complimentary breakfast buffet at the Placiere restaurant, and it certainly met and exceeded any expectations I had. The buffet was totally superb and you could even order omelets and things like eggs benedict. Fabulous, and with a view of the Marunouichi area of Tokyo. I could even see another of my favorite hotels, the Marunouichi hotel. Anyway, this room was certainly fantastic, wonderful, luxurious, and since I can't come up with any other adjectives, supercalifragilisicexpedaliosious. To quote Disney. I highly recommend this place, and it will now be, as I said before, my final resting place when going to Japan. GREAT!And one more thing...as a member of the Horizon Club I was provided with someone who carried my luggage and took me to the train at the attached Tokyo station. As I have traveled a great deal to Tokyo and always take the Narita Express back to the airport, I really didn't need this service, but it was just one more luxury provided by this hotel.

It is my one of favourite hotels in Tokyo. Hotel staffs are so nice and helpful. My room view at 35th floor is fantastic. Room is spacious and well equipped with elegant accessories. It is worth for the room rate.

First Class hotel located in the most prime area of Tokyo. Extremely pleasant feel throughout and the staff were beyond friendly/helpful from check-in to check-out. The room was extremely spacious with a large bathroom and a superb shower. The breakfast buffet was of excellent quality in a luxurious lobby restaurant setting. Most certainly the best place to stay in Tokyo whether for pleasure or business. Another superb Shangri-La hotel with easy access to public transport (Tokyo Station is directly below), convenience stores and World famous shopping. Will definitely stay again and again as it can't really get much better than this.

From hotel staff meeting us at Tokyo Station, the prime location, incredible views, delicious food and amazing service; our Shangri-la experience was flawless.The Horizon Club was great and during our 5 day stay, staff made my family feel warm and welcomed.Having stayed at other so called top hotels in Tokyo, though good, the Shangri-la is exceptional.

This hotel is located in a most ideal location, above Tokyo Station. It's staff and service quality is excellent. Everything you needed is taken care of. Live the nesspresso coffee machine in room. Highly recommended.

I spent the last few days of my trip to Tokyo at the Shangri La. My first few days were spent at the Park Hyatt (see my review there) so the Shang was quite a change in comparison. It was a completely different vibe (the Shangri La being more of a typical hotel venue and the Park Hyatt having a private feel). Service-wise, I felt that both were on par with each other.As other reviewers have mentioned, it’s not an easy place to find. My cab driver had a little difficulty in finding the drop off area as it’s underground below the building. The hotel is on the upper floors of an office building in a business district, so it doesn’t jump out and scream at you. I did notice the Four Seasons hotel on the way there - for whatever reason their signage was more noticeable.You take an elevator to the 29th floor lobby area to check in. This level also has the lounge, a restaurant, and the elevators to the room floors. You can’t miss the check in desk and someone was available to help me right off the bat. Very friendly service and I was asked if I wanted to arrange my transport to the airport after checkout. They purchased the train ticket for me (billing my room) and offered to escort me there with my bags. There was no service charge for purchasing the ticket. They even extended my checkout to accommodate the train schedule (my flight leaves in the early evening). Check in and check out was done electronically via Wacom tablets on the counter…a nice touch.I had a corner Premier room and it was very nice - elegant and modern. The room wasn’t as cozy as the Park Hyatt. There, almost all amenities are hidden out of view and the room feels more homey. Here, the coffee maker (nespresso machine - nice) and a few other amenities were out in the open making it feel more like…well…a hotel room. Lots of the usual electronic integration that you find at Asian hotels such as motorized binds, light switches, dimmers, Toto washlet, etc… The bathroom was good size and the walk in shower was huge with the tub also in the shower room. It had a handheld shower head as well as a ceiling mounted rainfall type shower head. Plenty of counter space to put items as well as a good size mirror (practically full length). The bed was very comfortable and softer than the one I had at the Park Hyatt.I didn’t eat at any of the onsite restaurants, but I did hang in the lobby lounge area and the service was friendly and prompt. I also ordered room service for breakfast one morning and it was good as well as the service (both on the phone taking the order and in delivering it to my room within 30 minutes). In general the hotel had a very large, grand feel to it. The ceilings were fairly tall on both the main floors and in the elevators (which had chandeliers in them, even). The elevators had tv screens in them playing pictures of the inside of the hotel. There was also music playing in the elevators. This felt a little commercial for me, as if they are advertising themselves while you are riding the elevator. The music was nice but I would have preferred a quiet ride. Anyway, both very trivial complaints.When I departed, a staff member carried my baggage and escorted me right to the Narita express train platform. A nice touch and she was very friendly and talkative on the way there.I highly recommend this hotel, especially if you prefer your home base to be in the Tokyo station area (the hotel is literally right next to the station). I did the majority of my travel using the subway system and it was nice to have such easy access. Also, the service is very similar to other Shangri La’s so if you like this chain, I don’t think it will disappoint.Pro’s:- Facilities: Felt new and modern, yet elegant.- Service: Very attentive. Staff always said hello to me - many remembered my name and addressed me as such - and lots of smiles and bowing. If I encountered a staff member in the hallway, they always stopped what they were doing and stepped to the side, unless I was getting in an elevator at which they’d escort me to it. Certainly not necessary but it does make you feel that you are a VIP.- Room: very well appointed. Good selection of amenities in the room…I even got pajama’s to wear at night.- Transportation: great options nearby - subway, taxi, bullet trains.- Nearby Conveniences: ATM’s and shops in the Tokyo train station right next door, including a food court and Starbucks.Could go either way:- If you’ll be taking the subway a fair amount, it’s a great location. Although there is no direct entrance from within the terminal, you are probably no more than 300 feet door to door. A great home base if that’s your preferred mode of travel. The bullet trains are right there also. Do note that the Tokyo train station is fairly large so you may find yourself walking a bit to get to the exit.- The lobby lounge has a small, but decent, selection of cigars which they present at night. The prices aren’t bad either. If you enjoy a Cuban stogie, a good option.- It’s located in a business district so if you are looking to be in a more quiet or charming area, this probably isn’t the place.- Lots of folks at the lobby bar as well as a piano player and/or music playing throughout most of the common area’s. A good energy if you like that. If you are looking for more peace and quiet, then it may not be to your liking. The floors where the rooms are located are of course quiet.Con’s:- Noise: There was a little bit of noise in the AM from what sounded like the building itself. I think it was the wind and possibly the heat from the AM sun warming up the structure and causing some expansion, etc Nothing terrible, but if you are a light sleeper (like me), or not an early riser, it may wake you up.- View: My corner room had one window with a great view but the other was right next to an adjoining office building. Not a good view and I had to remember to keep the shades down to avoid giving folks a peep show. There may be better locations on the other side of the building (I was in a “xx35” room).- Facilities: The sink drained slowly because I think the stopper was out of adjustment. Also I had one ceiling light out. Neither were big issues at all, but it’s always nice to have a room that’s feels spotless in every way.

Three night stay at the end of January. Excellent room size and all the amenities expected of the brand. Wet room particularly good. Tokyo really is a sprawling mass. Taxis are expensive for Asia so if you are so going to get out and explore the city, it is worth using the highly efficient train and metro lines so the hotel's proximity to Tokyo station is a huge plus. Marunouchi and the Imperial Gardens are all a 10 - 15 minute walk away.Not cheap!! Paid around 600 USD per night on a room only basis. The hotel occupies about six floors at the top of the Marunouchi Trust Tower so you benefit from some very impressive views. That said, I was starting to get irritated with having to change lifts to get to my room - the lift from the ground floor takes you to the reception and then you change to the hotel's internal lift - but that is the way things seem to be going in Asian cities. I would certainly stay there again.
user_name:
Jo A
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: These have been my Tokyo visit months. We stayed at the Tokyo Shangri-La simply because our other 5star choices were sold out - and had I not booked this immediately it too was sold out a few moments later. The location right next to the Tokyo Station is excellent - if the Tokyo Station is important to you. Should the Narita Express be part of your plans - this deluxe hotel makes a lot of sense. Other strong points: All the staff was wonderful, Breakfast was one of the best, the views - fantastic - being one of the taller hotels in the area. The only slight downside is the location. Location is entirely subjective - and all things being equal this is a great location. The High end restaurant was beautiful, however on this trip - a full meal there just wasn't part of the plan. Stay here - enjoy.

We booked for a deluxe garden view room, which was super! Everything you can expect was available in the room! Free bottles of water, Electricity Converter (Which I’ve already asked for via an email to the hotel. and they have not hesitated to provide it for us for free.. The voltage in Japan is 100V and i wanted a converter to 240V for my electric stuff), Kettle, Tea & Coffee, Bathrobe & Slippers, Toiletry. They even provide Clean Pajamas every night, which is quite awesome!! Also there were a couple of authentic Japanese Kimono outfits in the room closet. The Bathroom was really cool, even the toilet was advanced in technology which has an amazing system.The staff was very attentive and welcoming..Loved everything about it the lounge, spa, room.. The hotel centrally located, and it is a 5 minutes walk to Tokyo Station and the subway, a convenience way to visit all the attractions. Ginza is close to the hotel about 18 minutes walk. We spent 6 nights and It was an amazing experience at the Shangri-La Tokyo.

First time of trying this hotel (usually stay at the Four Seasons) and we were very pleased with the experience. I would say the stand out comment from us is the amazing attention to detail in all aspects from room design, restaurant, room service and little touches during our stay. Staff really first class.Breakfast delicious with great views across to the Palace gardens. Beautiful pool and quiet in afternnon weekdays.Would stay here next time

for 4 days we were treated like rock stars and hated to leave. the hotel location is great, you walk out the door into Maranuchi and the train station being next door is brilliant for travel. We loved the Horizon Club but just the health club to the quality of the rooms, best ever.
