I am a fussy so-and-so. I travel constantly and am the first to get irritated by "little things". This is one of those hotels where those things don't exist and, if they did, someone would iron them out immediately. The service is immaculate, without being cloying. The rooms are excellent and everything works smoothly.You pay for it though!

What you would expect from a Shangri-la. Luxury, faultless service, all the little extras. Starts when a bellhop meets you at the Tokyo Station platform when your train arrives from Narita and doesn't stop until you are taken back to the Station on departure.The room was spacious, seemed to be serviced continually during the day and as the hotel starts on Level 27, views to the horizon. Without exception, the staff were professional, helpful and polite. We were forewarned, but anyone attempting to tip had their money returned. The restaurants were great - a choice of Italian and Japanese. And a multitude of choice within easy walking distance.The only consolation on leaving after 8 nights is that we are heading to the Shangri-la in Penang.

Stayed at Shangri-La Hotel, Tokyo from 27th Mar 2013 to 31st Mar 2013 during Cherry Blossom season.It seems that Shangri-La Hotels always have some of the best locations within any city. This one is located near to Tokyo station. It means that you can take the Narita Express train to and from Narita airport in about an hour. Narita airport is 60km from the city and a taxi ride will set you back USD250. It is advisable on arrival to ask the concierge to fetch you from the train station as first timers may get lost in the huge train station.Tokyo station has multiple metro lines which means it is convenient to get to anywhere in Tokyo. You may want to get the NEX+Suica card at the airport allowing rides on Narita Express and metro lines in Tokyo.Tokyo train station itself has loads of restaurants in Kitchen Street. Daimaru department store is co-located at the train station and on the 12th floor there are about 15 restaurants. The street outside Shangri-La is called Sakura Dori as it is lined with Cherry blossom trees and is absolutely enchanting when the flowers bloom. Takashimaya is 5 min down the road. Ginza is 15min walk or one metro station away. Imperial Palace is walking distance.The standard room itself is spacious and spotlessly clean. Large toilet with all the necessary toiletries. Very beautiful view of Tokyo at night.We had breakfast every day in the hotel and both the Japanese and western dishes are excellent. I found Nadaman expensive and food so so. We dined at several Michelin star restaurants in Tokyo which were cheaper and better. Esaki, Ginza Toyoda and Kyubei are all highly recommended. It may be better not to include breakfast in your hotel package as there are so many cafes in Tokyo station which is just next door.Service as in the other Shangri-La hotels are always excellent. They booked all the restaurants for us and gave us maps, instructed the taxi drivers etc. Service is always polite, friendly. Service staff is always smiling. Very pleasant experience.Overall excellent hotel and worth consideration if you are looking for a luxury hotel near Ginza and Tokyo station

I love this chain. Although the branding is consistent, each hotel has the feel of the local area. In Tokyo, the hotel has great restaurants and deep bows as your lift door closes and you ascend to the high level foyer. It is a smaller property and being high level, the views from every angle are long and absorbing: ours was over Tokyo Station and the Imperial gardens. We slept very soundly and the busy world below did not bother us for a moment.The basic room size is excellent (two chairs at the desk, chaise longue, massive rain head shower, and fully electronic Toto loo complete with heated seat. The fast WiFi is free so I did not mind paying for in room coffee too much.

This property is not only beautiful with wonderful views, but the staff is one of the best I have ever encountered. They were attentive to every detail and made you feel very welcome. I inquired at the front desk to see if they could help me find a camera store nearby as I had forgotten the charger to my camera battery. I was leaving for the day and asked that they let me know when I returned. When I did return that afternoon there was the correct battery charger for my camera waiting for me in my room along with a handwritten note. To say they go above and beyond is an understatement. The food was excellent in both the restaurants and when ordering room service, they were extremely prompt.

One of the best in the Shangri-La chain with a great location above Tokyo station. That may sound odd, but being near Tokyo station can be a really positive thing when sightseeing and getting around this vast city. Knowing you are only 10 minutes from your room when getting off the JR or subway is a welcome relief at times. We upgraded to the Horizon Club floor level and enjoyed the breakfast and evening cocktails and canapés. The staff, especially the super friendly bell hop girls who meet you off your Narita Express train from the airport, are all helpful and eager to assist in any way they can. The Chi Spa is very good and the two hour massage was a great way to get over the 12 hour flight from London. The only disappointment was Nadaman restaurant which was really expensive sushi in a city where you can eat to a very high standard for a lot less.

Outstanding accomodation, service and food. To be honest I was expecting another overpriced and mediocre business hotel, what I got was stunning accomodation and first class staff at every turn. Tokyo was an amazing experience but the Shangri La just lifted the trip, I couldn't recommend this place more entusiastically.

Great service and location. Horizon club was excellent. I had breakfast there every morning there during my 12-day stay. Nothing much to say about this hotel other than this was one of my best hotel experience
user_name:
swk_13
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed in shangri la tokyo for 3 days, what a superb hotel. I had a previous experience in the peninsula, which really met my expectations, but Shangri la has far exceeded all levels as we always felt recognized from the first day to the last by everyone at the hotel. The hotel staff combines the Japanese great hospitality with a touch of a world class international experience which you rarely find else in tokyo. The rooms are spacious, the location is excellent which is close to major retail store, shopping malls, restaurants and cafes. I thought that ginza had it all, but I was wrong the area around Shangri la is also on bar with ginza.Shangri la vs peninsula, at the same price range I would choose shangri la with out thinking.

I happen to stay here for a week on a business trip and the experience is good..not the best as it is made out in other reviews. The hotel location is superb located right on top of Tokyo station. Rooms are nice, well designed keeping human comfort in mind. Breakfast is nice and has lot of variety. The service is just about okay, it does not boast par excellence as it is made out to be. I happen to extend my stay here. My initial stay was paid by my organisation, so while checking out I asked them of the remaining amount. The reception said all is taken care and no need to pay. Once i am back to Mumbai I get a email saying I have not paid for the trip. They asked for email asking to debit my card, which they did. However they have sent the receipts via ordinary post and are yet to reach me (even after 1.5 months)..I was suppose to get it reimbused, which does not look to be a case now. I have sent them reminders but they were very quick to respond when the money was to be debited, now they are not.

We (family of 4 with 2 young children) recently returned to the Shangri-La Hotel after a two year hiatus (stayed at the Tokyo Peninsula last year) and everything we originally enjoyed about the property is still intact.Favorite characteristics remain the same: clean comfortable rooms, excellent service/hospitality, convenience (daimaru, tokyo station, ginza). I've nothing to add at this point other than we will continue to patronize for as long as they provide this level of excellence.See you next year!

The attention detail is superb , simply the best hotel group and that includes the Four Seasons. I stayed for three nights and its in the perfect location for the business district. If I was a tourist I would probably consider the Palace hotel due to the location. ( on other occasions stayed at the imperial , outdated and still expensive)The rest has been mentioned before !

I stayed at the Shangri-La Tokyo for the first time last week for two nights on business.Very impressive and alround enjoyable experience! The location is fantastic right next to Tokyo station, a short walk to the buzz of the Ginza strip and nearby a number of shopping centres and offices. I also enjoyed an early morning walk around the Imperial Palance one morning which is not far away.My check in was very smooth and efficient - and I was very pleased to be offered an early check in at 530am without any charge or fuss (unlike my visit to the Conrad in Tokyo this week - review coming). The rooms are classic Shangri-La - tasteful decor, very well equipped and nothing significant I could fault. The rooms are spacious as is the shower/tub area, the beds are heavenly, the desk and chair very practical, nice tv with bose sound system and the automated toilet was a quirky reminder i was in Tokyo!I only had breakfast at the cafe - service is great, food ok, but the buffet spread a bit limited which was surprising and disappointing. Room service breakfast was also very good and well presented.The pool is a little small but has a nice view, same with the gym which has several cardio machines and small selection of weights. It was a bit crowded one morning with 6-7 people in there at the same time but does the job. The locker rooms with sauna, spa etc were well outfitted.Finally, I really want to highlight the service - every single member of staff was extremely polite and I've walked a huge fan of this hotel!Room service is efficient, food is very good

This is - as many other reviews already say - an excellent place to stay. You are lucky if you are able to stay here because of the overall highest level of service and infrastructure. The views are really breathtaking but so are the rooms: large with beyond-the-ordinary amenities and comfort.Definitely among the top hotels in the world, also if you have seen a lot of places before!

I travel a lot with my job and have stayed in lots of hotels around the globe, but particularly in the Middle East and Asia. This hotel is probably one of the greatest in the world, in terms of its standard of service and the amenities available.Situated right next to Tokyo station, around 45 minutes from Narita airport, and about 25 from Haneda, the hotel is right in the centre of the action. From the moment you arrive, nothing is too much trouble for the fantastic staff, who are incredibly polite, charming and attentive.I would recommend the not cheap, but excellent ,car service from either airport, which saves a lot of hassle and whisks you in some style to the hotel. The lobby on the 28th floor has an excellent bar, with great views over the city. The 'standard' rooms are all really modern and sizeable, offering every comfort - Bathrobes,slippers,pyjamas are all standard offerings of course.Free internet,decent flat screen TV with plenty of fantastic bed, great decor and another great view over the Tokyo skyline (my room was on the 35th floor). The bathroom is huge, with a separate wet room, with the biggest rainfall shower I have seen certainly.Only ate breakfast on my first visit last year, which was a buffet style, but huge choice of offering and excellent service again.I was in Asia for two weeks,visiting several different countries, and this was the finest hotel I stayed in by far - This was my second visit but will definitely be my regular stop from now on.

I use top of the line omazz & sealy mattress at my house . So I know what it is like to sleep in a good bed .At shangri-la is definitely better ! Maybe the best in the world. Of all hotel that I ve been to in the past 20 years. One of best amenities, best bathrobe , also given to use best pajamas , slippersOnly bad thing is rate is high for tokyo.. And when rate is high in tokyo... It is highest in the world But if u prefer good sleep & good location... This is it

What a fantastic hotel – really what a 5 star hotel should be all about. If you’re lucky enough to stay here, you’re in for a treat.Location is great for those doing a quick over night or stop-over from Narita. It’s located right at Tokyo Station which is about 45 minutes on the Narita Express. Do be sure to have someone meet you at the platform as it is very poorly signed to get from the platform to the hotel. It literally takes 15 minutes to get out of the station to the foot of the hotel. Hotel is beautiful and a dozen or so floors of a tall office building. As the hotel lobby only starts on the 28th floor, you’re basically guaranteed great views from your room. Rooms are huge and very nicely appointed – best feature are the views and also the large oversized washrooms with great features. Loved the washlet toilet especially. Nice big flat screen TV with lots of international channels.Appreciated the free shoe shine AND the free internet – almost unheard of nowadays.Breakfast was excellent – choose Western or Japanese option and there is a buffet included of a nice variety of items.To be improved was the Japanese restaurant – was expecting something a bit more flash for the Shangri-La. I didn’t find the food was of compelling value to price. Also Lobby bar had last orders at 2300?! Overall, wonderful hotel and wonderful staff.

I reviewed this hotel in May of 2012 and we just returned from another visit to this wonderful property and wanted to follow-up. After our first visit, we ranked the Shangri-La Tokyo as simply the best hotel we've ever stayed in. Hard to imagine, but after our second stay, we feel the hotel even exceeded those expectations. We upgraded from the completely amazing Deluxe room to a corner sweet - unbelievable. While the basic Deluxe room was wonderful, the corner room gave us sweeping views of Tokyo Bay and the Tokyo Sky Tree. But amenities aside, the unbelievable service and care from everyone of the hotel staff is what puts this hotel on the top of our list. One of the measures I use in evaluating a property is, was it a great value? While the Shangri-la isn't low cost, it IS high value. I feel you get everything and more for your money. Thank you Shangri-La for providing us such exceptional service during our stay.

The Shangri-Li Hotel in Tokyo perfectly put together elegance and modern. It sites at the 27th floor of a commercial building, which give her a very good view for every room in the hotel. The service was great; the room was big, with a very good city view from high and it was just excellent. Even the fragrance in the lobby is very comforting. Every time when we came back to the hotel, it was like entering another peaceful world. The room is excellent, and is very clean and tidy. The customer service responded quickly with our requests, which deserved a real compliment. Overall it is an excellent hotel and worth every penny of it. I am glad I made the right choice.

I stayed at Shangri-La Tokyo right after my stay at Grand Hyatt (see prior review). Shangri-La Tokyo is located right at the Tokyo station and the hotel is actually starting at the 27th floor. Typical Shangri-La design with beautiful fabrics all through the hotel. The moment you enter the hotel, you can smell you are at Shangri-La as also this hotel is using the typical Shangri-La scent which is used all over the world within this hotel company. my room at the 32nd floor was very spacious with views over Tokyo station and Maronouchi, I could even see part of the garden of the royal palace. The rooms are classically designed with very good linen in the bed, even the pyjama which gets provided by the hotel has a very good quality and was extremely comfortable to wear. The bathroom was huge as well with a big window right next to the bathtub... fantastic lying in there and looking over Tokyo at night.I tried afternoon tea at the Lobby Lounge as well as room service and all food was prepared to perfection, nicely presented and served with a warm smile. The hotel is fairly small, just around 200 rooms and it really feels like a boutique property so if you like individual, high class service close to Maronouchi and Ginza, this is your hotel.

Excellent hotel in every way. Views from 31st floor were amazing and also from the bar. Lobby staff were perfect, they arranged a taxi to be at the ground floor when I needed it and gave the driver instructions on where to go. Two things worth mentioning the hotel car from Narita is very expensive so get the limo bus if you can. Second, it was the most expensive beef burger and a few beers I have ever had in the bar but worth it just for the views.if you are not on a budget then would highly recommend.

We have just returned from our trip to Japan and this hotel was exceptional. Beautifully stunning rooms, luxurious throughout with absolutely everything you could ever need to make you feel comfortable. No cutting corners at this hotel, you get the best quality of everything. The staff are definitely what make this 5 star hotel special. The staff are so welcoming, and go out of their way to accommodate any request. Very polite, service was outstanding and the food was absolutely delicious - what an amazing spread for breakfast, I have never seen anything like it.Location is excellent, right next to Tokyo station, we watched the bullet trains come and go from our window. Incredible view of the city. We arrived on the 1st January 13 and when I had previously booked my trip through my travel agent, they could not get any tours as all tour companies were closed for the New Years break. However Shangri-La concierge managed to find us a private guide for 2 days to show us around Tokyo, we had a fabulous time, our guide showed us how to use the underground trains, took us to see the Emporer for his New Years greeting. It was just perfect. Thanks Shangri-La, your service is exceptional, we will definitely be back!

I can't find anything to fault this hotel at all...service was immaculate, staff spoke perfect english, the bell-girls were pretty, location fantastic and the room INCREDIBLE! I do a lot of hotel inspection in my daily job so when i stayed in this hotel recently, I really really loved it. First of all, the location is fantatsic. Right next to the Tokyo station which connects you to everywhere. Not to mention, Tokyo Station has lots of shopping and food places. I couldnt get out of this place everyday! haha! And Daimaru is also right at the station which has a lovely inexpensive food hall for takeaway. Lots of varieties and for people who are crazy over the Tokyo bananas, they have an outlet in the foodhall too!Service was immaculate - the staff all spoke perfect english and was very helpful. Very often, the 5 star or 6 star hotels do not give you a feeling of warmth. Yes, they are all pretty and perfect and the staff all professional. What Shangri La Tokyo excelled in was combining professionalism with warmth...they always had a smile and that smile was genuine. It felt like "home" when I came back everynight. This is what makes a hotel click! And the room...i can go on and on about the room!!!!! Most delightful! it was such a pleasure to stay in and sleep in. For the first time in my life, I actually wanted to stay in the room the whole day! My room had a lovely view overlooking the Imperial Gardens and I could even see the tip of Mt Fuji in the distance! The bed was so comfortable and the sheets were heavenly. Every evening, there was turndown service and it came with a different traditional Japanese snack each time. And I loved the bathroom! Like all Japanese hotels, the toilet bowl came with all the different buttons and functions...it was a clever toilet bowl! It opens up automatically everytime you walk near it and it closes on its own too! Japan technology! haha! But what I liked most was the shower cubicle with the bathtub in the shower cubicle. It had a huge rain shower, and keeping the rain shower on while you soaked in the bathtub was absolutely therapeutic! And the bathroom amenities came with lovely scented bath salts!Thank you for a most lovely stay! and I cant wait to come "home" soon on my next trip!

i have stayed in this hotel two times, last time on My Honey Moon in June 2012, the best thing was that the staff remembered me from my last visit in 2009 and offered me the same room i stayed in last time, the service was very personal and i dont think i will think of another hotel whenever i stay in Tokyo again, every dat they leave you a treat in your room with a personal message from the hotel staff everybody greats you by your name, they will help you even in things beyond your stay in the hotel, for instance the concierge planned my whole railway trip in Japan for the next two weeks in Japan, also arranged for my luggage to arrive at my last destination, the hotel location might be one of the best features your on top of Tokyo station and can get to anywhere in Tokyo from there also across Japan, i can go on and on but i belive you wont find a better hotel to Enjoy your stay in Tokyo :)
user_name:
Abdulaziz A
Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia

review_body: From the location, to the service to the attention to detail this is one of the best hotels I have stayed in. Lovely, efficient, discreet service and staff. I always take the train from Narita and walk to the hotel from Tokyo station. Much more of the experience than my colleagues who go in cars. I also walk to our offices from here and the general area. Great place, great location thoroughly recommended

Every detail is taken care of. Incredible, the staff of the hotel extremely friendly, breakfast and dinner great and the rooms very comfortable and great view. Design of the hotel well done. The best!

The staff, food and service at Shangri-La are outstanding. We had a fabulous stay here. The people are lovely and super attentive. Especially Shioshi at the front desk, she was so helpful, even when our friend left things behind on the express train - not once, but twice. (Returned safely both times)The position is brilliant too- soMany great things to eat, do & buy in Tokyo Station- literally next door.Thank you, Shioshi & Shangri- La Tokyo!

This is possibly the most impressive hotel I have ever stayed in for business, the room was a great size with all expected fixtures and fittings, the tech connectivity was huge, with all kinds of ports, cables and options for your room that you will probably never use!When I am travelling, the WiFi in a hotel is hugely important, this was excellent (as you would expect in Tokyo) and free of charge!The bed was comfortable and the room luxurious and modern, lighting was adjustable for day/night/reading from various control switches on the walls all well located.The breakfast was good, they offered two options, a full buffet and a a la carte with partial buffet, both were of high quality.We cruelly played a game when having evening drinks one night, we found that if you moved seats on the table you were at, the staff would move the drinks to you, we did this a few times, each time they drink, napkin and nuts follwed us around the table - as I said, cruel, but, a real indication of simply how excellent the service was! I would recommend this hotel for anyone who can afford it, it's perfectly located right next to Tokyo Metro and the central train station and being on the 27th floor upwards you have no noise from the same. The views anywhere in Tokyo are excellent if you are over 20 floors up and this hotel was no difference, with views of Mt Fuji, The Sky Tree and Tokyo Tower from the various bars and areas.When I returned home to get into an elevator, I almost felt upset no one was there to bow at me and wish me a good day.Truly amazing, next time I am in Tokyo, I will surely use this hotel, come hell or high water!

I have been to Tokyo on a few occassions in the past and have stayed in hotels during those visits. The impression that I got is that all hotels in Tokyo are similar except for the branding being different. This trip I decided to stay in Shangri La although it meant that I had to travel a little more to get to my office. This stay has changed my view about hotels in Tokyo and needs to be experienced to be believed. I can go on describing the hotel from start to end but if I have to say something in a one word I would state is as a "PERFECT" hotel with no shortcomings. The service is equally outstanding with good choice of food in restaurants and room service. The staff is very attentive to your needs. Also the hotel helps you with booking for Narita Express to the airport at no extra cost. In addition for new comers to Tokyo one of the challenges is to get to the correct platform at train station and the hotel provides you with an escort service if the guest informs them in advance. This place is a pleasure to visit and stay and I would strongly recommend it to any person visiting Tokyo.

We stayed at the Shangri-La for our last nights in Japan. We had experienced excellent hospitality throughout the country so had high expectations. These were fully met from the moment we checked in to our departure. The staff could not have been more helpful. We were checked into a better room which had breathtaking views of Tokyo including the Sky Tree and bay area, with wrap around windows. We were given a complimentary drink in their beautiful bar as our room was being serviced when we arrived back from shopping - the manager even came and apologised. Totally unnecessary but very nice all the same. Upon check out we were helped with our bags from the hotel to the station platform for the airport express. This is a free service and very welcomed with lots of bags and a very busy station!

What can i say , i felt over welcomed , wonderfull staff , generous welcome gifts , smiles everywhere. from the hotel manager , directer and marketing head ... all went out of their way to welcome me , i felt like i was a Vip . its defnitly my first option to japan . the staff at the lobby all memorised and addressed me with my name (respectfully) which made me feel apreciated a wonderfull experiancespacious rooms and amazing food...price? very reasonable for japan and for the standard they provide its fair and acceptable. i cannot even find any thing to critisize them . my ultimate experiance so far - world wide

I was half expecting the hotel room to be small like many Japanese hotels but the room here was very spacious and comfortable. The bathroom was huge too! One thing I truly appreciated was that that if you need to take a train from the Tokyo Station and are afraid of being lost in the labyrinth, the hotel has a service (I didn't pay for it) where they bring you all the way to the platform.

Great hotel, but then it needs to be as the competition from other top end hotels in this part of Tokyo is demanding. Located right next to Tokyo station which is great for Shinkansen and other JR services including the Narita Express (the hotel offers a "guide" service to get you to or from your train which if youve not been to Japan before you'd be well advised to use). The Shang occupies the top floors of an office block (as do the nearby Four Seasons Marinouchi and the Mandarin) so the views are good. Minor quibbles: my paper didnt arrive first day and I had to ask for extra shampoo when I ran out....so not a lot to complain about! I didnt eat in the restaurant so can't comment on the food. Good as it is I think the Mandarin in Nihonbashi just has the edge, and the Peninsula has a better bar and is just as good otherwise. Service at the Four Seasons is even better. And the Conrad just feels 'cooler' and has a fantastic restaurant. But all these are great hotels so probably best just to pick the location that suits you or go on price. I havent tried the new Palace Hotel yet or the Maranouchi Hotel, and the Tokyo Station Hotel is just re-openning after renovation which might be an interesting pick. And if you fancy a more traditional Japanese experience there's always the Imperial. As I said competition is intense!

This hotel has got it so right. The staff are friendly and helpful. The design and furnishings are of the highest quality. The rooms are big with great views of Tokyo. Upon check in I was asked how I would be getting to the airport. The lady offered to buy my train ticket and charge it to the room. Upon checkout I was escorted to the express train to Narita. Normally I wouldn't accept as the train station seemed so close. On this occasion my colleague encouraged me to accept. I'm glad I did as the Shangri-La staff member took me through the maze of the station corridors to the right platform at high speed. The Imperial Palace was a short walk away - but unfortunately closed on Fridays. So I had to settle for shopping and a beer in an interesting beer hall along the main street. I highly recommend this hotel for the luxury, service and location.

Many people have rightly praised this hotel - and it lives up to all expectations. From the minute you arrive to the moment you reluctantly have to leave ! Nothing is too much trouble, from directions to anywhere, to requests of where to find items - I had a few treatments in the Spa - it was truly the most wonderful experience of service and wonderful treatment and I love my Spas !THe location is wonderful right by Tokyo station and Ginza and the Imperial Palace are within easy walking distance. The Lobby lounge in particular was a relaxing space at any time of the day or evening and service like all the hotel was superb. The rooms are just wonderful with spectacular views - wonderful to just look out day or night and feel so lucky ! In summary - Service is the priority at EVERY level of this wonderful and special hotel

I usually don't write reviews but took it upon myself to sign up and write b/c of my recent stay. This was simply the best hotel experience I've had ever top to bottom. Yes, it's certainly pricey and I'm a frugal guy but it was absolutely worth every penny. I hesitated in writing b/c I wanted to keep it a secret and don't want them to change. The rooms were immaculate and luxurious to the point I didn't want to leave. The views were absolutely awesome. The lounge and restaurants were great. The best thing however bar none was the service. From the front desk to all the others - they totally tried to take care of you in every way. And no tips in Japan! Remembered your name and escorted you to the train station. A quick story as an example - I was late for my train leaving for the airport so one of the guys went with me to buy the ticket and ran, actually sprinted, with me at top speed (carrying my bags) through the maze of the train station (in his suit!) to get me to my train on time. Simply unbelievable and never had that type of experience. I hope to return soon.

This hotel is ridiculously good. Situated a stone’s throw from Tokyo’s main station, from the minute you arrive it feels luxurious and special. The hotel occupies the top floors of a tower building, and the reception is on the 28th floor, so you are guaranteed great views no matter which room you have. Our room was on the 34th floor with amazing views out of the large picture window. The room was among the best I’ve stayed in, it was huge and comfortable. It also had really good extras like a coffee machine, stereo system, and a well stocked mini bar. The bathroom is fantastic, and there is a huge walk in shower/wet room and a bath next to a huge window for yet more views. We didn’t eat in any of the restaurants but we did have a few drinks in the bar, which had a really good choice of cocktails and of course more views!The staff were attentive yet unobtrusive, and the place had a quiet calmness to it. In terms of location, you can get to most places easily via the subway which can be accessed from the station next door to the hotel. I would highly recommend this hotel, it isn’t a bargain but I felt it was worth every penny for the quality of the accommodation and standard of service. I’m looking forward to staying in more Shangri-La hotels in the future!

After many trips in the Western hemisphere I almost forgot how excellent a hotel can be. It is very well located, just within walking distance from Tokyo station and also a 15 minute walk to the vibrant Ginza district. After check-out if you want to go to Narita, you can take a bus directly from this hotel. The rooms are remarkably modern and comfortable. The restaurant on the 28th floor offers a good breakfast buffet. As for lunch (Italian cuisine) it is high in quality but, as I am a good eater, low in quantity. The gym on the 29 th floor is good and well equiped. Room service is very good. As for their staff, it could not be better, top notch. If I visit Tokyo again, I will definitely stay at this hotel.

I seldom give 5 stars to a hotel, but occasionally I do, and very occasionally I wish I could allocate six stars. The Shangri-La in Tokyo joins my very small list of hotels, which far exceeded my expectations, and to which I know I will return because of the excellence of the stay. It joins the Peninsula in Bangkok and the Oberoi at the Taj Mahal on my list of most favourite hotels.We stayed for four nights at the end of a vacation touring Japan, and booked a corner room with a view of the bay and Tokyo’s Skytower. We were met at the door of the bullet train as it arrived in Tokyo station, and helped with our luggage and the short walk to the hotel. (Tokyo station is large and complex, the hotel would not have been easy to find without the help of the hotel staff. We were met by two, very helpful young ladies – but I think I prefer a man to assist with my heavy bags!!).Our room was large, superbly decorated and very comfortable. Two walls were floor to ceiling glass with amazing views across Tokyo and a sunrise to be seen to be believed. It contained, a large, very comfortable bed with superb linens – which gave us a great night’s sleep. The bathroom was large had a rain shower and regular shower, with a great selection of toiletries. The room had the level of comfort and quality of contents that you would absolutely expect of a 5 star hotel.The difference for me, however, was in the quality of service. Just outstanding. Nothing was too much trouble, and everything was done with a willingness to please. We had great concierge service with help on tickets for the Sumo and restaurant advice. We left the “Do not disturb” light on one day: but they were there to service the room as soon as we returned and switched off the light. Club lounge service was very attentive and non-intrusive. It did take almost an hour to get two cocktails on room service the first night, but they called to apologise and to advise that they were running late. Some of the best service I have ever received.The hotel is in a great location, right on top of the main station and is therefore a great base for touring and visiting Tokyo. For the level of service and quality of the facilities, for me it also represented value for money. We enjoyed our stay at the Shangri-La, and it has my complete recommendation. I would not stay anywhere else on a next visit.

We spent the last four nights of our two week honeymoon at the Shangri-La and it was the perfect way to end the perfect holiday. Located right next to Tokyo Station, we came off the Shinkansen train and within about 5 mins we were going up (in an extremely fast and sparkly lift!) to the reception and lobby on the 28th Floor. From the moment the door staff greeted us by name (how did they do that?!) to entering lobby we had already fallen in love with the place. A efficient check-in meant we were in our room (#3535) within minutes along with a complimentary bottle of delicious sparkling wine as gift for our honeymoon. The room has the wow factor from the moment you walk in - the view over towards to Tokyo was stunning and was even more lovely in the evening! We sat staring out of the windows sipping our wine for quite a while! The bed was huge and ridiculously comfortable and meant every night we had a great night's sleep! It was very easy to make the room as light or as dark as you wanted with the variety of switches for the lights, blinds and curtains - nice little touch thanks to technology. A large desk with fast wifi meant it was very easy to make our friends jealous with many photos of where we staying! The bathroom was also great - bathroom and shower room, large sink and vanity area (with great lighting for putting on make-up! and also one of the best toilets ever!! Automatic lid, flush, seat warmer, you name it it had it. The concierge was GREAT - she booked us tickets to Kabuki, Sumo, confirmed our train booking to Narita, made dinner reservations for us as well giving us information about Tokyo and getting around. Her service was amazing and greatly appreciated. They also advised on the Tsujuki Fish Market and organised a taxi to be ready for us at 0345 so we could make it to the Tuna Auction (not that I wanted to leave the bed!). Service from all of the other Front Office staff was also friendly, polite and professional without being cold. Housekeeping standards were very high and you rarely saw them to say thank you!! We were very sad to leave (they kindly gave us a late check out as our flight was not until the evening) but two members of staff escorted us to the NEX platform and helped us with our bags, which was the perfect ending touch to an amazing stay. Thank you to everyone, we hope to come back one day.

The Shangrila Tokyo is perched on top of a skyscraper tower right next to Tokyo Station and The Imperial Palace in the center of the city. Arrival is a bit disorienting as you enter below ground level and the lobby is on the 28th floor. The hotel occupies several floors above the 28th, and the result is the room views give everyone a specatcular landscape right at your feet. The lobby bar benefits from this view, as does the well appointed fitness center, complete with a pool on the 29th floor. If you are looking for open courtyards and wide open spaces this isn't your place, but then again Tokyo probably isn't your type of city either. If you want a smart room with all the bells and whistles, attentive service and good food, all with a world class metro view, then come on in. The concierge is very helpful to meet all needs, which is often key in a city like Tokyo which can be challenging for foreigners. The location is central to everything, and easy walks to the Palace, Ginza, Tsujuki Fish Market. Rooms are spacious and well designed. This is a top flight hotel in a world class city and location.

This property is one of the nicest I have ever stayed in. Impeccable service, great location, and facilities that are beautiful. The rooms are good sized with technology that will spoil you. Very modern and feels like the whole property is brand new. If you can get a deal, stay on the club floor and enjoy the breakfast to die for, snacks throughout the day, and drinks overlooking the Tokyo skyline at night. Having the Tokyo station next door was very nice for us. My wife and I were a little intimidated as this was our first trip to Japan, but after one day we had it figured out and could hop on a train and go wherever we wanted. Check out the different parts of Tokyo. They have great shopping and the little, off the beaten path restaurants are the best to enjoy the local experience.We enjoyed every thing about this hotel and would highly recommend it.

The Shangri-la chain has developed a reputation of being non-descript 5* luxury, hence I was hesitant of booking the Shangri-la. With so many top end hotels to choose from in Tokyo I initially did not have the Shangri-la as my first choice but between being offered and excellent rate and wanting to be next to Tokyo station I booked the Shangri-la.I am very pleased to say that the Tokyo Shangri-la totally beat me expectation and has made me look at the chain in a new light. From first impressions all the way through to the end of our stay we were made to feel at home and the hotel went out of its way to make us feel at home. After a 12 hour flight in to Narita and the train in to Tokyo station we were greeted by the bell staff on the train platform (a great friendly service) and escorted to the hotel. This complimentary service is invaluable after such a long flight also Tokyo station is a maze with multiple exits.My only small complaint is the Shangri-la lacked a buzz, it’s not a big hotel and being based in an office block made the atmosphere a little sterile. Its neither small enough to be a boutique hotel nor big enough to be a big hotel and hence lacks atmosphere.Pros:Hotel designRoom sizeGreat serviceMeet and greet at Tokyo stationFurnishing qualityAverage:Breakfast quality Medium size hotel that lacks the buzz.Location is good if you want to be near Ginza, business district or Tokyo station. However far away from nightlife.

Spent a magical five nights here alone on business. I love my family but WOW was it fun to relax here alone -- I felt like I was in a sanctuary.Warning: if you want to see Tokyo's sights, probably a better thing not to stay here. Because you will not want to leave the tranquility and sheer and total perfection of service that permeates everything from design to housekeeping to advance technology in the rooms to the amazing food to the spa (the best treatments I've ever received and in the most luxurious spa rooms).The hotel is on top of a skyscraper -- don't let this put you off. It is many floors of lobbies and spa and restaurants with the rooms above this. All rooms have a tremendous view a la Lost in Translation (which was filmed at the Hyatt -- but same type of view). Here are some suggestions if you are going to stay here:1. Insist on a room with a view of the Royal Imperial Palace where the Japanese royalty live. If you are lucky, and the clouds disperse, you will see Mount Fuji as well. You will also see the main train tracks in the foreground -- fantastic full view of Tokyo.2. Book a full spa treatment. The staff will sit you down and go over your needs and give you a type of test to know how to best work on and with you. I was dubious but it ended up being the most amazing treatment I've had at any resort -- or otherwise. They start with washing your feet and move on to massage, facials, etc. There is a shower in your massage room and it is beyond luxurious3. Enjoy the heated toilets, the lit dimmers and the window shades in the room. Sounds strange but it will totally effect how comfortable you can feel. Every single switch in every single room, no matter complex, worked perfectly. Only the Japanese!4. Make sure you get club access. They serve a happy hour spread that is divine -- all the top-shelf alcohol and Champagne you could dream of plus delicious food both hot and cold. You barely need dinner after this. CONSNone. Seriously, I have never said that before. This place is perfect. Perfect location, perfect service, perfect food.Enjoy!
user_name:
neptuno3
New York City, New York

review_body: Almost all good hotels in Tokyo have great service by western standards so it goes without saying that this hotel does as well. I stayed here for a week and found it extremely convenient being a short walk to several subway lines as well as the Tokyo JR station. Prices are not cheap but in the context of high end Tokyo pretty reasonable. One downside, the two restaurants in the hotel are not great and for some reason very very slow service (based on two meals so they have just had a bad couple of days).

What an excellent experience in every aspect in this magnificent hotel. Customer service is amazing. The porters (two young women) insisted in taking my suitcase to the train station 1 block away despite my pleas to let me do it alone. The room was fantastic. The bed was divine. The shower was incredible. Every forgotten amenity was supplied for in the room. The breakfast was a feast. The pool on the upper room was so nice-quiet and peaceful. This was one of the best places in which I ever stayed!

High atop the Marunouchi Trust Tower, this top had a few floors in the building. The entrance was a bit difficult to get to, but the location was great - right next to the main Tokyo train station, and within walking distance of multiple department stores, train lines, shops, restaurants and gardens of the Imperial Palace. In fact, if you like to walk, you could walk to Ginza (the main shopping district) and if you felt more adventurous, probably an hour's walk to Akihabara (electronics district) and Asukasa Shrine (touristy ethnic place for shopping / sight-seeing) and the new Tokyo TV tower.The luxurious fittings and fixtures, the customer service, and the food was great. Ofcourse, all this was at a price that was incredibly expensive. But the room was stunning and big, and the bathroom had a really sophisticated automatic toilet. Everybody spoke and understood English and was helpful. There was free WiFi in the room as well, though breakfast wasn't part of our package.Only downside was that they did not have my room ready, even by 3pm, and then I had to wait for around 15 minutes and remind them. Other than that, it was quite flawless.

Have stayed in this hotel since it first opened and love the convenience of the location sitting right over Tokyo central station. The rooms have wonderful views of the city and the staff are exceptional in the level of service which they consistently provide. Having stayed in many of the other 5 star choices (Grand Hyatt, Conrad, Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental, etc) which are very good by the way, this still remains the stand out choice.

Stayed 2 nights in June. Hotel is in a great location withing a couple minute walk of the Tokyo Station. Nice and clean modern room with comfortable bed and good showers. Wifi had a steady connection during the entire stay.All rooms are on floor 31 or higher. Makes for wonderful views. The breakfast included was very average. Staff was friendly and helpful during the entire stay. Rooms were a tad pricey, but the hotel id offer a safe and comfortable stay.

I thought the hardware was mind-blowing but it's the software of the property that makes my stay sublime. The high-level of staff service, from the swimming pool to concierge, is what makes guests come back for. The well-appointed Piacere, where I had breakfast everyday and dinner, has the most attentive and professional staff on this planet. The food prepared by Chef Paulo reminded me of the true purpose of eating while Sommelier Kenji-san offered expert recommendation on food and wine.

We have been to Tokyo many times and stayed at many hotels but this was the very best experience ever. Starting with the wonderful welcome at the front desk, it just gets better and better. The room was very comfortable complete with hotel pajamas - great because I forgot to pack my nightgown! The staff was exceptionally friendly and so happy to help. When we asked the concierge for help to plan an outing....he went above and beyond the usual service. And then there is the wonderful breakfast buffet in a lovely room with a beautiful view. And the crowning touch was the complimentary railroad station service. The bellman carried our luggage and walked us to the station platform and put our luggage on board the train. We also asked them for a pick-up when we returned to the hotel which is very helpful because the Tokoyo station is huge and a maze. Can't say enough about this great hotel.

Check my profile - I have stayed in thousands (literally) of hotel rooms, in all parts of the world, in all classes. Ritz Carlton, Four Seasons, Mandarin Oriental - all very good and well worth the money. The experience at the Tokyo Shangri-La exceeded them all. The feeling of care and attention to detail are simply unmatched. Bathrobes, kimono's, AND pajamas? Unbelievable. Outstanding in every way - thank you Shangri-La.

Situated at the heart of Tokyo, right next to Tokyo station, Marunouchi north exit, you will find yourself overwhelmed by friendly staff who will bow in front of you until the elevator door closes. since its right next to Tokyo station, literally the busiest station on earth, it is easy to get around freely. The room is excellent, huge bathroom, comfortable bed with splendid views overseeing tokyo, the imperial palace, or the skyline of tokyo depending which room you are staying in. will for sure stay with them again! no doubt.

The service, location and quality of accommodations were excellent. The room was spacious, the bed was comfortable, the staff were all very friendly. I had breakfast there twice and the buffet was good. The service in the lobby bar for drinks in the evening was a little slow, but nothing unbearable. I would definitely return.

Basking in the glory of any Shangri la hotel is a good experience but this is taking it up a notch. The rooms are spacious and feel super luxurious. Beds are to die for. Food was fab, but what made rhis stay very memorable was the staff. It is the little thngs that do it for me. The remark that i seem to really like my coffee and then makingsure there is take away cups set up for my 4 am departure to the fish auction. The reservation of train seats to kyoto and then making sure the seats are on the side where you can see mount fuji. I wish i could go back thee tomorrow!

This is an absolutely fantastic hotel. Located centrally right next to Tokyo station which makes getting around the city (and out of it) extremely easy.The hotel is beautiful. The rooms are appointed to the highest standard, with extremely comfortable beds. The restaurants and bar are superb, both with excellent service where nothing was too much trouble.There is a lovely swimming pool, perfect for relaxing after a long day. A wonderful hotel, in a brilliant location.

My first stop on a 90 day around the world trip (see my blog - www.toscanoworldtrip.blogspot.com") began with a 5 night stay at the Shangri-la Tokyo. The stay has been so good that I had to write this review after my 3rd night! It was a great choice especially to help me get over the jet lag! I am staying on the Horizon Club level and the service is so near perfect that all of the Concierge level team can anticipate my request before it is asked! Shangri-La Tokyo-you are doing a great job, especially in these times of service shortcuts. The next two stops on my trip are Hong Kong and Singapore where I will stay...where else? The Island Shangri-La in Hong Kong and the Singapore Shangri-La (Valley Wing) where I am sure that the service will also be top flight but I really wish I could take all of the Horizon Club team from the Tokyo Shangri-La with me because they are that good!

Kasura had just started when we received our Japan visa but that never daunted our excitement to pursue our trip to Tokyo. When the JAL touched down at Narita, i could feel the excitement burning. Konnichiwa! like a baby uttering his first few words, i greeted everyone i saw ( mind you, i had practiced the art of bowing). After a friendly encounter with immigration and customs, a big and warm smile from a staff of Shangri-la Tokyo just assured me of a perfect vacation. The bags were securely arranged at the van while we were taking some burgers for energy. Shangri-la Tokyo greeted us with a famiiar scent at basement 1 and we where immediately whisked to 28th floor for check in. We took the last floor (37th) known as the Horizon Club. I love the teddy bears that welcomed me.Shangri-la Tokyo is best for businessmen who visit Tokyo. It is at the heart of the city where everything is within reach: the tokyo station, some local and authentic restos and shops. For regular travelers like me, this may not have a vacation ambience, but the service is still perfect. The room is spacious. You have 2 television sets ( at the bedroom and the other is at the vanity area) ... There's no reason missing a scene from your favorite japanese anime movie. The beds are comfy. You dont need to change the linens everyday. Another wise way of helping mother earth. The shower room is awesome. Dont forget to close the curtain. :-) The quality of service is common to most Shangri-la hotels, but Tokyo's Shangri-la restroom spells the difference- it is automated. The seat cover opens by itself when you get near it. Hahaha, i know it's about sensor powered thing, but i am really amazed. Now that is sitting like a King. The wifi is recommendable. Singapore Shang has one fast wifi service too. Just a bit sad i could not try the pool. The weather was really cold - but the Chi Spa is heavenly. I recommend this hotel when you visit Tokyo and dont forget to try their wagyu beef - ouishi ne.Yoi kyuujitsu o!

Being my first time to Tokyo, we decided on a hotel that needed to be centrally located and not far from the Train stations. Shangri-la is just above Tokyo Central Station, so if you take the Narita Express from the airport, its just an hour away and just a few steps away from the train station. Next to the hotel is Daimaru shopping centre. I walked to Ginza which strolling only took 20 minutes to get to. We took a corner room which had the most amazing views of the Imperial Gardens. We were on the 34th floor so the view was simply amazing. The corner rooms are really very spacious. Please see the pictures for a better appreciation of the room. The package we had came with breakfast and choice of full buffet or ala carte depending on where you dine. Both experiences were awesome as the chefs really put effort into ensuring that what they send out is near perfection.Concierge was very helpful with reservations and recommendations on places to dine. Coupled with very detailed maps and descriptions of the place that you need to go to. I am impressed with the level of professionalism and service standards and would return again.

The Shangri-La hotel in Tokyo is located in the CBD area and is in fact housed in one of the office buildings, spanning its top few floors. The nearest train station is Tokyo station which is about 5 minutes walk from the ground floor entrance (‘Yaesu North’ at the train station). We arrived from Haneda airport via airport limousine bus which costs US$11/person one way. We were told by the hotel that there was ‘complimentary pick up service’ from the bus stand. We were expecting a car to pick us up but instead we met 2 hotel staff dressed in bright red uniforms who took our heavy luggages and escorted us to the hotel which was about a 10-15 minute walk away (i.e. they pulled our luggages through the busy CBD streets all the way to the hotel). There is a simple reception area on the ground floor where you need to take the lifts up to the main reception which is on the 28th floor.The hotel has luxurious interiors with crystal chandeliers cascading over a descending staircase, plush furniture, soothing jazz music coming from the bar and that lovely scent omnipresent in Shangri-La hotels. It definitely takes your mind away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo in the streets below. The hotel staff were very polite and friendly and check-in was fast. Though we arrived at 1pm they had a room ready for us as we had requested for early check-in. Although the staff who checked us in showed us to the lift, there was no one to help bring our luggages to the room.We had a standard room on the 33rd floor and stayed for 2 nights. It cost us US$685/night with daily breakfast included. The room was huge for a standard room and offered views of the Tokyo train station below and the skyscrapers. We were lucky enough to see Mt Fuji on a clear day. There was no traffic noise whatsoever. The interior of the room was luxuriously furnished with two comfortable single beds and a small lounge by the large window which had automated day and night blinds. There was a large flat screen TV, free wireless internet, working desk and fully equipped mini bar with tea/coffee making facilities. The bathroom was excellent with a separate wet shower area/bath tub and toilet stall. You could see the bathroom from the bedroom through a glass wall with an automated blind for privacy. However, if the bedroom is dark and the bathroom is well lit, you will be able to see the person taking a shower although the blinds are down! The rain shower was huge but I would have preferred stronger water intensity. The turn down service was nice with bookmarks, comfy bathroom slippers and pyjamas! They even had Japanese style robes in the drawers which were really comfortable to wear. They also provided a couple of fruits on our first night. Room service was expensive. I tried their chocolate fondant cake which was average as the middle part which had the chocolate did not ooze out.We had our daily breakfast at Piacere which offered stunning views of the city. A very modern and classy restaurant. For the breakfast buffet, you had a choice of either American, Chinese or Japanese breakfast set (one serving) with the buffet service only comprising of pastries, juices, soup and fruits. Service was excellent. I also tried the foot reflexology at Chi The Spa which had great service and transports you to another world of peace and tranquility with soothing music and massage oils tailored to suit your needs.The hotel also allowed us late check-out at 3pm on our departure day and helped us to store our luggage until we returned. Overall, I recommend the Shangri-La for its large rooms and luxurious and comfortable accommodation. They can improve on going the extra mile to provide more personalized service. At times it felt like there were too many guests coming in and out of the hotel and the staff couldn’t remember that you were one of their guests. The location in the CBD might be a tad far away from the main areas (about 20 minute walk to Ginza) but the Tokyo metro station is a 5 minute walk away. Overall an excellent experience.

We arrived to Tokyo on a cold March month however a stay at Shangri-la's newest addition was beyond spectacular and warmed us right up with their service. The best I would say of all the Shangri-las I have been to. The rooms are gorgeous. Beautiful comfy beds, large bathrooms and overall extremely spacious especially so considering this is Japan we are talking about!The concierge was the most helpful I have ever experience. We would ask her for directions (many many times) and she would print us out a detail maps with pictures, arrows and all! I went to the Park Hyatt which I also considered to stay and I would say pass that. It out of the way (other than the rooftop bar to boast.) The added plus about Shangri-la is that it is next to the train which is very key considering taxis are extremely pricey!The only thing I would say is it isn't the best view eg. the entire skyline of Tokyo. But its still respectable.Loved loved it here.
Stayed here during a work visit. Soon as I saw the room I did not want to leave. The furnishings are impeccable and pure luxury. Was the best hotel experience I have had.
user_name:
businesstravel_12
New York City, New York

review_body: My first time to Japan and Tokyo but not my first stay at a Shang hotel and I have to admit they just don't disappoint. This hotel just exudes class and luxury.I had a Horizon Club Premier room and seriously its a big room with a huge TV, really comfortable bed, large bathroom and overall everything a guest would want or need to make an enjoyable stay something to remember.I'm a huge fan of Shangri-La's Horizon Club, as a business traveller its perfect for casual business meetings and as a guest its great to sit and relax and be spoilt with their fantastic service. It is expensive and there's no denying that and I accept there are cheaper options that are also excellent hotels, but, this hotel really is one amazing place and if you're on a holiday looking to spoil yourself and your significant other then this is the hotel for you.Its not just great hotels that make Shangri-La special, its the little things and attention to detail and its the service that you can rely on to be outstanding no matter which hotel you stay at and that's what I value and find worth the extra expense.My regret was I only had time for a 3 day stay and I really look forward to returning later this year not just to the Shang in Tokyo but also to see more of that city.

Shangri-la Tokyo is one of the best luxury hotels I’ve seen in Asia, Europe, Middle East, and US. • Excellent customer service• Big and luxury rooms• Rooms are equipped with many entertainment features• Smoking rooms are available• Good location (next to Tokyo’s station)The hotel is highly recommended for business travellers, the hotel’s lobby is good for short business meetings or dinner.

This is one of Shangri-La's newest hotels and you will not be disappointed. We love luxury hotels and this one definitely exceeds expectations. The rooms have the most comfortable beds, and the soft furnishings are all high luxury. The marble bathroom and toiletries are all 5 star. The lobby and the restaurants are also of a world class standard. I will definitely be back in July this year. I forgot to mention the service is exceptional.

If you can afford to stay here, you won't be disappointed. The quality of the lodging is first class, the rooms huge and I had a fantastic view. The location is perfect also, very central.The only downsides are maybe that you have to take 2 elevators to get to your room and that the restaurants are of course very very expensive. But there are plenty of good cheap options just outside the door including a Starbucks across the street instead of the $30 coffee room service... Also, one quirky weird thing, Taxis have to drive up to the hotel under ground...and for whatever reason they can't use the credit card system there as they get no signal. So pay your cabby before you go underground (and just walk a few feet) or have them add their fee to your room bill (which is time consuming and difficult if you don't speak Japanese).

only one night was all it took, but would need more nights to really settle in but couldnt stay any longer this time around as other hotels were on the schedule so i had to leave. the room was perfect with goodies to match. loved the warm toilet seat always welcoming to my derriere

A great hotel... but one small think ruined the experience.. and usually the Shangri-La chain is not this "cheesy." My reservation said "1 Deluxe Bay View Room (King)." So I woke up and opened the window expecting a view of a "Bay." Nothing but buildings as far as I can see... so I called the front desk and the said I was in a Bay room but "its complicated because the Bay is very far away but you can see it sometimes." So - the lesson - don't pay extra for the Bar View... pay extra for some of the other amazing amenities in the Hotel..
user_name:
RT1971
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Tokyo has plenty of first class hotels, but the Shang is in a class of its own. Very high quality furnishings and decor, plush carpets and couches even in the basement taxi lobby, and a scent that always takes me back each time I step into the hotel. The rooms are also fantastic, well equipped with every amenity you could think of (the small shaving cream sprays were a very welcome touch for someone like me with a 5 o clock shadow by 2pm!). The rain shower is a delight, and beds are some of the most comfortable I've slept it. But above all, the service is top notch with friendly staff and courteous greetings on every occasion. They always help explain my destination to taxi drivers, and bags are taken care of.Areas to be improved: the gym is somewhat small and sparse, although it does come with free weights, which are rather rare in hotels. The pool is a little small but adequate. Really, little to complain about except that sometimes I can't get a room because they always seem fully booked at all times of year! I will be at the Granbell Shibuya hotel next time I'm in Tokyo this month (personal trip), but wishing I were in the Shang.

One of the best rooms I've ever stayed in. The bed, work area and especially the bathroom were perfect. Service is excellent but most hotels in Tokyo have great service. Restaurants and bars are very good. I especially thought the breakfast buffet had an excellent selection.Gym facilities, despite having a pool, are lacking by five star hotel standards (see Four Seasons Marunouchi) but in line with high end Tokyo hotels where the locals clientele doesn't work out.

Stayed 3 nights last week. Overall, the premium quality of the hotel is evident from the momemnt you are greeted at the door to the details in the finishing of the rooms. Room and toilet were luxuriously fitted out and full range of toiletries provided (comb, toothbrush, moutthwash, sewing kit, Occitane soaps/shampoos). Found the beds too soft for my liking. Hotel kept luggage for 4 days whilst we went to Nagano for skiing without any hassle. Location (next to Tokyo station) was very convenient if you intend to use the JR trains to go to other prefectures. Tokyo station itself has tons of shops and eating places.

This past November I was lucky enough to be able to stay for a week in the Shangri-La Hotel. I've never had service like this at a hotel before. They were more than happy to accept my luggage via delivery service (takkyubin) and hold it for a week for me. Makino-san, with whom I had been corresponding via email regarding the matter, actually recognized me when I was checking in and greeted me by name and told me if there was anything at all I needed to just let them know. They purchased my return train ticket to Narita airport for me, and would have guided me to the proper platform as well, if I had needed the assistance. And every single morning when I walked by and every single evening when I returned from work they greeted me with enthusiasm and asked me how I was and if there was anything they could do to help me. I went out shopping every evening and each time they hurried to help me with my bags and to call the elevator for me and would help me all the way to my room if I needed it.The room was stunning as well. Tastefully decorated and not to mention enormous. There was plenty of room for everything, a very comfortable desk for me to work at and I must say I loved the heated toilet seat with bidet attached as well. Every little luxury I could think of had been provided for - comfy slippers, a turn down service every nice, fresh bottles of water each day - and if I needed help with anything and called the front desk, they always greeted me by name and helped me immediately. I slept soundly every night and they had obviously also thought about sound-proofing the room somewhat, because I never had problems with noisy neighbors or getting woken up by slamming doors, which I often have with other hotels.I can't think of a single bad thing to say about either the staff or the hotel. And it's location can't be beat either. It's under a 10 minute walk from Tokyo station - even for someone with short legs like me.It's not cheap, but then again, what's cheap in Tokyo? But you won't regret staying here - I'm sure of it!

This is the best Shang I have ever stayed in. The rooms are gorgeous the bed divine (better than any Westin bed) the staff were unassuming and perfectly aware of our needs. Nothing in Tokyo is cheap but this hotel is worth that little bit extra.

This was my first time in Japan on business and the team at Shangri-La made it an outstanding experience. Service was simply flawless, from the concierge team that met me at Tokyo station and escorted me to the hotel to the reception team that helped organized my daily business excursions into Tokyo. Every member of staff went out of their way to help me acclimatize to a very new environment, it was a refreshing experience to be greeted by name by almost all members of staff after less that 24 hours! The central location in Maranouchi and next to the Tokyo station made travel easy, the great concierge team who translated all my travel requirements to the taxi drivers made it all the more so! I cannot recommend the Shangri-La Tokyo enough.
They don't have the New York Bar at Park Hyatt, but that's about it... Shangri-La at it's best...

Good location, superb service, nice rooms, I used to stay at the Conrad in Tokyo but from now on it will be the Shangri-La, it has everything to satisfy a demanding client except the price...After disappointing stays at Shangri-La hotels in Beijing and Hong-Kong (but dealt with by the Management with care and efficiency), Tokyo reconciled me with Shangri-La hotels.

This is my third stay in the hotel and it is my favourite in Tokyo. Being right next to Tokyo station makes it extremely easy to get to from Narita airport and there are loads of good restaurants around the area. The service is impeccable. After just the second stay they had noted my preferences and ensured things were the way I liked it during this recent stay. You just need to ask and they will do their best to meet your needs. They got me my train tickets and offered to have someone walk me to the train - not just the entrance but right to the platform! I loved the cotton pyjamas they lay out for me each day. Getting into them after a shower at the end of a long day was just so relaxing. It is the ambience in the room that makes a difference. In other hotels I have stayed in, I have felt comfortable but not as relaxed as when I am in Shangri La Tokyo. The stress and worries just melts away. The beds are one of the most comfortable I have slept in.

Visited Tokyo on business, and was recommended to stay here. I'm glad I listened. Check in was quick and easy - up from the basement car park to the 28th floor lobby in the express elevator, then checked in and shown to my room on the 35th. The room was fantastic - amazing view of Tokyo - the backdrop of an incredible city scape down to the railway station, where I could see bullet trains arriving and leaving, and then beyond to the Imperial Palace gardens. From the restaurant it's possible to see the new Tokyo Sky Tree which is currently under construction, which when finished will be 634m tall. Anyhow, back to the room - great layout - loved the bathroom (as a first time visitor to Japan I must confess to being highly amused by the electronic toilet seat!), and also rather liked the chaise-longue! The AV equipment in the room was great, and the ebeds extremely comfy. The staff were extremely helpful, with additional services like providing mains adaptors and providing a map of the area, and a jogging map all provide with maximum charm. The area is primarily business, and didn't get the chance to stray too far from the Maronouchi area, but for those looking to stay somewhere nice in this area, I can heartily recommend this hotel.

I gave it try, but problems:- TV in 'corner suite' only faces into middle of room, so cannot watch in bed or from sofa, had to sit on office chair in middle of room- No steam room in mens gym locker...this is Japan and claims to be a 5 star hotel...why no steam room in the land of onsen?- Room not cleaned, was forgotten about- Cannot easily walk to nightlife hubs, so many roads to cross and stuck by the huge central station

We came back to this hotel after more than a year just to find that it still keeps improving. Service is flawless and very personal indeed. In fact, it has touched our hearts to witness how well and selfless guests are treated, knowing that some of the employees must have gone through very difficult times in their personal lives in recent months. For once, we would like to bow to so much dedication and persistence. Shangri-La Hotel, Tokyo will always be our first choice when traveling to Tokyo.

We chose this hotel because of its location right atop the train station. Were hoping to get the train to the airport, and then found out when we arrived that a lot of trains have been suspended in an effort to cut down on electricity use. So instead we took the cab [20 mins] to the Ueno station and took the Keisei train, which was fast and less expensive than JR. so it all worked out. The service in the hotel was fantastic. I also would say that the breakfast was completely fine, more than adequate. The rooms are really extravagant in a pre-2008 sort of way. See-through rain shower, a day bed [!] etc. It felt a bit more Singapore than Tokyo. Walkable to Ginza, the East garden, all the subway lines imaginable.

This property just underwent an extreme makeover, and the results are spectacular. Gorgeous rooms, outstanding restaurants, flawless spa, outstanding service and even Free WIFI (something not all luxury properties offer). Better still, it is adjacent to Maronouchi, a chic neighborhood that literally picks up where Ginza leaves off in terms of fashion, food and culture. It is also next door to Tokyo Station, and with the trains being the best way to get around town, this place is a winner. It may be one of the more expensive hotels, but those who can afford it get what they pay for. I love the fact that if you forget something at home, chances are the hotel will be able to give or loan you (pajamas, athletic shoes) what you left behind. The concierge is also really on the ball.

First time staying with Shangri-la group and first time in 5 stars hotel in Tokyo. With the money you paid, this hotel's performance did exceed what we expected! (Compared to the other foreign hotel group in Osaka, no "wao" factor except the price!)It was a comparatively small hotel occupying several floors in the commercial building next to the Tokyo Station. The deco is a standard Shangri-la, yet the room size really surprise us, comfy beds, big washroom, independent shower and bathtub (if you need goooooood shower when traveling aboard, it's definitely the one!), free wi-fi, good lighting (main panel with both side of the beds), curtain with buttons to control (yes!).Nice breakfast in their Italian restaurant, you can choose from continental, asia, japanese or even a la carte, and if you really don't know what to eat they still have a small buffet table. We didn't encounter any noisy tourists with hyper-active kids during our stay, the whole restaurant was quiet, elegant and demure, and we liked it alot!Quite a few times when you're staying in 5 stars hotel, having paid such price you'd expect to be treated like a king/queen but you feel disappointed because they always focus on other residents who can pay even more. I appreciate a whole lot, that even though I booked my discounted room via local Japanese travel website (ikyu.com), even though I didn't stay in the fancy club level executive suite, they made me feel like I'm the queen. Although it wasn't budget-friendly at all to stay in Shangri-la, but it'd definitely my only place I'd stay next time in Tokyo.

Stunning rooms with latest high-tech gadgets and excellent location just steps away from subway station making it really easy to travel around Tokyo. Staff is absolutely amazing, everyone is super friendly and helpful. No question or request is ever a big deal for them, to the point that if you express an uncertainty how to get from hotel to subway station or nearby restaurant, someone from the staff member will actually stop doing whatever they are doing and walk you all the way to where you need to go. They truly care about every single guest and go out of their way to make sure that your stay is not just enjoyable but absolutely perfect in every possible way. Highly recommend!Tip: try the Spa, it is absolutely worth it!

I am a big fan of Shangri la hotels - after Four Seasons Group they are quite simply the best there is and Tokyo is no exception. A really excellent hotel but, with the value of the Yen as it is, its desperately expensive. My room cost US$450 per night for a basic room - not a club floor room. Dinner for three in their "ordinary" Italian style restaurant cost US$500 for a basic meal including a pretty ordinary bottle of wine.Having said that and seeing that somebody else was paying for my stay, it is hard to fault this place. The room is perfect - everything works, all possible amenities are there and all you could want is available, in perfect working order. The health club/spa/pool is pretty small and basic but remember this is a city centre, business hotel so don't expect more - its always empty anyway so why make it a big feature.There is also a shortage of F&B outlets but again, with 5,000 restaurants and bars just outside the front door, why try to compete - more fool me for eating in their restaurant and spending US$500 - my tip? - just go across the road and eat better for 10% of the price. Having said all this, you pay for what you get and as long as you don't mind forking out the readies, this place is as good as it gets. Great staff, great service - if my widening experience of Shangri La hotels include such places as this, I might even start looking on Four Seasons as Number 2.

Stayed here on business and was blown away by the quality of the hotel, both in terms of facilities and services. Simply outstanding. Having experienced the Shangri La experience elsewhere, expectations were high, but were exceeded in every way. I can't recommend this hotel enough.

I was treated like royalty when I stayed at this hotel. It was a magical stay. I had a corner room with 180 degree view over Tokyo - spectacular. The room was beautifully decorated with all the modern features you would expect of a top class Tokyo hotel. The staff were excellent, very accommodating and thoughtful. I used the pool and gym during my stay, they are both small but have everything you would need. The hotel met my every wish and need in true Shangri-La style. I would definitely recommend it to others.

I have stayed here 3 times on my trips to Tokyo and you can always guarantee a clean, spacious comfortable room with every add on you could want. The carpet is so lush you could get a good nights sleep on the floor! The bathrooms are superb and I do like the heated toilet seat with jet spray cleaning!There is a decent gym with modern equipment and an indoor pool, sauna etc. As with all 5 star chain hotels, they charge exorbitant prices for breakfast and if you choose to dine in but there are numerous dining options close by, right outside and opposite in fact at a fraction of the price. I travel a lot for work and as a point of principle choose to dine out locally wherever I am, it is cheaper and generally a way of immersing in to the local fabric.The hotel is seconds walk from Tokyo station right in the centre of Tokyo and Ginza district, very handy if arriving on the Narita Express and well connected via the metro to anywhere you need to go in the cityAs a business hotel I would highly recommend the Shangri-La

This is my second review and I am unapologetic about my absolute love of this property. I am yet to find fault.
