[The closure of the hotel after the earthquake was a cause of some concern however people all react in different ways and it's unfair to fault human nature.]Standards of customer service are already high in Japan, but I have come to understand that the Shangri La Tokyo completely redefines that high standard. There is not a moment that I do not feel very well looked after, that the staff are genuinely focused on ensuring guests are 120% comfortable and that every need and request is taken care of. When dealing with any of the staff it feels like talking with a caring family member, a discreet butler, a close friend and personal concierge all-in-one. I have been to 6-star resorts in places like the Maldives to Venice, 5-star diamond properties in every continent, and stayed at some of the most extravagant and prominent hotels of the world. Many times I have felt I never want to leave but in my passion to try as many places as possible I rarely return to the same hotel twice. In contrast this is the first hotel or resort anywhere in the world where I feel that this is where I am supposed to be. Content. Happy. Not a care in the world... and I want to stay again!

For nearly two decades I have been making regular visits to Tokyo and had the opportunity to sample almost all its upmarket hotels. Many of the newer hotels are very comfortable and elegant but for my main needs, the Shangri-La is the best. Two main reasons:1. the location is unrivalled. An entrance to Tokyo Station, the functional centre of Japan, is moments away. And if I draw circles around the office locations where I usually have meetings in Tokyo, the ShangriLa is the closest of any hotel to to their intersection. It is easy to sneak back to the hotel for an hour or two's downtime in the middle of the day. And the lifts speed you quickly from street-level to room in a fraction of the time required in some of the other tower hotels like the Park Hyatt or the Ritz Carlton.2. it's discreet and unfashionable. The lobbies of flashier hotels nearer to the "action" (ie Roppongi), like the Grand Hyatt, get clogged up by excitable hordes of irksome Tokyo newbies - for example, young hedge fund analysts waiting to be indulged by their brokers - whilst the ShangriLa exudes calm and dignity. I recommend the station-side rooms that look right down on to the Shinkansen tracks. Watching the trains and their pasengers is hypnotic and relaxing and gives an insight into the pulse of Japanese life that the more obviously expansive views available elsewhere do not.

My wife and I stayed at the Shangri-La in Tokyo for one night. It was not cheap but was well worth the experience. When we got into our room, we were wowed by the fantastic view of the city through the floor-to-ceiling windows (we were on a high floor). Not to mention curtains were electronically controlled with day curtains and night curtains. The 5 star experience has you feeling pampered in every way. (Not like some hotels which claim to be 4 star but then when you enter the room, you feel like your home is more comfortable and better finished.)(+) The room and bed was incredibly plush and furnishings top-notch, and the TV was either the largest or second largest we've ever experienced in a hotel room(+) Luxurious bathroom with sliding outside partition, and option to use the overhead shower(+) Business centre had 3 or 4 computers with free internet access. I was able to print my maps for my next driving trip with no fuss(+) Professional, impeccable, excellent service from bellboys/bellgirls to reception staff. The bellgirl did not expect/want a tip but we gave her anyway.(+) The hotel has a free service which we used on the day we checked out - where the bellboy would escort us with our luggage to the train station. Although the JR station was not very far away, it was a confusing walk where you had to change elevators on different floors and walk through some areas under construction. Am sure we would have gotten lost if we tried to walk there ourselves(+) Close to Tokyo JR station and Daimaru. Central location in Tokyo(-) Not really a minus, but because the hotel is relatively new, and it is inside the Marunouchi Trust Tower, it is not very obvious from the ground floor how to get to the hotel. The sign which says Shangri-La is placed at a strange position in our opinion. Didn't mind taking the lift to the reception floor which was on the high floor, as they had staff downstairs to help with luggage.

My wife and I enjoyed a prompt, friendly late-night check-in at the 28/F Reception which took less than 10min. However, our bags took another 10-15min longer to arrive from the underground garage lobby from which we entered the hotel after arriving from Haneda Airport for our one-night stay.We were assigned a spacious corner room with floor-to-ceiling glass walls on two sides, a king-sized bed (with a mattress that is a little too soft), large contemporary sofa, large flat panel TV mounted on the wall, minibar-fridge, electronic safe and full-sized wardrobe. Day and Night curtains are remotely controlled from various panels on the walls and on night tables flanking the bed. The writing desk comes with Technology Kit, Stationery Kit, discreet flip-up panel at the side which gives access to electricity sockets, a variety of female jacks (USB, RJ45, S-Video, Video, Audio In, HDMI-2, VGA/RGB) and universal electricity plug adaptor. Also provided are an electric kettle, Nespresso coffee maker and two sets of comfortable pyjamas. WiFi, well-padded bedroom slippers, teabags and Nespresso capsules are free. We slept well; due to the excellent soundproofing we couldn't hear trains in Tokyo Station, which is conveniently located next to (and under) the hotel.The large well-lit ensuite bathroom is separated into 3 sections: a long counter with an elliptical washbasin; a roomy wetroom with over-sized bathtub and shower; and a toilet cubicle with a TOTO Washlet high-tech throne. L'Occitane amenities are complemented by two hairdryers and an adequate number of well-positioned clothes hooks and towel bars. The thoughtfully-designed room was perfect for us, and we especially appreciated the attention to detail which makes for a well-executed 21st century update to the Shangri-la formula.

I normally stay at hotel chains like Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental, Ritz Carlton and Shangri-La and What I can say is that the Shangri-La Tokyo exceeded my already good expectations by far, service was amazing, the concierge at the Horizon Club was very helpful and knowledgable, location is unbeatable and the rooms are amazing. I can't wait to come back !!!!

Of 120+ nights in hotels last year, 2 of them were at a Shangri La - you do the math. I am admittedly not the biggest fan of the chain, but that was until I stayed at the Shangri La Tokyo. The layout of the room is suspiciously similar to the Conrad Tokyo, yet with a look and feel that is decidedly Shangri La and a final product that is spacious, comfortable and really makes sense. The over-sized chaise longue along the window made perfect sense for watching the sun rise over Mt Fuji or the lights of Tokyo come on during dusk. One night I sat there after a conference call watching the bullet trains sweep in with a bottle of bubbles and it somehow felt perfectly natural. The desk offers 2 choices of chair - one for those who need to work, and one for those who like to kick back while on leisurely phone calls. For a business traveller having a 'working' desk is critical and this point hasn't been ignored by the Shangri La. Each room comes equipped not just with an iron but also with a steamer, and more than a few other technological mod-cons like themed lighting, remote controlled blinds and the latest in washlet toilet seats. The in-room internet is free and is the fastest I have experienced anywhere in the world!!The Italian restaurant Piacere has some of the most authentic Italian cuisine in the Metropol, with staff who as skilled as David Copperfield in that they are so attentive you barely need to request anything and it's already being handed to you, while at the same time managing to keep out of sight. There are so many gems on the menu that you're best to come hungry and try the set menu which lets you savour an appetiser, 2 pastas, a main and a dessert for 10,000 JPY. For a budget traveller this may not be the cheapest Italian you can eat in Tokyo, but take a bite, close your eyes and you'd swear you're in Sicily! The lobby lounge was comfortable although nothing to rave about. The gym is cosy but considering there is a lap pool alongside it (and that you're at Tokyo station where space is a premium) it feels more than adequate.What impressed me most about this property was the staff. Clearly the staff are trained in a very different way from other properties and that's something you will notice the moment you approach the ground floor entrance doors. In the period of 30 minutes after checking in I had housekeeping picking up my shoes, room service delivering dinner and the porter delivering my bags, each of whom asked me before they left "is there anything else I can do for you?" In each instance it was asked in such a way that I felt they really did care, and wasn't just something they were each told to say. Such phrase was to be repeated many times during my week at the Shangri La, so much so that as I checked out and was asked for the last time if there was anything else I would like, I almost asked them to book my next stay.

We stayed at the Shangri-La over the 2010/11 New Year period because the hotel we usually stay at was fully booked. I have to say that I'm glad it was. The Shangri-La was amazing. We stayed in a deluxe room which was extremely well fitted out both in terms of decor and amenities. Our room was on the 31st floor and had views out over Tokyo station and across the city. The proximity to Tokyo station is a real bonus, as was the proximity of the running route around the Imperial Palace (ask the concierge for a jogging map). The staff were all extremely friendly and professional and their service was faultless. The only thing to note is that the Shangri-La doesn't feel quite as Japanese as some of the other big hotels in Tokyo - that's not a criticism, just an observation. That said, we would definitely stay here again.

Recently stayed for 1 night in Tokyo and this hotel is amazing with sensational views from all rooms as the hotel starts on the 28th floor. The room was a deluxe room and the modern features made the stay most enjoyable. The staff were friendly and always willing to assist. The Horizon club is excellent and the breakfast is outstanding.Lunch at the Italian restaurant was delightful.When next in Tokyo I will be staying at the Shangrila. Great experience

WOW all i can say is what a wonderful stay myself and my husband and two year old daughter had at Shangri-la in Tokyo. We where really treated extremely well and the customer service was impeccable, truly wonderful service.. and what can I say but if only all of the western world could take on board the lovely friendly and helpful service from most Asian cultures. We have a lot to master!! A very informative and extremely polite Mr Kohei Makino ( Horizon Club Manager ) took great pride and effort to make our stay ultra comfortable, even to the point that his manners and services even took him through the very busy train station lugging our luggage to help us board the train to return back to the airport, not once but twice due to a cancelled fight, and due to it being a long Japanese weekend, and being that most accommodation throughout Tokyo was booked out after our departure. Mr Makino made some extraordinary measures to place us once again in the hotel, even when the hotel was booked out!! !! Impeccable service truly, there was no complaints from us and we felt like we where wrapped in a very friendly family bubble and didn't want to leave!! Every staff member acknowledges you as you pass through the floors and receptions and if your staying at the Horizon Club and suites, plus children are accepted!! big bonus!! your previous preferred drinks will be remembered by all rotation staff, this sort of professional service makes ones trip truly special. Why then are they rated 19th on adviser, there something wrong there!! We have spent many years travelling and staying in high-end to moderate accommodation and Shangri-la in Tokyo has proven the best by far for me personally. Right down to the very beautiful ever so classy decorations , rooms, restaurant and décor. and on a happy note, heated self cleaning toilets as the Japanese are famous for!! I so want a one..... I'm sure you wouldn't be disappointed, and we wouldn't hesitate to stay there again after our fantastic stay in Tokyo!!

We are so happy we chose Shangri-la to stay at in Tokyo. Its our first time to stay at a Shangri-la. We normally stay at Four Seasons or Ritz Carlton hotels.The Deluxe room was probably one of the largest rooms we've ever stayed in that's not a suite, which was a surprise since we've always heard Tokyo rooms are smaller in comparison to US hotel rooms.We also thought it was one of the most quiet rooms we've ever stayed in. Our room was on the 34th floor facing the Tokyo station tracks below, but could not hear the trains at all. Also in most hotels, by around 8am you will hear housekeeping cleaning noises, but we never heard any noise from them nor did we ever see any housekeeping cleaning carts in the hallway. It was so quiet and with the black out shades, we actually over slept one morning and didn't wake up until 11am!Everything was state of the art, all the lighting and window shades were electronic. If you don't want to be disturbed, there's a button you press by the door. But if you forget to turn it off before you leave, your room will not be cleaned, which did happen to us once. But all you need to do is call housekeeping and they will come and clean it right away.Service was flawless. Everyone were extremely friendly and polite.One thing that would have been nice was better detailed direction posted on their website on which exit to take out of Tokyo station. Tokyo station is so large and has many exits. We had to ask a station agent to direct us to the right exit, which is the Yaesu North exit. Go to your left when you exit and you will see the Shangri-la hotel sign just a few steps away.We liked the location of the hotel. Its more of a business area, but there are still plenty of shops and restaurants close by and Ginza is only a short walk away. With Tokyo station just below, its easy enough to take the subway to farther away places. Its walking distance to the Imperial palace and East garden.We had a wonderful stay and would recommend this hotel.

all of the high-end hotels in tokyo are beautiful and have great service and it's probably tough to pinpoint the best one. we've stayed at conrad, ritz, peninsula, mandarin and shangri-la and all have their own benefits. shangri-la's location above tokyo station is pretty convenient tho it's a bit confusing to find the first time. the lobby here is the least striking--not a big open room with high ceilings. the bar is also very close to reception area so it's kind of noisy sometimes. we booked a corner room and were surprised at how large it was. there is a huge open space from the bed to the window chaise, probably enough for two people to jump rope. in the entry way is a small vanity/desk, in addition to a work desk in the main area. we had beautiful views facing the imperial palace on one side but it was a little strange for the other wall to look right into offices, so we kept our sheer shades down all day. the decor is elegant yet simple, very clean looking. the windows were triple-paned so we couldn't even hear the trains right outside. we also couldn't hear any noise from the adjacent guest room. it's strange that the bathroom only has one sink but perhaps in practice it's not a big deal. the fitness room was a standard hotel gym and the pool has nice city views too. the locker spa has a jacuzzi and steam. this is probably the most simple facilities of any of the tokyo hotels we've stayed at. i thought the nappy blue towels they used in the pool/locker rooms looked dowdy. unlike other hotels, shangri-la doesn't charge for gym clothes/shoes/swimming suit rentals and wi-fi is complimentary.we didn't try any of the restaurants because a lot of other reviews were poor. there's a bellmart and starbucks downstairs to get some small items (i'm a big fan of aloe yogurt and apple yogurt, and chiffon cake from starbucks). the breakfast buffet at conrad is tough to beat.i think the shangri-la logo needs a re-design. i think the signage is supposed to be a gold color but it looks kind of puke-colored, and the "S" logo is a bit blocky and doesn't look elegant. we'd probably choose shangri-la again mostly for its convenient location for public transportation and access to daimaru, the whole underground shopping arcades and ginza shops.
Great hotel, hard to beat the service. The rooms are very spacious. Breakfast is quite poor though. Booked a BMW for the way back to the airport and they mixed it up and sent a van instead.

We stayed 3 days in one of the Horizon suites and absolutely loved it !! Service was very efficient and friendly, room is very spacious for Tokyo standard and with latest technology - it is the most recent five star hotel in Tokyo. Shangri-la quality can be variable from one hotel to the other but this one is definetely one of their best with beautiful interior design. Location is convenient - just above Tokyo station. Again, staff is very friendly, attentive and polite - and abundant. We strongly recommend this hotel.

A new benchmark in luxury hotel has arrived in Tokyo. And it’s the Shangri-la. Opened barely one year ago, this hotel quickly established itself as the new yardstick for luxury hotel standards in Toyko.After hearing lots of buzz about this hotel, I decided to try out just to see how it measures up. I did not go with high expectation. Past exposure to Shangri-la hotels and my preconceptions dictates that I am expecting a hotel that caters more to the masses with room rate that’s enticing to those seeking mid-tier luxury, that will offer a grand and large lobby but mediocre rooms, service that are efficient but more impersonal and business like. Wrong Wrong Wrong. This Shangri-la really surprised me. ArrivingI arrived by taxi right after I had checked-out from the Conrad. As the hotel is so new, the taxi driver was confused. Even his GPS was not showing the hotel’s location. Fortunately, I had a map with the hotel name in Japanese. The hotel is located within a high rise office tower. The ground floor ( arrival lobby ) is on the small side but opulently decorated with large crystal chandeliers and plush carpeting. Sort of like arriving in a very nice mansion. Upon arrival, bell hops quickly took care of my luggage. Check-in was quick. I was escorted to the room and the staff briefly demonstrated the room features. RoomThe room I had booked was a Premier Corner Room with a spectacular and un-obstructed view of Tokyo skyline ( looks even better at night ). All the latest in-room tech is there, including side table power panel with A/V and iPod connections. A large 42” Sharp Aquos high definition LCD TV outfitted with a Bose sound system. Electronic curtains and mood lighting and the minibar even decked out with a Nepresso coffee machine. Now, the design of the room might not be very groundbreaking. But the comfort factor in this room is off-the-charts here. Starting with the huge King Size bed. If ever there is a hotel bed where it literally made me difficult to get up, this is the one. The mattress has just the right firmness, the high thread count linens are sumptuous and of superb quality. Large goose-down pillows and an assortment of pillows. Next the bathroom. Decked out in posh marble and the finest of modern bathroom fittings, this bathroom has an advance electronic toilet with proximity sensor and a host of automated features. The large walk-in shower cubicle has an oversized rainforest shower head that gives one of the best showering experience. Water pressure is good. There is a platform bathtub with a view, and to round things up, a high definition in wall TV. Other commendable aspects of this room is that it’s whisper quiet. The hotel wasn’t far from the Tokyo train station and yet, there is no noise whatsoever. The switches and lightings and other conveniences are all at the correct place where I wanted them. The in-room tech is not as flashy as that of the Peninsula but it works. One feature I discovered is that I could playback high definition videos from my laptop directly onto the LCD TV with the cablings provided. Only nitpick is that they should have provided an iPod dock instead of cablings to connect my iPod to the in-room music system. The room itself is a testimony of up-scale luxury. Everything thing in this room is of very high quality, from the décor to the in-room fittings right down to the accessories provided. Even the in-wall switches are clad in leather. This is a room that has very high wow factor along with providing supreme comfort. Seriously, only the best hotel suites in Hong Kong can compete with this and no other hotels that I have tried in Tokyo can measure up. Common AreasThe hotel is distinctively boutique in nature. It only have about 100+ rooms and the smaller, more intimate lobby is unlike the usual Shangri-la grandness, more subdue but still very beautifully decorated. There are only two restaurants and a bar in the hotel. The Italian restaurant serve contemporary western cuisine for lunch / dinner and morning breakfast. The breakfast is good, with nice selection of pastries and other breakfast goodies though I wish there are more selection. The other restaurant is the Nadaman Japanese restaurant, a restaurant chain often associated with Shangri-la. Tried their teppanyaki dinner and it was spectacular. Using only the freshest ingredients and cooked to perfection by the resident chef right in front of me, it’s a wonderful culinary experience of a lifetime for me. Keep in mind even by Tokyo standards, the price is very expensive, but it’s worth every cent. The hotel also have a Spa, a full size and well equipped gym and an indoor swimming pool that have spectacular views of Tokyo skyline at night. ServiceThe service at Shangri-la is fast, efficient yet gracious. Nearly every request was immediately answered. I believed they actually provide a floor butler at each floor because it’s literally seconds after I put down the phone when someone will show up at my door with the things I requested. Another major plus point about this hotel is the English proficiency of the staff. I understand that English is not a first language in Tokyo and most hotel staff I encountered during my previous visits in Tokyo have difficulties understanding more complicated request and very often, I have to repeat many times. In the Shangri-la, based on my experience, everyone from the waiter in the restaurant to the door men have a workable fluency in English which makes things much easier for me. Overall, service is just exemplary, right up there with the very best. LocationThe hotel is located in close proximity ( ie 5mins walk ) to the Tokyo station, the main transport hub of Tokyo. From there, it’s just a subway ride away from most popular destinations. Near the hotel there are also an assortment of department stores, shops and restaurants. Conclusion The Shangri-la Tokyo is now my #1 favourite hotel in Tokyo, over-taking the Peninsula which used to be my favourite. If I were to return to this city again, this will be my first choice accommodation. It’s pure indulgence and first class luxury all the way. For all these, one is expected to pay lots of Yens, but then, you can’t expect to get a true luxury hotel experience by paying peanuts. Highly recommended and I am pleased to award it my highest rating of 5 / 5.

Room was gorgeous - we had an incredible view, a huge room, with an amazing bathroom. Swimming pool is lovely, especially at night. "Spa" amenities at the gym - menthol rainshower, sauna, soaking hot tub. Service was fantatsic. Front desk attendant walked us to Tokyo station and helped us buy tickets for the Shinkansen; escorted us practically to the train platform. Front desk also helped us find a room in Narita and arranged all details. Really a wonderful experience all around (well, my husband ordered room service breakfast and hated it - but that was our only complaint). Expensive, but really a treat and perfectly located. Lots of dining options nearby and easy transport to any part of the city. A gem.
user_name:
twiggy422
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here in June 2010 for 4 nights. We are great fans of the Shang experience worldwide, but we must state that this was the best Shang location we stayed at, without doubt. The Krungthep in Bangkok (which we find overated - we saw the lady butler only once) was mediocre in comparison. The Shang Tokyo is expensive, but location wise, its great - just next to the Tokyo Marunochi station. All our needs were taken care of, and kudos to the 2 concierge staff - Koji and Hideo. They went out of their way to make us and our 3 children feel at home, and arranged everything, and answered all our questions. For parents, you would know how some top notch hotels almost 'frown' on children in their business and corporate type environment (no matter what you pay), but certainly not the Tokyo Shang. One of our best holidays, and we have every intention to return. We just hope they stay the same.

This is a nice hotel. Stayed in Tokyo also at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel and Niwa hotel. See my other reviews. The room at the Shangri La was big, modern and very clean. I had a premier room. Stayed here in August 2010 for a couple of days. The hotel's pool was very nice. Staff was ok at the reception and not trained at the breakfast restaurant. The breakfast was simply the WORST i've ever had in a hotel! Food quality was very low and the prices were very high. I complained about the breakfast and had a simple "sorry" in return!. That was quite a bummer!

The rooms were very impressive, especially if they have a view over the city. The bathroom, fixtures and fittings are all thoughtfully placed and excellent. The staff are extremely helpful and kind to guests finding their way around the city and do go the extra mile to help. It might be towards the top end in price but is great value for the experience.

Having read the good reviews, I was happy to be impressed in my recent visit. There is a complimentary concierge service to meet you when you arrive on the Narita Express and there is a good reasons for this. Like all other stations, Tokyo Station is huge and the signage is not always tourist friendly. Coupled with some construction work, I am pretty certain I would have been wondering around for some time if not met by Etika, whose very good English and friendly manner put me at ease after a tiring trip. Please remember to call the hotel ahead with your coach and seat number.The hotel is quite new and the rooms are possibly the best I have had. The view was great and facilities more than ample with a coffee machine, DVD large HD TV, numerous gadgets and of course the famous toilet. Service was very good and significantly better than some of the more average services I have had in other Shangri-Las. The pool and gym looked nice with complimentary attire, but I had no time to use them. The complimentary wifi was probably faster than most hotels I've lived in, and that includes paid wifi services.The rooms were all located from the 30th floor upwards so there was no noise from the streets.If I have any complaint about the place, it was the air conditioning which was inadequate to counter the searing heat, so I found the thick covers to be a touch hot and had trouble sleeping when I was there.Location wise, the hotel is in the central business area so it's fine if you're there for work / business. Otherwise don't expect the lights, noise and excitement of Shibuya or Shinjuku.I found the breakfast to be limited and very expensive even by Tokyo standards. There were much better local choices in the smaller restaurants in the streets behind the hotel (turn right at entrance, go down the path and cross the main road) which is what I came to Tokyo for anyway. Food in Tokyo Station itself was ample, but the restaurants were crowded and more expensive. The food section in the adjoining Daimaru is worth a visit to stock up on goodies to bring home.The concierge service was very good and they were helpful in helping me find my way in the confusing subway system. If you're going back by Narita Express, I recommend you ask them to buy the ticket for you and escort you back to the platform.On the whole this was a wonderful experience and while it wasn't cheap, you get what you pay for.

Tokyo's newest hotel, the Shangri-La is located beside the Tokyo station (Nihonbashi district) and walking distance to the Marunouchi financial center. With a discrete entrance within a larger commercial building, visitors take a separate elvator to the 28th-floor lobby. I stayed in rooms on the 33rd (3 nights) and 35th floor (2 nights) - both were deluxe rooms with a king-size bed (remarkably comfortable), very spcaious, with a panoramic view of th city from the top and packed with amenities including a WC in the bathroom (separated from the bedroom by a glass wall, with a switch to lower blinds) with a control panel ! Service was extraordinary, with the staff very helpful and extremely friendly. A Golden Circle membership (free) gives you 50% off on breakfast, and for a city as expensive as Tokyo may be well worth considering. The breakfast spread itself could be a lot wider - seemed very limited, and not only because I'm vegetarian! While I had a negotiated company rate, I understand room tariffs at Shangri-La have fallen in general, making the hotel a viable option for all travelers to Tokyo, and is clearly one of the best hotels I've stayed at while travelling overseas.

It is a quite new hotel, centrally located, just nextdoors of JR Tokyo central station. Our deluxe room was on the 33rd floor with an impressive view of Tokyo bay. Our room was great: a nice large kingsize bed, a very large bathroom with an view through the windows separating it from the bedroom, a working desk area. [Just around the corner of the hotel is the tourist information center of Tokyo or TIC]The swimming pool on the 29th floor was a distinct experience with a panoramic view of Tokyo city. Swimming high above Tokyo city does not happen everyday.Our western style breakfast buffet in Piacere was a great disappointment. Service and breakfast management was far below the quality level of Shangri-la. We arrived at 8.45 and breakfast was theoretically served until 10 am. We had a last choice of pastries, after quarter past nine there was no more resupply of the choice of pastries. At half past nine there was no more choice of fresh fruits or of breads. When we complained, we were offered a Japanese breakfast - hardly meeting what we wanted. It is false economy not resupplying breakfast items long before the end of the breakfast 10 am [this explains my poor evaluation of the hotel service].

The Shangri-La Tokyo goes down in history as the most perfect hotel I have ever had the privelege of staying in. This was my first trip to Tokyo and I only speak phrasebook Japanese (at best). The pros (there were no cons):Unfortunately, we timed our holiday at the height of summer with its humidity and temperatures that hardly waver from day to night. We never felt any of this inconvenience in the hotel. Our room was large, fully appointed and very clean. Nothing was left to chance from the L'Occitane toiletries, to the fully array of toiletries, to the special electrical appliance recharger bay. There were both kimonos and bathrobes as well as pyjamas.I love to work out on holiday (!!) and the gym and pool areas are perfect. There is no charge to use these areas. There are only 4 or 5 machines plus weights. But the big plus is that all sporting wear is available to hire for free. It is all Nike sports gear. The pool is 22m long and the water is tested every hour or so. Then there are the changerooms. Full spa, sauna and the usual including a secure locker for each guest.We dined at both restaurants. Once again, perfect service and attention to detail. We had a buffet breakfast at one restaurant and an Italian meal at the other.The laundry service was exceptional - right down to our items all being pressed and packaged in rice paper with pot pourri to keep them fresh.When booking a restaurant for you, the concierge will provide you with a map to get there, a letter to confirm your booking as well as a little card to explain the hotel's address should you get lost on the way home or need a taxi.Free wireless internet throughout the property was also greatly appreciated.There is a deli at the station and a short walk to supermarkets.The relative cons (for tourists):Relate only to the location of this hotel. It is in the business district and some may find that this doesn't give you the 'real Tokyo' experience. I loved the peace and quiet of the hotel to be honest and the fact that it was an escape from the city.However, the tourist information centre is very close to the hotel entrance and it is very helpful.Thanks for a wonderful stay and I hope to return again.

We stayed in Shangri La in Tokyo for 3 nights. Everything was simply perfect: the room was very spacious with luxury fittings and wonderful view of the town. I Just cannot find enough words to describe this beautiful hotel, the staff was always very attentive and corteous.Every single detail was astonishing. Don't miss this hotel if you go to Tokyo.

We stayed in Shangri La hotel near Tokyo station for 3 nights while visiting the town on our Holidays. Everything in the hotel is just perfect: the excellent service, the marvelous room with fantastic view of the town. We just hope to go back once again to this astonishing hotel.

What can i say more??? Their service blew us away..... Thank you so much Ms Yuki, for guiding us through ALL the way to the train platform so that we would not lose our way (and our train!) AND struggling with our heavy luggage at the same time. Our stay at Shangri La Tokyo has indeed been a very memorable one and we felt pampered in every way. We will definitely be back again and will recommend to all our friends visiting Tokyo and looking for a home away from home!

I have to rate this hotel for it's great service for children. We did stay in a small suite which was perfect size for a toddler to run amok. The hotel stay brought up treats, cookies, a Shangri la teddy, small slippers for our son and was generally very good with providing us with anything we needed within minutes of calling housekeeping. Located right next to Tokyo Station it was convenient to catch the subway everywhere and to find a quick bite to eat. There's a Daimaru at the station so we had everything we needed within walking distance.We didn't eat at the hotel since we wanted to eat out so I can't comment on the food but as far as service, location, and room facilities go two thumbs up from the whole family.

Stayed at the Shangri-la Tokyo for four nights end of May. Wonderful experience. The hotel is perfectly situated above Kyoto station (convenient for all types of commuting). Service was absolutely top-notch, the staff very helpful, and extremely professional. The room (we had a Deluxe King) was amazing with a breathtaking view on the city. Decoration was done with great taste, bathroom very elegant and amenities among the best. Pool was also a good experience. I definitely believe Shangri-La are running the hotels with some of the highest standards all across. Would go back anytime and definitely recommend it to anyone wanting to spend a few days in Tokyo.

Just returned after a one week vacation in Tokyo with 6 nights spent at the Shangri-La and one at the Peninsula. So glad it wasn't the other way around! Can't emphasize enough how remarkable a hotel the Shangri-La is from the gorgeous, spacious rooms to the ever-attentive and courteous staff. Although our room overlooked the Tokyo train station (as well as the Imperial Palace), the soundproofing meant we heard nothing and had great sleeps. The buffet breakfast is the best value that I have ever seen and as such, we ate there every morning. I have no criticism worthy of mention for the Shangri-La and would say that after years of travel at some of the world's finest hotels, this was amongst the best and would return without hesitation. The Peninsula was a disappointment on many levels and I would rate it a 4 star hotel, relative to the Shangri-La.

Our first time in Tokyo, and we wanted to treat ourselves to a big room in a luxury hotel. After browsing TA for our choices, we settled on Shangri-La, and we couldn't be happier we did.We booked the Bay View Deluxe room (I think that's what it was called) which sat at the corner of the 33rd floor with a stunning view of the Tokyo cityscape and Imperial Gardens. The room itself was wonderfully spacious, with a large queen bed, comfortable couch, good-sized desk and a 42" flat screen TV conveniently placed for easy watching from bed or desk (though not from the couch). The bathroom was lovely, with a rainfall shower stall easily big enough for two and a separate inset bathtub adjacent to a window with another stunning view of the city (we used the tub regularly and the view at night while soaking therein was fantastic).The hotel's location is good, in that it sits in the middle of Chiyoda-Ku and a ten minute walk from the beautiful Imperial Gardens. What was great, however, was that the hotel was a fifteen-step walk from Tokyo Station, which meant going anywhere in the city or out couldn't be more convenient.The staff was incredible, from the front desk and concierge to housekeeping and room service. We received great recommendations for places to shop and eat, and on our departure the head concierge and a porter actually raced through Tokyo station with us, hauling our bags for us, to make sure we wouldn't miss our Shinkansen to Osaka. The level of dedication to service blew my mind, as none of that was at all expected.My caveats to this great review are:1. Such great treatment comes with a stiff price, but considering how we were treated I paid it with a smile and gave everyone I could find a tip on top of it.2. The hotel food, both room service and the Italian restaurant at lobby level, were not spectacular in general but poor considering their prices. Luckily, if you're staying there you're in a city with more restaurants per block than any other worldwide, so why are you dining in anyway?All in all a fantastic hotel and I hope to stay there again whensoever I fly back through Tokyo.

I stayed here for 6 nights on a holiday to Tokyo. This hotel is in a fantastic location, right next to Tokyo station although for first timers trying to find the hotel after getting off the train was a bit of a challenge and requires more signage directing you to the hotel. It also has a Daimaru department store next door, as well as many other convenience stores nearby. It is not cheap, but then nothing is in Tokyo but I considered that for value and location, Shangri-la beat the other options. It is also close to Ginza and Marunouchi (lots of restaurants, shops, cafes), and as mentioned adjacent to Tokyo station.The service was first class and could not be faulted. When I checked in I was taken by the Guest Relations Manager directly to my room for the check in process and everything was explained to me. She even gave me her business card.The room was enormous, exceptionally well appointed and comfortable and I could have spent all my time in it, had it not been for all the sights to see in Tokyo!!The bathroom was amazing and included a fantastic electronically controlled toilet which meant that you did not have to touch anything as it sensed when you were approaching the toilet and raised the lid and flushed automatically then closed the lid. A shower with rainforest shower rose as an option and bath were located in a separate large "room" and a vanity with extensive amenities including a special set for women. The room included Shangri-la pyjamas, robes and kimonos and slippers. Instead of an iron there was a steamer which was a very good idea. Electronically controlled day and night blinds in the main room as well as in the shower room, as well as mood lighting options.Linen was superb (as would be expected) and there was a full range of L'occitane toiletries available plus a range of other items such as a hairbrush, mouthwash and razors, toothbrushes etc.I had breakfast in the restaurant once but felt a little uncomfortable being on my own and surrounded by mostly Japanese couples and families!!The fitness centre was small but reasonably well equipped with several cardio machines, free weights and an integrated weights machine which was somewhat complicated to set up for various exercises. It certainly would not be very efficient if there were several people wanting to use it. There was also a very nice looking pool beside the fitness centre. The hotel also has a chi spa which I did not use.I would definitely recommend this hotel and would not hesitate to stay here again.

Stayed here for 2 nights when we first arrived in Japan and from the booking to the end of our trip (2 weeks after we left the hotel) the shangri la was perfect.We chose this hotel because it seemed the best value out of all the top hotels in Tokyo and after our stay I would say that it would be hard to beat. Great location (opposite North exit of Tokyo Station), top class service, a very big room with a good view and an excellent bathroom. I give the concierge 6 stars as no matter how much I bothered them (i asked them about studio ghibli museum tickets on about 5 seperate occasions, including after we had left the hotel) they always provided the best service, they really impressed, in fact the all the staff did.

We recently stayed here over the long easter weekend and could not be more satisfied. Traveling with our 18 month old daughter, the condition and quality of the room was of absolute importance and the Shangrila exceeded our expectations. The size of the room, level of comfort, cleanliness, bed, linens and especially the bath area were excellent.Wonderful L'occitance bath amenities.The Shangrila teddy bear for our daughter at turn down was a nice touch.The hotel's proximity to Tokyo Station, and more importantly, Daimaru department store (the prepared foods section was ideal for feeding our toddler) lends to the hotel's excellent location.The staff was friendly and helpful when asked, but not overly so. One note is that we speak both English and Japanese but made the mistake of calling down to the concierge for a restaurant recommendation in English. We were directed to an absolutely mediocre but English friendly (read: touristy) restaurant in Ginza. Not necessarily a negative as I can understand their thought process, but the meal was extremely disappointing nonetheless.The only negative I can think of would be that the lobby and check in area isnt particularly grand and often smelled of cigarette smoke from the attached coffee shop / restaurant.

My wife and I are travelling to Tokyo regularly and for a while already we wanted to try the new Shangri-La, because it is located right next to Tokyo station. It turned out to be a perfect choice, because not only is the location very convenient, the service was really amazing. We were escorted from Shinkansen platform to the hotel and all staff were so warm and friendly, which made us feel home from the moment we arrived. We had a dinner at the beautiful Italian restaurant and they had a special Earth Hour night with live music and the food and service were fantastic. We visit a lot of good restaurants on our trips to Tokyo and usually try foreign cuisine places with at least one Michelin star. We hope that this restaurant will also get one soon, because the experience was really outstanding.Overall there is nothing to criticize about this hotel. The facilities are very nice and luxurious, but the most amazing was the service. In Japan we have a very strong culture for service, but Shangri-La should be a new benchmark for hotels in Tokyo.

We stayed for four nights at the Shangri-La in Tokyo and couldn't wait to write a review for this amazing hotel.Here are the bullet points:Location: Fantastic location, right next to Tokyo station (literally a 1 minute walk). Many will tell you to stay in Shinjuku or Shibuya, but Nihonbashi, where the Shangri-La -conveniently located next to Tokyo station, as mentioned, which allows for easy day trips outside the city, or even within the city on the JR lines or Tokyo subway line-less than 10 minute walk to the great shopping area of Ginza-the area is a business area so generally seems a bit more upscaleService:Wow - just awesome.The concierge service was outstanding - I called the concierge ahead of time to ask if they could book us into one of Tokyo's famed Michelin 3 star Japanese restaurants for a special occasion, and if they weren't available, to try some 2 stars that they would recommend. This isn't a typical request, and is a fair amount of work, but they did so without hesitation. They called all the 3 stars AND a few 2 stars, and gave us options for that evening... all within a few hours. When we arrived, they had already prepared envelopes outlining the details of our reservation, directions, etc.The maid service was also great with a few nice touches, which may not seem like much, but really put the hotel a notch above. For the turndown, they leave on BOTH night stands a new bottle of mineral water with a fresh glass every night. They also provide nice Shangri-La pajamas (which they will fold on the bed - and provide you new ones if they can't find the ones you wore.) Just nice touches.A number of the staff in the lobby even made a point of seeing you to the elevator when you left the building (the lobby is on the 28th floor) just so they could bow to you as the doors closed. Totally unnecessary, but just typical of the service you get here.Rooms:See photos attached. Big rooms even not in a suite. The shower is gigantic. Wall mounted flat screen with BOSE speakers. High ceilings. The blinds can completely shut out any light when closed. 5 different settings for the lights. You name it, it had everything. And everything (blind control, lights, toilet) is automated. The toilet has buttons for whether you want both seats up, one seat up, or both down, and automatically raises the top lid when it senses motion (and closes it when there's no motion). What more can be said - this is a great hotel that we would recommend to everyone. We'd stay here again in a heartbeat. And having stayed at other hotels in Japan on this trip (where we paid almost similar prices for nowhere near the quality of the Shangri-La), the value for your money is there without question. Absolute thumbs up.

I spent a really amazing week at this hotel.Everything is great, and people were really nice.Maybe just one thing about food, it could be better. I mean it look like classic food you can find in any hotel of this kind.I was expecting something different...

After a 6.5 hours flight from Singapore, we arrived in Tokyo via the Narita Express (one hour ride). Upon leaving the train, we turn to our right and saw the sign 'Yaesu Central', but there was no 'Yaesu North' exit anywhere , as advertised on the Hotel's website. So, we walked towards this Yaesu Central exit, turn to our left and finally found the right exit near the Daimaru Departmental Store. From here, turn left, walk straight and turn left again, its another 1-2 minutes slow walk to the Hotel's somewhat nondescript ground floor lobby. We then arrived on the 28th floor check in area. This is a classier area, styled with elegance and alot of thoughtfulness. The receptionist lady was friendly and courteous, however, the procedures to get checked in seemed somewhat slow to two weary and tired travellers. We booked the lowest room category, the Superior rooms, and was assigned room 3121. This room, being located near the corner of a walkway, is both spacious and really quiet for a good nights sleep. Everything was new and high tech, however, there was no mood lighting as with the case of the Peninsula Tokyo which we had stayed last year. The clear glass Bathroom comes with a nice tub, huge overhead Rain shower and a standing shower. Curtains can then be drawled to ensure privacy. But alas, the bathroom door is also in clear glass, so when my mum showers, I cannot use the wash basin area, since it was adjacent to the Bathroom. The single wash basin is huge, however, we would prefer two smaller basins to one large basin. Toilet wise, in a separated cubicle, is also rather high tech. However, whenever one walks near it, the toilet seat cover would automatically moves up, creating some noise when one visits it late at night, and this might disturb the other sleeping partner. The other gripe was the expensive breakfasts - Continental & Oriental, both at 2,700 yen each, European 3,500 yen and Japanese, 3,900 yen! Since we are no breakfasts people, we didn't dine at the Hotel. Our twin beds, was, very comfy and spacious indeed. Curtains and blinds are all automated, huge flat screen TV right in front of the bed and beside the wash basin. Writing table also serves as our breakfast table, which was nice! There was even daily complimentary mineral water, tea and coffee bags. On arrival, we even get a plate of yummy chocolates! Both pyjamas and yukatas are also available in the room, what a thoughtful gesture! The two female Conceirges at Reception was ultra friendly and extremely helpful! They even helped to book our train tickets to Nikko with no extra charges, print out tour and travel info on Nikko without us even having to ask for them ... really touched. And oh yes, they all speak very good English! Everyone was really kind and helpful to us, calling for taxis whenever we needed one at the Basement level. All the good points as mentioned above, with the Hotel's superb location, just next to the Tokyo Station, is every weary traveller to Tokyo's dream! Our favourite Tokyo hotel to date, the Peninsula, even requires a short 5-10 minutes taxi ride, but this brand new Shangri-La is even better, doing away with the need of a taxi ride! A few tips about staying here - the nearby Daimaru has a wonderful food hall at its basement level and the subway ride to Shinjuku on the Rapid Chuo Line is only but a 4 stop journey (GO- platforms 1 & 2, BACK - platforms 7 & 8)... and do ask Receptions for the Subway map. As for Nikko, the cheapest option would be taking a cab (10-15 minutes) to the Tobu-Asakusa station, 1,800-2,000 yen depending on traffic. A normal one-way ride is 1340 yen, while a faster one is 2620 yen. Compared with the Tokyo station's JR Shinkansen, which will set you back about 5,400 yen, the Tobu ride is a better option. Moreover, the Tobu trains are non-stop, while the JR Shinkansen requires a change of train. All in all, we had a wonderful two nights stay at this superb Hotel. If we return to Tokyo again, we wouldn't stay anywhere else but here. However, we would love to try out their higher room category the next time. Hope there would be more surprises then?!

After a long flight from London, the location of the Shangri-La Hotel right by Tokyo station made it incredibly easy to access from the Narita Express. The hotel is situated on the top floors of an office tower, so you start the experience by entering a street level lift lobby that whisks you straight up to the 28th Floor. The staff greet you at every stage with a beaming smile and impeccable politemess.Check-in was swift and efficient and our room was ready for us, even though we were arrived a few hours earlier then the official check-in time. We were escorted to our 'Deluxe' room on the 35th floor and guided around the various features of the room.The room was absolutely amazing! It was a large, very well appointed room with a stunning view over Tokyo Station and the Imperial Palace and over to the skycrapers of Shinjuku in the distance. There was more than enough storage available, a huge TV with a BOSE sound system that also connected directly to a laptop or i-Pod should you want to play your own music through the system.The bathroom was out of this world with 3 distinct areas to it - the wet room with a huge overhead rainfall shower plus a deep soaking bath, the main washbasin was massive with a great selection of amenities and finally the show-stopper.....the hi-tech Japanese toilet! Fully automatic, right down to even lifiting the lid, the toilet was a real novelty with a heated seat and various heated water spray options!The beds were extremely comfortable with full bedside controls for almost everything in the room, including electrically operated window blinds.As our room rate did not include breakfast, we ordered room service on a couple of occasions and that was also perfectly presented. Basically, it is impossible to fault anything in this hotel!!! Obviously, a luxury 5 star hotel in Tokyo is not going to be cheap and the food and drinks were very expensive but that's normal in a city centre hotel.I would thoroughly recommend this hotel to anyone wanting a few days of absolute luxury and excellent service, in a central location handy for Tokyo station and access to the Tokyo Metro for getting around the city.

Beautiful, sparkly hotel (there are crystals everywhere) In a brilliant central location right next to Tokyo station, it makes getting around Tokyo very easy as most public transport goes through Tokyo station. Good views to Mount Fuji and into the gardens of the Imperial Palace. The service is impeccable, the staff cannot do enough for you. The rooms are spacious, quite business like rather than very sexy, but have everything you could want right down to the heated loo seat. Nice if small gym with very lovely spa, the hot tub is out of this world!!! In a slightly business-y area in terms of restaurants in the evening but there are good local places to be found and karoke nearby!!If you get invited to use the Horizon club, its fantastic and the complimentary snacks and drinks from 6-8pm is a fantastic way to start your night. The room service food was also very good, if not cheap!

The new addition to the Shangri-La family provides a very intense personal experience with outstanding service and attention to detail. The staff are excessively attentive and hosusekeeping service is the best I have seen anywhere. The hotel is well located adjancet to the main Tokyo station situated in the upper parts of an office block. As you might suspect this hotel does not do "casual" so expect fine meals and wines not casual quick snacks. The rooms are very well equipped and designed (with the curious exception of the washroom TV, commented upon by another reviewer). The Horizon Club offered an attentive service and I am grateful to the wonderful staff there for their assistance in arranging travel and helpful conversation each day. Its a great place for a business stay. Thanks everyone!
I stayed at this hotel on the day of the opening because I read about it and I was happy to see that the staff pay so much attention on the customer. I love this shangri-la hotel
